ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Parks and recreation program fees. 
    The fees and charges for all parks and recreation programs and facility use which are not otherwise specified in this chapter shall be provided on the schedule of recreation program fees for athletics, special programs, camps, tennis, swimming, gymnastics and rental of facilities, as such schedule is on file in the city clerk's office. The parks and recreation director shall assure that a current fee schedule is maintained on file in the city clerk's office at all times, and as recreation fees and facility use charges are set during the annual budget adoption process of the city council, the schedule shall be accordingly revised and updated as filed in the city clerk's office. 
(Ord. No. 855, § 1, 9-24-91) 
Secs. 14-2-14-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MARINE ACTIVITIES 

Sec. 14-16. - Boats speed 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any boat or other watercraft upon any waterway or body of water within the city at a rate of speed which causes waves to damage docks, wharves, seawalls or boats moored or tied to docks or wharves. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any boat or other watercraft in any of the waters in the city in such a manner as to endanger life or property. 
(b)  All canals located within the city shall be designated as idle speed/no wake zones and posted as same. 
(c)  That portion of Biscayne Bay located within the city limits, shall be designated as slow speed/minimum wake zone and posted as same. 
(Code 1958, § 15-3; Ord. No. 1266, § 1, 9-9-08) 
Sec. 14-17. - Waterskiing prohibited. 
    Waterskiing is prohibited on the canals and waterways in the city except for Biscayne Bay. 
(Code 1958, § 15-3) 
Sec. 14-18. - Fishing from private property. 
    It shall be unlawful for anyone to fish from any private property in the city without the express permission from the owner or lessee of the property. Where such property is vacant, failure to provide written evidence of such permission shall be considered as prima facie evidence of lack of such permission. 
(Code 1958, § 15-20.1) 
Sec. 14-19. - Signs requiring use of life vests to be posted at boating marinas. 
(a)  Sign required. Any person owning or operating any marina located within the city shall post a U.S. Coast Guard approved signage reminding boaters of the necessity to utilize life vests while engaged in boating activities. This sign shall be in the form set forth below: 
NOTICE 
Every person under six (6) years of age on board a motorboat, sailboat, or vessel which measures less than twenty-six (26) feet in length shall wear a type I, II, or III Coast Guard approved personal flotation device while such motorboat, sailboat, or vessel is underway. 
(b)  Penalty. Any person who violates any provision of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separated violation. This section shall also by subject to enforcement by the Local Government Code Enforcement Board Act, F.S. Ch. 162, as amended. Enforcement may also be by suit for declaratory, injunctive, or other appropriate relief in a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 930, §§ 1, 2, 2-28-95) 
Sec. 14-20. - Penalties. 
    Any violations of this article shall be subject to civil penalties pursuant to chapter 2, division 5.3 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of North Miami. 
(Ord. No. 1266, § 1, 9-9-08) 
Secs. 14-21-14-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PARKS AND RECREATION FACILITIES 

Sec. 14-36. - Parks and recreation facilities available to public. 
    The use of the public parks and recreational facilities of the city shall be limited to residents of the city and their invited guests except where nonresident fees or conditions for use by nonresidents have been established by the city or when otherwise required by law. 
(Code 1958, § 16-1) 
Sec. 14-37. - Identification required 
    Any person using the public parks and recreational facilities of the city shall produce upon request of an official of the parks and recreation department or a police officer of the city, sufficient identification to establish his place of residence for purposes of determining the fee for use of the facilities or for any access policies. 
(Code 1958, § 16-2) 
Sec. 14-38. - Hours of operation. 
(a)  City parks, pool and other recreation areas and facilities shall be made available to the public during the hours established by administrative regulations. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person other than city personnel conducting city business to occupy or be present in the park during any hours in which the park is not open to the public. City-sponsored or supervised events may be extended beyond normal closing hours until their completion. 
(c)  Any section or part of a park or recreation area may remain open or closed to the public by order of the city manager at any time and for any interval of time either temporarily or at regular or stated intervals for city-sponsored or sanctioned programs or in the event of an emergency or for matters affecting the public's health, safety and welfare. 
(Code 1958, § 16-3; Ord. No. 988, § 1, 2-10-98; Ord. No. 1269, § 1, 10-14-08) 
Sec. 14-39. - Griffing Adult Center Park boat ramp permit. 
(a)  No motorized boat shall use the Griffing Adult Center Park boat ramp without a permit. 
Permit fees shall be: 
(1)  June 1-August 31: 
Resident ..... $50.00 
Nonresident ..... 100.00 
(2)  September 1-December 31: 
Resident ..... 37.50 
Nonresident ..... 75.00 
(3)  January 1-March 31: 
Resident ..... 25.00 
Nonresident ..... 50.00 
(4)  April 1-May 31: 
Resident ..... 12.50 
Nonresident ..... 25.00 
The permit fee for resident citizens age sixty-five (65) and older is hereby waived. 
(b)  Upon payment of the launch fee, permits shall be issued to all persons who have not been convicted of violating the provisions of this Code including but not limited to violation of the wake and speed ordinances regarding the operation of boats. Permits may be revoked upon conviction of violation of this section or of the wake and speed ordinances regarding the operation of boats. An official decal shall be displayed on the trailer and boat of each permittee. The city manager or his designee shall have the power to establish the procedures necessary to implement the provisions of this section. Such procedures shall include execution by the permittee of a license agreement, as prepared by the city attorney, a copy of which is on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1958, § 16A; Ord. No. 1028, § 1, 9-21-99) 
Secs. 14-40-14-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - MUNICIPAL SWIMMING POOLS 

Sec. 14-51. - Declaration of purpose; interpretation 
    All persons are hereby declared eligible to purchase a family membership which will provide them with the privilege of utilizing the municipal swimming pools and related facilities owned by the city at a rate on file in the city clerk's office. Family membership shall be interpreted to mean a membership issued to and purchased by any person and the membership shall include the legal dependents. 
(Code 1958, § 16-12) 
Sec. 14-52. - Communicable diseases; abusing facilities. 
(a)  Any person known to the public authorities in charge of the municipal swimming pools of the city to be infected with any communicable malady or disease, or who the public authorities may have reason to believe is infected with a communicable malady or disease, may be denied admission to the municipal swimming pools of the city and barred therefrom during the continuance of the malady or disease, so as to provide for the protection of the public health and welfare of other citizens or persons using the subject recreational facilities. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person having any communicable disease to enter the municipal swimming pools of the city. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to misuse or abuse the facilities of the municipal swimming pools of the city or cause a breach of the peace. Such person may be barred and denied admission by the public authorities charged with the management of the swimming pools. 
(Code 1958, § 16-16) 
Secs. 14-53-14-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - TENNIS CENTER 

Sec. 14-66. - City tennis fee schedule. 
    The tennis fee schedule shall be on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1958, § 16-30) 
Sec. 14-67. - Operation. 
    The operation of the city's tennis facilities shall be under the supervision of the director of parks and recreation who shall establish reasonable rules and regulations concerning the use of the courts. All such rules and regulations shall be subject to the approval of the city manager. 
(Code 1958, § 16-32) 
Chapter 15 - PERSONNEL, PENSIONS AND RETIREMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1361, § 2, adopted November 12, 2013, changed the title of chapter 15 from "Pensions and retirement" to "Personnel, pensions and retirement." 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; personnel department created, § 2-231; police department, § 2-231; finance, Ch. 7; fire prevention, Ch. 8; taxation, Ch. 18. 
State Law reference- Actuarial soundness of retirement systems, F.S. § 112.60 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - DEPARTMENT OF PERSONNEL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- See editor's note at article II. 

Sec. 15-1. - Merit basis of appointment. 
    Appointments and promotions in the city's classified service shall be made according to merit and fitness to be ascertained, so far as practicable, by competitive examination. 
(Ord. No. 1361, § 2, 11-12-13) 
Sec. 15-2. - Personnel manager; qualifications. 
    The personnel manager shall have had training and experience in personnel administration. 
(Ord. No. 1361, § 2, 11-12-13) 
Sec. 15-3. - Personnel manager; powers and duties. 
    The personnel manager shall have power and shall be required to: 
(1)  Hold all competitive examinations required under this chapter, given for appointments in the classified service; 
(2)  Give wide publicity through appropriate channels for all position vacancies; 
(3)  Prepare and recommend to the personnel board such rules as he or she may consider necessary, appropriate or desirable to carry out the provisions of this article as provided in section 15-7 of this chapter; 
(4)  Maintain a classification and pay plan based on the duties, authority and responsibility of positions in the city service; 
(5)  Prepare and maintain a pay plan in the city service; 
(6)  Establish and maintain a roster of all persons in the municipal service in which there shall be set forth, as to each employee, (i) the class title of the position held, (ii) salary or pay, (iii) any changes in class title, pay or status, (iv) such other data as may be deemed desirable or useful to produce significant facts pertaining to personnel administration; 
(7)  Monitor all payrolls for persons in the city service. No payment for personnel service to any person in the service of the city shall be made unless the payroll includes the approval of the department head or his authorized alternate that the persons mentioned therein have worked the hours paid or for approved paid leave; 
(8)  Certify that all persons in the municipal service have been appointed and employed in accordance with the provisions of this article; 
(9)  Develop and establish training and educational programs for persons in the municipal service; 
(10)  Investigate periodically the operation and effect of the personnel provisions of this chapter and the rules promulgated hereunder, and report his findings and recommendations to the city manager; and 
(11)  Perform such other and different lawful acts and functions as he or she may deem necessary or desirable to enforce the purposes and provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1361, § 2, 11-12-13) 
Sec. 15-4. - Personnel board; appointment. 
(a)  There shall be a personnel board consisting of six (6) members who shall be appointed as follows: One (1) member by the mayor (without approval of the city council) designated as Group A; one (1) member by the city council (excluding the mayor) designated as Group B; one (1) member by the city council (excluding the mayor) designated as Group C; one (1) member elected by the employees designated as Group D; one (1) member elected by the employees designated as Group E; and one (1) member by the mayor with the approval of the city council who shall be designated the "alternate". No member of the personnel board shall be an employee of the City of North Miami. "Employee" shall mean the employees paid by the city. The terms of office of the personnel board members shall run from the second Tuesday in June commencing in 1971 and the initial term for Group A shall be one (1) year; Group B, two (2) years; Group C, three (3) years; Group D, two (2) years; Group E, three (3) years, with all successive appointments for three (3) years. The term of the board member and alternate appointed by the mayor shall be coterminous with the mayor's term of office. The city council may at any time remove a board member from office and appoint a qualified person to serve out the unexpired term of any board member so removed. 
(b)  The personnel manager shall prescribe rules, regulations and procedures in connection with election of the two (2) members to the board by the city employees. 
(c)  Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as original appointments were made and shall be for the unexpired term of the member whose position is vacated. 
(Ord. No. 1361, § 2, 11-12-13; Ord. No. 1372, § 1, 4-22-14) 
Sec. 15-5. - Personnel board; qualifications. 
    Each member shall be a qualified voter of the city and shall be known to be in sympathy with the merit principle as applied to the civil service. Proof of residency is required. 
(Ord. No. 1361, § 2, 11-12-13) 
Sec. 15-6. - Personnel board; compensation. 
    Members of the board may be allowed compensation as shall be determined by ordinance for each meeting devoted to the work of the board. 
(Ord. No. 1361, § 2, 11-12-13) 
Sec. 15-7. - Personnel board; powers and duties. 
    The board shall have power and shall be required to: 
(1)  Advise the personnel manager on problems concerning personnel administration; 
(2)  Advise personnel manager in fostering the interest of institutions of learning, civic, professional and employee organizations in the improvement of personnel standards in the municipal service; 
(3)  Make any inquiry which it may consider desirable concerning the administration of personnel in the municipal service, and report to the city manager, its findings, conclusions and recommendations; 
(4)  Hear appeals of employees in the classified service who are suspended, reduced or removed and report in writing to the city manager its findings and recommendations; and 
(5)  Review the activities of the personnel department and recommend changes to city manager in accordance with their findings. 
(Ord. No. 1361, § 2, 11-12-13) 
Sec. 15-8. - Rules. 
(a)  The personnel manager shall prepare and recommend to the board such rules as he or she may consider necessary, appropriate or desirable to carry out the provisions of this article. After a public hearing thereon, the board shall approve or reject the rules wholly or in part, or may modify them, and approve them as so modified. Rules and amendments thereto which are approved by the board or on which the board takes no action within sixty (60) days after they are recommended by the personnel manager, shall be transmitted to the city manager for filing with the council. Rules and amendments thereto shall become effective when approved by the council or on the tenth day after submission if prior thereto the council shall not have rejected them by resolution. Thereafter the board shall have power to amend, repeal or add to the rules on the recommendation of the personnel manager or on its own initiative, subject to the requirement of a public hearing and all the other subsequent steps of procedure required herein for adoption of the original set of rules. 
(b)  Rules adopted hereunder shall have the force and effect of law. They shall provide for the method of holding competitive examinations, the establishment, maintenance, consolidation and cancellation of eligible lists, administration of classification plan and the pay plan, the application of service ratings, the hours of work, attendance regulation and leaves of absence for employees in the classified service, the order and manner in which layoffs shall be effected, and similar matters of personnel administration. 
(c)  The powers herein conferred upon the personnel manager shall be subject only to the provisions of this chapter and of the rules adopted hereunder, and may be exercised by regulation or by order as the personnel manager sees fit. 
(Ord. No. 1361, § 2, 11-12-13) 
Sec. 15-9. - Unclassified and classified service. 
    The civil service of the city shall be divided into the unclassified and the classified service. 
(1)  The unclassified service shall comprise the following offices and positions: 
a.  Members of the city council and other elected officers, and persons appointed to fill vacancies in elected offices; 
b.  The city clerk; 
c.  The city manager, deputy city manager and the assistant manager, if any; 
d.  The city attorney, deputy city attorney, assistant city attorney, paralegal, and legal secretary, if any; 
e.  The directors or managers of each city department or division (or such other individual employed as the head of his/her respective department or division) and their respective confidential secretaries; 
f.  One (1) executive assistant or deputy and one (1) executive secretary to the city manager; 
g.  The police chief, assistant police chief(s), police commander(s), police major(s) and police lieutenant(s); 
h.  Members of boards and commissions in the city's service; 
i.  Those positions which are either of a temporary nature or which require peculiar and exceptional qualifications of a specific, managerial, professional or educational character which positions do not fall within any existing classification and the duties of which do not fall within the scope of the specifications set up for any existing classification, and which do not warrant the establishment of a new classification or the expansion of the specifications in an existing classification because of the temporary nature of the employment. 
(2)  The classified service shall comprise all positions not specifically included by this section in the unclassified service. 
(Ord. No. 1361, § 2, 11-12-13) 
Sec. 15-10. - Classification. 
(a)  The personnel manager shall prepare and maintain an up to date record of the authority, duties and responsibilities of each position in the classified service. The personnel manager shall prepare and submit to the personnel board a plan of classification and grading of all such positions according to similarity of authority, duties and responsibilities. The city manager shall submit the classification plan to the council with such changes as he or she deems desirable and such plan shall take effect when adopted by the council. 
(b)  Changes in the classification plan which the personnel manager deems desirable may be recommended and adopted from time to time in the same manner as herein provided for the original adoption of the plan. 
(c)  As promptly as practicable after the adoption of the classification plan, and after any amendment thereof, the personnel manager shall, with the approval of the city manager, allocate each position in the classified service to the appropriate class therein on the basis of its authority, duties and responsibilities. Thereafter, as new positions are created or additional classes are established, or existing classes are divided, combined, altered or abolished, the personnel manager shall make such allocations or reallocations of positions to new or existing classes as are necessitated thereby. 
(d)  Following the adoption of the classification plan and the allocation to classes therein of positions in the classified service, the class titles set forth therein shall be used to designate such positions in all official records, documents, vouchers and communications, and no person shall be appointed to or employed in a position in the classified service under any class title which has not been approved by the personnel manager as appropriate to the duties to be performed. 
(e)  Employees affected by the allocation or reallocation of a position to a class, or by changes in the classification plan, shall be afforded a reasonable opportunity to be heard thereon after filing with the personnel manager a written request for a hearing. 
(Ord. No. 1361, § 2, 11-12-13) 
Sec. 15-11. - Promotions. 
    Vacancies in higher positions in the classified service of the city shall, as far as practicable, be filled by promotion from lower classes following competitive tests. A change from a position in any class to a position in another class for which a higher maximum rate of pay is prescribed shall be considered a promotion. The personnel manager shall, to the extent he or she considers such action desirable, indicate the lines of promotion from and to each class in the class specifications or in regulation. 
(Ord. No. 1361, § 2, 11-12-13) 
Sec. 15-12. - Pay plan. 
    The personnel manager shall prepare for the city manager a standard schedule of pay for each position in the city service: The city manager shall submit the pay plan to the council with such changes as he or she deems desirable and such plan shall take effect when adopted by the council by resolution. The pay plan adopted by the council shall include a minimum and maximum and such intermediate rates as may be deemed desirable for each class of position. Amendments to the pay schedule may be adopted by the council, from time to time, upon recommendation of the city manager. In increasing or decreasing items in the city budget, the council shall not increase or decrease any individual salary items but shall act solely with respect to classes of positions as established in the classification and pay plans. In no event shall the council reduce the salary of a class below the minimum or raise it above the maximum salary established by the pay plan except by amendment of the pay plan. 
(Ord. No. 1361, § 2, 11-12-13) 
Sec. 15-13. - Pension and retirement system. 
    The council shall have authority to establish a pension and retirement system for any or all groups of officers and employees in service of the city. Any such pension and retirement system shall be established on a jointly contributory basis. The cost of the system shall be determined actuarially on the basis of such mortality and service tables as the council shall approve and shall be calculated and contributed as a uniform or decreasing percentage of the payroll of members. No system requiring an increasing percentage of the payroll to be paid as the contribution of either the members or the city shall be established. The provisions of the ordinance establishing such a pension and retirement system shall require periodic actuarial evaluations which shall serve as the basis of any changes in the rates of contributions and shall also provide for the maintenance at all times of adequate reserves. Any officer or employee of the city at the time of the establishment of such system shall have for a reasonable time thereafter the privilege of becoming a member of the system so established and to share its benefits. Officers and employees thereafter appointed in the classified service shall be required to join the system as a condition of employment. Existing local pension and relief funds under the provisions of the state law shall continue as long as such laws are in effect or until the beneficiaries thereof have elected to become members of the system set up in conformity with the provisions of this section; but the beneficiaries of any system under state law may be limited by the provisions of the pension and retirement system created under this section to those officers and employees who were the beneficiaries of such funds at the time of the adoption of a pension and retirement system as herein authorized. No officer or employee of the city may be a beneficiary of a local pension or relief fund established under state law and at the same time a member of a pension and retirement system established hereunder, except Federal Social Security if such is in existence at the time the pension plan is set up. Any pension and retirement system established or administered under the provisions of this section shall be administered by a board of trustees, subject to the approval of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1361, § 2, 11-12-13) 
Sec. 15-14. - Oaths; prohibitions. 
(a)  For the purpose of the administration of the personnel provisions of this chapter, any member of the personnel board and personnel manager shall have the power to administer oaths. 
(b)  No person in the classified service of the city or seeking admission thereto shall be appointed, promoted, reduced, removed, or in any way favored or discriminated against because of his race religion, creed, color, national origin, age, gender, disability, marital status or his political or religious opinions or affiliations. No person shall willfully or corruptly make any false statement, certificate, mark, rating or report in regard to any test, certification, or appointment held or made under the personnel provisions of this chapter or in any manner commit or attempt to commit any fraud preventing the impartial execution of such personnel provisions or of the rules and regulations made thereunder. No officer or employee in the service of the city shall continue in such position after becoming a candidate for nomination or election to any public office. No person seeking appointment to or promotion in the service of the city shall either directly or indirectly give, render or pay any money, service or other valuable thing to any person for or on account of or in connection with his test, appointment, proposed appointment, promotion or proposed promotion. No person shall orally, by letter, or otherwise solicit or be in any manner concerned in soliciting any assessment, subscription or contribution for any political party or political purpose whatever on city property from any person holding a position in the service of the city. No person holding a position in the service of the city shall make any contribution to the campaign funds of any political party or any candidate for public office or take any part in the management, affairs or political campaign of any political party, further than in the exercise of his rights as a citizen to express his opinion and to cast his vote. 
(c)  Any person who by himself or with others willfully or corruptly violates any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall upon conviction thereof be punished by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment for a term not exceeding two (2) months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. Any person who is convicted under this section shall for a period of five (5) years be ineligible for appointment to or employment in a position in the city service, and shall, if he be an officer or employee of the city, immediately forfeit the office or position he or she holds. 
(Ord. No. 1361, § 2, 11-12-13) 
ARTICLE II. - RETIREMENT IN GENERAL[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1361, § 2, adopted November 12, 2013, redesignated the former article I, § 15-1 as article II, § 15-15. The historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 

Sec. 15-15. - Limited extension to mandatory retirement age for police officers. 
    The fifty-fifth year of age mandatory retirement date for the City of North Miami police officers, as provided in this chapter, may be extended to the age of fifty-six (56), upon request of the employee subject to such mandatory retirement, subject to the condition that the chief of police find and certify as essential the continued service of such officer for an additional period of one (1) year, not to exceed age fifty-six (56) years, and subject to the approval of such certification by the city manager, and authorization of such certification action by the city council. Upon receipt of such certification of the police chief and approval of the city manager, the city council may by ordinance, authorize such one-year extension. 
(Ord. No. 878, § 1, 9-22-92; Ord. No. 1361, § 2, 11-12-13) 
ARTICLE III. - EMPLOYEES' RETIREMENT SYSTEM; ORD. NO. 582[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1361, § 2, adopted November 12, 2013, redesignated the former articles II and III as articles III and IV. The historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 

Sec. 15-16. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, unless a different meaning is plainly required by the context, the following words and phrases shall have the following respective meanings: 
    Accumulated contributions means the sum of all amounts deducted from the compensation of a member and credited to his individual account, together with interest credited on such amounts at the rate of three and one-half (31/2) percent per annum, accrued from the January first coinciding with or next following the date of each such deduction and accrued to the January first coinciding with or immediately preceding the date on which such accumulated contributions shall be determined. 
    Actuarial equivalent means the benefit of equal value when computed upon the basis of such actuarial tables as are from time to time adopted. 
    Beneficiary means any person so designated by a member as provided in section 15-45 who may become entitled to receive benefits under this article. 
    Compensation means total compensation payable to an employee working the full normal working period for his position. 
    Contributions means the amounts deducted from the compensation of a member as provided in sections 15-33 through 15-38. 
    Disability retirement means retirement upon the disability retirement date as provided in section 15-40(b). 
    Effective date means May 1, 1956. 
    Employee means every person regularly employed on a full-time basis by the City of North Miami. 
    Employer means the City of North Miami, Florida. 
    Fund means the North Miami Employees' Retirement Fund created by this article. 
    Member means any employee who is included in the membership of the system. 
    Membership service means service rendered while a member of the system following the effective date of the retirement system. 
    Membership service allowance means the retirement allowance to which a member is entitled as provided herein because of the membership service reserve accumulated to his account during his membership service. 
    Membership service reserve means the sum of all amounts deducted from the compensation of a member, plus the sum of all matching contributions made by the city on behalf of the member, less the sum of any amount paid out of the fund as benefits under the system to the member, together with appropriate adjustment for interest accumulation according to the interest rate and basis adopted from time to time. 
    Prior service means service rendered as an employee of the city prior to the effective date of the retirement system. 
    Prior service allowance means the retirement allowance to which a member is entitled as provided herein because of his prior service. 
    Retirement allowance means all retirement payments to which a member is entitled as herein provided. 
    Service retirement means retirement upon the normal service retirement date, early service retirement date, or delayed service retirement date, as provided in sections 15-39 and 15-40. 
    System means the North Miami Employees' Retirement System created by this article. 
(Code 1958, § 19-2) 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 15-17. - System created. 
    There is hereby created and established: 
(1)  A retirement system for employees to be known as the "North Miami Employees' Retirement System," by and in which name it shall, pursuant to the provisions of this article, transact all of its business and shall have the powers and privileges of a corporation, and 
(2)  A special fund to be known as the "North Miami Employees' Retirement Fund" which shall consist of all of the assets of the system. 
(Code 1958, § 19-1) 
Sec. 15-18. - Employees' pension system advisory committee-Created. 
    There is hereby created an employees' pension system advisory committee consisting of seven (7) members of the system. 
(Code 1958, § 19-3(a)) 
Cross reference- Board, committees and commissions, § 2-31 et seq. 
Sec. 15-19. - Same-Membership. 
(a)  The following divisions or departments shall have representation on the pension system advisory committee of one (1) member each: 
(1)  Public service department; 
(2)  Department of water and sewers; 
(3)  Police department; 
(4)  City manager's, city clerk's and tax office; 
(5)  Fire department; 
(6)  Recreation department and library; 
(7)  Engineering department; 
(8)  Personnel department; 
(9)  Civil defense department; and 
(10)  Building cleaning department. 
(b)  Each division or department shall select a member of the system within such division or department to serve on the pension system advisory committee. At the inception of this plan the seven (7) so selected shall be voted on by the members at large and the four (4) receiving the highest number of votes cast shall serve for a period of two (2) years. The remaining three (3) shall serve for a period of one (1) year. Subsequent terms of office for the pension system advisory committee shall be for two (2) years. 
(c)  All of the above members of the pension system advisory committee shall be selected after the system has been in effect for six (6) months, but not later than one (1) year after the system has been in effect. 
(d)  If a vacancy occurs on the pension system advisory committee, the vacancy shall be filled within thirty (30) days after the date of the vacancy for the unexpired term in the same manner as the vacated member was selected. 
(Code 1958, § 19-3(b)-(d)) 
Sec. 15-20. - Same-Meetings. 
    The pension system advisory committee shall hold regular meetings at least once in each yearly quarter. The pension system advisory committee shall select one (1) of its members as chairman. Another member of the pension system advisory committee shall be selected as secretary, who shall keep a record of all of its proceedings. All meetings of the pension system advisory committee shall be public and members shall serve without compensation for their services. 
(Code 1958, § 19-3(e)) 
Sec. 15-21. - Recommended changes. 
    No recommendations to make changes in this system shall be made to the city council unless the same shall have been unanimously approved by the pension system advisory committee. In the absence of a unanimous vote of the pension system advisory committee, recommendations to make changes to this system shall be only upon a majority vote of the pension system advisory committee and, in addition thereto, approval by a two-thirds ( 2/3 ) vote of the membership of the system. Any member of the system or the city council can make recommendations for changes in this article by submitting same in writing to the pension system advisory committee. No city council may change or abolish this article or any part thereof without the unanimous approval of the pension system advisory committee, and in addition thereto approval by two-thirds ( 2/3 ) vote of the members of the system. 
(Code 1958, § 19-3(f)) 
Sec. 15-22. - Treasurer; payments from fund. 
    The city treasurer shall be treasurer of the system and the custodian of its funds. All payments from the fund of the system, paid to an employee, shall be made only upon authorization of the personnel department. All vouchers and checks shall be signed by the treasurer and city manager or mayor. 
(Code 1958, § 19-3(g)) 
Sec. 15-23. - Medical committee. 
    There shall be appointed a medical committee to investigate all essential certificates of a medical nature by or on behalf of a member in connection with an application for benefits under this system. The medical committee shall consist of three (3) physicians, one (1) of whom shall be appointed by the city council, one (1) by the member claiming a disability allowance, and the third by the first two (2) so designated. The medical committee shall report in writing to the personnel department its conclusions and recommendations upon all matters referred to it. 
(Code 1958, § 19-3(h)) 
Sec. 15-24. - Actuary. 
    The city council shall appoint an actuary who shall be the technical advisor to the personnel department on matters regarding the operation of the system and who shall perform such other duties as are required in connection therewith. 
(Code 1958, § 19-3(i)) 
Sec. 15-25. - Actuarial tables. 
    The personnel department, with the approval of the city council, shall adopt such actuarial tables as are necessary for the administration of the system. At least once in each three-year period the personnel department shall cause an actuarial investigation to be made of all of the experience under the system together with an evaluation of the liabilities of the system. Pursuant to such investigations the personnel department with the approval of the city council shall from time to time revise the actuarial tables previously adopted. 
(Code 1958, § 19-3(j)) 
Sec. 15-26. - Management of funds. 
(a)  The city treasurer, with the approval of the city council shall have full power to invest and reinvest such funds, subject to all terms, conditions, limitations, and restrictions imposed by the State of Florida upon the investment of funds by fiduciaries, except that notes, bonds, or obligations of the city shall not be subject to any restrictions or limitations. The city treasurer with the approval of city council shall have the power to purchase notes, bonds or other obligations of the city before or after the same are offered to the public. The city treasurer with the approval of city council shall have full power to hold, purchase, sell, assign, transfer and dispose of any of these securities and investments in which any of the funds of the system have been invested as well as the proceeds of such investments and any moneys belonging to the fund. There shall be kept on deposit, in such depository as is designated by the city council, available cash not to exceed ten (10) percent of the total assets of the system. All funds of the system shall be held for the sole purpose of meeting disbursements according to the provisions of this article. 
(b)  The city treasurer, as custodian of the fund, shall be responsible on an official surety bond for all cash and securities in his custody. All registered securities in the fund created by this article shall be registered in the name of North Miami Employees' Retirement System, and every change in registration, by reason of sale or assignment of such securities, shall be accomplished by the signature of the city treasurer and city manager or mayor, and securities shall be delivered by the city treasurer. All payments from the fund, except those paid to an employee, shall be made by the city treasurer and city manager or mayor, with the approval of city council. 
(c)  The city council shall have the right by majority vote to designate at any time a duly licensed bank or trust company, for the purpose of safeguarding and investing the assets of the fund until they are needed for disbursement for such benefits or refunds as are provided herein. 
(Code 1958, § 19-4) 
Sec. 15-27. - Persons composing membership. 
(a)  Each employee of the city shall become eligible to be a member of the system as of the effective date. 
(b)  Each other employee shall automatically become a member of the system on the first day of the month coinciding with or next following the date on which he completes one (1) year of service in the employ of the city. However, an employee may voluntary request, within the first year of his employment, to become a member of the system, effective on the first day of the month coinciding with or next following his request. 
(c)  Upon becoming eligible to participate as a member under the system as of the effective date, each employee shall, within ninety (90) days, elect whether or not to participate as a member and to agree to make contributions required of him by this article. Each person on authorized leave from service as of the effective date, and who would otherwise at that time become eligible to be a member, shall, within ninety (90) days of his return to active service, elect whether or not to become a member and to agree to make contributions as provided by this article. 
(d)  Each employee eligible to become a member as of the effective date who does not elect, whether in service or on authorized leave from service, within the time set forth in the preceding paragraph, to become a member and agree to make contributions required of him by this article shall forfeit all right for credit for service prior to the date he might subsequently elect to become a member. Provided, however, the 90-day time limit from the effective date of this article, shall not apply to policemen or firemen, but shall be extended to ninety (90) days from such time as is determined by the city attorney, that benefits accruing to policemen and firemen under F.S. § 175.04(1), and F.S. § 185.7(1) can or cannot be retained to their specific credit under this article or under any law that the city council may adopt, notwithstanding anything contained in this article to the contrary. 
(Code 1958, § 19-5(a)-(d)) 
Sec. 15-28. - Cessation of membership and contributions. 
(a)  The membership of any person in the system shall cease upon the payment from the fund of his accumulated contributions or membership service reserve, as provided in section 15-45 or because of death or other termination of employment. 
(b)  The contributions required of a member under this article shall cease upon: 
(1)  Service retirement; 
(2)  Disability retirement; 
(3)  Death; 
(4)  Other termination of employment. 
(Code 1958, § 19-5(e)) 
Sec. 15-29. - Effect of suspension and reinstatement. 
    Should a person be discharged or suspended by reason of a violation as stipulated in the rules and regulations of the personnel board or the civil service board of the city, and should he subsequently be exonerated of such charges and be reinstated in city service, he may receive membership service credit for the period he was under suspension or discharge by making contributions for such period, and he shall again become a member of the system. 
(Code 1958, § 19-5(f)) 
Sec. 15-30. - Effect of reemployment. 
    Should a person be reemployed by the city after having his previous employment with the city terminated with or without cause, he shall for the purposes of this article be deemed to be a new employee as of his date of reemployment and his membership service shall commence on the November first or May first coinciding with or next following the first anniversary of his date of reemployment. In event of reemployment within three (3) years of the termination of his last period of employment, an employee may have his membership service credit restored for his membership under the system during his last period of employment provided he pay into the fund the accumulated contributions which he received upon such termination, together with the interest thereon accumulated from the date of such termination at the rate of three (3) percent per annum, upon which payment to the fund such person shall continue as a member under the system and shall make contributions to the system and be credited with additional membership service beginning with the date of such payment to the fund. 
(Code 1958, § 19-5(g)) 
Sec. 15-31. - Determining year's service. 
    The personnel department shall determine how much service in any year is the equivalent of a year of service, but in no case shall it allow credit for more than one (1) year of service for all service rendered in any period of twelve (12) consecutive months. 
(Code 1958, § 19-5(h)) 
Sec. 15-32. - Loss of rights upon cessation of membership. 
    Upon cessation of membership each employee shall thereafter lose all right to any benefit under this article except as hereinafter provided. 
(Code 1958, § 19-5(i)) 
Sec. 15-33. - Contributions by members and by city for membership service-Rate election by member. 
(a)  Each member shall, at his own option, elect to contribute for each pay period at the rate of either three (3) percent, five (5) percent, or seven (7) percent of his creditable compensation. Such contribution shall be considered to commence on the date the employee becomes a member, and shall continue at the same rate during his membership until the November first coinciding with or next following the date the member makes formal request in writing to the personnel department that such rate of contribution be changed. 
(b)  Each member shall have the right at any time to request a change in the rate of his contribution to either three (3) percent, five (5) percent or seven (7) percent of his creditable compensation, with such change in rate of contribution becoming effective the November first coinciding with or next following such request by the member. 
(Code 1958, § 19-6(a)) 
Sec. 15-34. - Same-Payable deductions. 
    The city treasurer shall cause to be deducted from the compensation of each member for each and every payroll period subsequent to the date of the establishment of this system, the contribution payable by such member as provided in this article and according to the rate of contribution duly elected by such member. Contributions deducted from the compensation of the members of the system shall be paid monthly directly into the fund by the city treasurer. 
(Code 1958, § 19-6(b)) 
Sec. 15-35. - Same-Payment by city. 
    At the end of each calendar year the city shall pay into the fund an amount which is equal to the total deductions made during that calendar year from the salaries or compensation of all members under the system. Such amount shall be reduced by the excess, if any, of the membership service reserves held in behalf of all members who terminate during that calendar year for reasons other than service retirement or disability retirement, over and above the amounts payable to such members upon such termination as provided in section 15-45 hereunder. Such amount payable by the city each calendar year shall be increased by the total of all accumulated contributions plus interest thereon which are paid into the fund during that calendar year by reemployed members according to section 15-30. 
(Code 1958, § 19-6(c)) 
Sec. 15-36. - Compensation less deductions deemed full payment. 
    The deductions provided for herein shall be made notwithstanding that the minimum compensation provided by law for any member shall be reduced thereby. Every member shall be deemed to consent and agree to the deductions made as provided herein, and payment of salary or compensation less such deductions shall be a full and complete discharge of all claims for services rendered by such persons during the period covered by such payment, except as to any benefits provided by this article. 
(Code 1958, § 19-6(d)) 
Sec. 15-37. - No deductions when payment by city in default. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of this section, no deductions shall be made from any member's compensation if the city's contribution required by this article is in default. 
(Code 1958, § 19-6(e)) 
Sec. 15-38. - City's contributions for prior service allowances. 
    The city shall pay into the fund at the end of each calendar year, in addition to the amount provided in section 15-35, such amounts as shall be determined from year to year by the actuary to amortize the liability of the city for prior service allowances provided hereunder to members. The period for such amortization shall be for a period of thirty (30) years. 
(Code 1958, § 19-6(f)) 
Sec. 15-39. - Retirement dates. 
(a)  The normal service retirement date for each member shall be the first day of the month following the 65th birthday of the member, provided such member has completed at least ten (10) years of service in the employ of the city. No member shall be permitted to remain in the employ of the city beyond his normal service retirement date except with the consent of the city council and except to complete ten (10) years of service in the employ of the city. 
(b)  The early service retirement date shall be the first day of the month following the receipt by the personnel department of an application signed by the member requesting early service retirement. Except as provided in subsection 15-41(c) no early service retirement allowance shall be paid to any member who has not attained at least age forty-five (45) and completed at least the years of service as required for his age by the following chart: 
Attained age Required years 
of service 45 25 46 24 47 23 48 22 49 21 50 20 51 19 52 18 53 17 54 16 55 15 56 141/2 57 14 58 131/2 59 13 60 121/2 61 12 62 111/2 63 11 64 101/2  
(Code 1958, § 19-7(b)) 
Sec. 15-40. - Delayed service and disability retirement date. 
(a)  The delayed service retirement date shall be the first day of the month following the actual retirement of a member who has been permitted by the consent of the city council to remain in the employ of the city beyond his normal service retirement date. 
(b)  The disability retirement date shall be the first day of the month following the date of receipt by the personnel department of a statement in writing from the medical committee which shall certify that member is, and has been continuously for at least thirty (30) days, mentally or physically incapacitated for the further performance of duty and that such incapacity is likely to be permanent and that such member should be retired. 
(Code 1958, § 19-7(c), (d)) 
Sec. 15-41. - Membership service allowances. 
(a)  Upon a member's retirement at either his normal service retirement date, early service retirement date, or delayed service retirement date, he shall receive such monthly membership service allowance, payable during his remaining lifetime, as shall be determined by the actuary as being the actuarial equivalent at the member's then attained age of the membership service reserve then credited to the account of the retiring member. 
(b)  Any member may on his early service retirement date elect to have the commencement of his membership service allowance deferred until age sixty-five (65) in which event he will receive a membership service allowance beginning at age sixty-five (65) and payable monthly for the remainder of his lifetime in such amount as shall be determined by the actuary as being the actuarial equivalent at age sixty-five (65) of his member-ship service reserve upon the attainment of age sixty-five (65). 
(c)  Any member may, on his disability retirement date, provided he has completed at least fifteen (15) years' service in the employ of the city, elect to have the commencement of his membership service allowance deferred until his normal service retirement date, or his early service retirement date, as provided in subsection 15-39(a) and subsection 15-39(b). However, any member who recovers from any such disability may reenter the active employ of the city within thirty (30) days of such recovery. He shall thereafter be a member of the system and he shall make his required contributions to the fund. Such reemployment shall revoke his previous election to have his membership service allowance deferred because of disability. 
(Code 1958, § 19-8) 
Sec. 15-42. - Prior service allowances. 
(a)  Each member in the service of the city on the effective date shall become entitled, upon his normal service retirement date, in addition to any other benefits hereunder, to a prior service allowance which shall become payable commencing on his normal service retirement date and which shall be continued monthly for the remainder of his lifetime. Such a prior service allowance shall be determined by multiplying (1) times (2) as follows: 
(1)  Two (2) percent of the monthly rate of compensation of the member as of the effective date, multiplied by 
(2)  The number of years prior service credited to the member. 
(b)  Any member who shall elect to retire on his early service retirement date and who does not defer the commencement of his membership service allowance until age sixty-five (65) shall have his prior service allowance commence at his early service retirement date but such allowance shall be reduced in amount as determined by the actuary so as to be the actuarial equivalent of the prior service allowance which he would have received had he retired on his normal service retirement date. 
(c)  Any member who defers his retirement beyond the normal service retirement date shall receive the same prior service allowance, commencing at his deferred service retirement date, that he would have received had he retired on his normal service retirement date. 
(d)  Should a member's employment with the city be terminated because of abolition of his position following transfer of services to Miami-Dade County government, whether such member has been accepted for employment with Metropolitan Dade County or not, provided he did not reject county employment with duties, responsibilities and level of compensation equivalent to those held with the City of North Miami on his own volition, the member shall be kept active on the books of the North Miami employee retirement system with respect to prior service allowance only, and may apply for and be paid at age sixty-five (65) the prior service allowance established for him, or at age fifty-five (55) at a reduced amount determined by the actuary so as to be the actuarial equivalent of the prior service allowance which he would have received had he applied at age sixty-five (65). Equivalency of duties, responsibilities, and level of compensation shall be determined by the personnel department and approved by a majority vote of the pension system advisory committee. Those members who are not accepted for county employment shall obtain a certificate from the Dade County personnel department indicating that the member had sought county employment but had been disqualified, stating the reason for disqualification. 
(e)  Any member who was in the service of the city on May 1, 1956, at the establishment of the retirement system for employees of the City of North Miami, who has completed ten (10) years of service and who terminates under the provisions of section 15-29, shall be entitled to receive a prior service allowance calculated according to the formula in section 15-39. This prior service allowance shall commence at age sixty-five (65) unless the member elects by written notice to the personnel department to draw an actuarially reduced allowance commencing no earlier than age fifty-five (55) and continued monthly for the remainder of his lifetime. 
(Code 1958, § 19-9) 
Sec. 15-43. - Optional modes of service allowance. 
(a)  Each member shall have the right at any time, and from time to time, at least three (3) months prior to his service retirement, to elect to have both his membership service allowance and prior service allowance payable under either of the options hereinafter set forth in lieu of the monthly allowances otherwise payable to him upon service retirement under any of the provisions herein. The amount of any optional service retirement allowances shall be the actuarial equivalent of the amount of such allowances otherwise payable to him hereunder. The member shall make such an election by written request to the personnel department and such an election will be subject to the approval of the pension system advisory committee. 
(1)  Option A. Joint and last survivor option. A member may elect to receive a decreased monthly allowance during his lifetime and have such decreased monthly allowance or a designated fraction thereof continued after his death to his beneficiary during the remaining lifetime of the beneficiary. This option may not be elected by a member if the social security option following has previously been elected. 
(2)  Option B. Social Security option. If a member retires prior to his normal service retirement date, he may elect to receive increased monthly allowances up to age sixty-five (65) and decreased monthly allowances thereafter in order to provide, to as great an extent as possible, a more nearly level monthly allowance when such decreased monthly allowances are added to his primary benefits under the federal social security act. The election of this option will automatically revoke any election under the joint and last survivor option above. 
(b)  The election by a member of any of the options above shall be null and void if the member dies prior to service retirement. Option A shall not be voided in event a member continues in employment subsequent to his normal service retirement date and dies prior to actual retirement. 
(c)  The election by a member of option A above shall be null and void if the designated beneficiary dies before the member's retirement. If a member remains in the active employ of the city beyond his normal service retirement date, his retirement, for the purpose of this paragraph, will be deemed to be at his deferred service retirement date. 
(d)  A member who has elected either of the options may, at any time within the period provided for such election, revoke any election by written notice to the personnel department. 
(Code 1958, § 19-10) 
Sec. 15-44. - Disability retirement allowance. 
(a)  Upon his disability retirement date a member may, at his option, receive a monthly disability allowance equal to the smaller of: 
(1)  One-half (1/2) of the member's monthly compensation during the month immediately preceding the date disability occurs; or 
(2)  One hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(b)  Such monthly disability allowance shall be deducted from the membership service reserve credited to the member's account and shall cease upon the first of the following to occur: 
(1)  The complete depletion of the membership service reserve credited to the member's account; 
(2)  The recovery from such disability; 
(3)  The death of the member. 
(c)  Upon termination of a member's monthly disability allowance because of recovery from such disability, and provided he reenters the active employ of the city within thirty (30) days after such recovery, he shall continue to be a member of the system and shall thereafter make his required contributions to the fund. In no way, however, is this provision to be construed that the membership service reserve credited to the member's account shall be restored to the total amount credited prior to the commencement of such monthly disability allowance payments. Such membership service reserve shall, instead, be accumulated following recovery in the normal way from the amount to which it had been reduced at the termination of such monthly disability allowances. 
(d)  Should a member's monthly disability allowance be terminated because of death of the member, any death benefits provided elsewhere hereunder shall be reduced by the total amount of all monthly disability allowance payments made during the member's period of disability. 
(e)  Upon the termination of a member's monthly disability allowance because of the complete depletion of the membership service reserve credited to the member's account, the member's membership under the system shall thereupon cease and terminate and no further benefits shall be provided under the system. 
(f)  Once each year following the disability retirement of a member who is receiving a monthly disability allowance, the personnel department may require such member to undergo a medical examination conducted by the medical committee. Should the member refuse to submit to any medical examination, his monthly disability allowance shall be discontinued until his withdrawal of such refusal, and should such refusal for one (1) year, all of his rights to any disability allowance payments shall cease and his membership under the system shall there upon terminate. 
(Code 1958, § 19-11) 
Sec. 15-45. - Benefits upon death or termination. 
(a)  Each member shall name a beneficiary to receive any benefits payable upon the member's death such designation to be made on a form provided by the personnel department. A member may change his designation of the beneficiary from time to time in the same manner. 
(b)  In the event a member who has elected option A under subsection 15-43(a) dies subsequent to his normal service retirement date but while still employed by the city, in lieu of any other benefit payable hereunder by reason of death, there shall be payable to his beneficiary the same monthly allowance that would otherwise have been payable under option A if the member had retired on his normal service retirement date. 
(c)  Should a member die prior to his service retirement but before completing five (5) years service in the employ of the city, there shall be paid in a lump sum to his beneficiary, not later than ninety (90) days following the death of the member, the amount of the accumulated contributions credited to the member's account at his death. Such accumulated contributions paid as a death benefit to the beneficiary shall be reduced by the total amount of all disability allowance payments, if any, paid to the member prior to his death. 
(d)  Should a member die prior to his service retirement but after completing five (5) years service in the employ of the city, there shall be paid in a lump sum to his beneficiary, not later than ninety (90) days following the death of the member, the amount of the membership service reserve credited to the member's account at his death. 
(e)  If the employment of a member is terminated before completing ten (10) years of service in the employ of the city other than by service retirement, disability retirement, or death, there shall be payable to such member in a lump sum not later than ninety (90) days following such termination the amount of his accumulated contributions as of the date of termination. Such accumulated contributions payable upon such termination of employment of a member shall be reduced by the total amount of all disability allowance payments paid to the member prior to such termination. Upon such termination of employment and the payment from the fund of the amount herein provided, the membership of such terminating employee shall cease and no further benefits shall be payable under the system. 
(f)  If the employment of a member is terminated after completing ten (10) years of service in the employ of the city, other than by service retirement, disability retirement, or death, there shall be payable to such member in a lump sum, not later than ninety (90) days following such termination, an amount in relation to his then completed years of service in accordance with the percentage of membership service reserve shown in the table below. Such benefits shall be reduced in event of any previous disability allowance payments to the member by an amount in accordance with the percentage of disability allowance payments to be deducted shown in the table set forth below for the appropriate number of completed years of service. 
Completed years

(g)  Upon such termination of employment and the payment from the fund of the amount herein provided, the membership of such terminating employee shall thereupon cease and no further benefits shall be payable under this system, except as provided in section 15-42. 
(h)  Should a member die at any time after service retirement but before receiving membership service allowance amounting to at least as much in total as his membership service reserve as of the date of such service retirement, the difference between such membership service reserve and such total membership service allowances shall be payable to the beneficiary under one (1) of the following options as the beneficiary may select: 
(1)  In a lump sum within ninety (90) days following the death of the member, or 
(2)  Payment in monthly amounts equal to the monthly amount received by deceased member until such difference is depleted. 
(i)  In the event a member terminates his employment with the city for any other reason than disability after twenty (20) years' service and before attaining age fifty-five (55) he may retain in the system the membership service reserve credited to his account at such time and elect to receive his membership service allowance at the normal service retirement date or early service retirement date. 
(j)  Actuarial deficits that may occur as a result of payments made from the fund under (h) above and section 15-41, shall be an obligation of the city. The city shall make up such deficits by budget appropriation in the fiscal year following such deficits. In order to establish a reserve for this deficit the city shall pay an additional one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) per year into the fund until such reserve amounts to twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00). 
(k)  Should a member's employment with the city be terminated because of abolition of his position following transfer of services to Metropolitan Dade County government, whether such member has been accepted for employment with Metropolitan Dade County or not, provided he did not reject county employment with duties, responsibilities and level of compensation equivalent to those held with the city on his own volition, the member shall be allowed to draw his membership service reserve reduced by the total amount of all disability allowance payments. Equivalency of duties, responsibilities, and level of compensation shall be determined by the personnel department and approved by a majority vote of the pension system advisory committee. Those members who are not accepted for county employment shall obtain a certificate from the Dade County personnel department indicating that the member had sought county employment, but had been disqualified, stating the reason for disqualification. 
(l)  If as a result of transfer of services to Metropolitan Dade County government a member is required to be demoted to a lower class of position following abolition of his position in a higher class and reallocation of his position from such higher class to the lower class, the member shall be allowed to draw his membership service reserve reduced by the total amount of all disability allowance payments if he presents evidence of having obtained employment with Metropolitan Dade County in the same occupational area in which he was employed with the city. This option must be exercised at the earliest date following the demotion that Metropolitan Dade County accepts applications and examines applicants for positions in this occupational area. 
(Code 1958, § 19-12) 
Sec. 15-46. - Changes or errors in records. 
    Should any change or error in records result in any member or beneficiary receiving from the system more or less than he would have been entitled to receive had the records been correct, then on discovery of any such error the personnel department shall correct the same and as far as practicable shall adjust the payments in such manner that the actuarial equivalent of the benefit to which the member or beneficiary was correctly entitled shall be paid. 
(Code 1958, § 19-13) 
Sec. 15-47. - Effect of repeal of article. 
(a)  If this article shall later be amended or repealed in its application to any person benefiting hereunder, the amount of benefits which at the time of such alteration, amendment, or repeal shall have accrued to the member or beneficiary shall not be affected except to the extent that the assets of the fund may be determined to be inadequate. 
(b)  If this article shall be repealed, the personnel department shall continue to administer the system in accordance with the provisions of this article for the sole benefit of the then members, any beneficiaries then receiving retirement allowances and any future persons entitled to receive benefits under one (1) of the options provided for in this article who are designated by any of the members. 
(c)  In the event of repeal of this article, the assets of the system shall be allocated by the city treasurer in an equitable manner to provide benefits on a proportionate basis to the persons so entitled to benefits in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(d)  The allocation of assets of the system in event of repeal of thin article shall be carried out through the payment by the city treasurer of the benefits provided hereunder as they become due or by the transfer of such assets to any retirement system replacing this system provided that full vesting of benefits under this system are provided and fully maintained under such new retirement system. Any funds remaining in the assets of this system after all the vested benefits provided hereunder have been paid shall revert to the general fund of the city. 
(e)  Any allocation of assets made in accordance with the provisions hereunder shall be final and binding on all persons entitled to benefits under the system. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14) 
Secs. 15-48-15-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CLAIR T. SINGERMAN EMPLOYEES RETIREMENT SYSTEM; ORD. NO. 691[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- See note at article III. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 15-61. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accumulated contributions means the sum of all amounts deducted from the compensation of a member and credited to his individual account subsequent to the effective date of this article, plus all amounts contributed by the city on behalf of members in satisfaction of the members' mandatory contributions to the system, together with allowable interest credited annually on such sum. 
    Actuarial equivalent means the benefit of equal value when computed upon the basis of such actuarial tables as are from time to time adopted. For the purposes of determining the actuarial equivalence of optional forms of benefits hereunder, the actuarial assumptions shall be the 1983 group annuity mortality table at interest rate of seven (7) percent for lump sum benefit calculations; eight (8) percent for all annuity benefit calculations. 
    Annual benefit means a member's retirement allowance exclusive of any benefit not required to be considered for the purposes of applying the limitations of section 415 of the code. 
    Average final compensation means the annual average of the highest two (2) of the last ten (10) years of credited service for members who have reached the normal retirement date on or before September 29, 2016. Effective September 30, 2016, average final compensation for members who did not reach the normal retirement date on or before September 29, 2016 means the annual average of the highest three (3) of the last ten (10) years of credited service. Effective September 30, 2017, average final compensation for members who did not reach the normal retirement date on or before September 29, 2016 means the annual average of the highest four (4) of the last ten (10) years of credited service. Effective September 30, 2018, average final compensation for members who did not reach the normal retirement date on or before September 29, 2016 means the annual average of the highest five (5) of the last ten (10) years of credited service. 
    Beneficiary means any person so designated by a member who may become entitled to benefits pursuant to this article. 
    Board means the board of trustees, which shall serve as trustee of the fund established in this article and which shall have administrative authority and supervision of the retirement system as set forth in this article. 
    City pickup date is November 1, 1987, the date upon which the city manager first authorized the employer to make contributions on behalf of each member in satisfaction of the members' requirement to make mandatory contribution to the system. 
    Code means the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as may be amended from time to time. 
    Compensation means total compensation payable to an employee working the full normal working period for his position and shall include contributions made by the city on behalf of a member in satisfaction of the members' mandatory contributions to the system. Effective January 1, 1989, in accordance with section 401(a)(17) of the Code, the compensation of an employee for purposes of this ordinance shall not exceed two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) per year adjusted for cost of living increases in accordance with section 415(d) of the Code. 
    Contribution means the amount deducted from the compensation of a member as provided in this article or contributed by the city on behalf of members in satisfaction of the members' mandatory contributions to the system. 
    Credited service means the total number of years during which a member has served as an employee of the city, provided that credited service shall only be allowed for those years or portions of years for which required member contributions have been made, or during which the city has made contributions to the system on behalf of members in satisfaction of the members' mandatory contributions to the system; however, all service prior to May 1, 1956, shall not be allowed for service incurred during any period of time for which an employee has previously rejected participation as a member. 
    Members shall have the option to purchase credit for up to five (5) years of active governmental service with any governmental agency, subject to the following requirements: 
(1)  Members must complete ten (10) years of creditable service in the system before becoming eligible to claim such prior governmental service credit. A member must make a written election of this option within four (4) years of eligibility on a form provided by the city with such election accompanied by the documentation set forth in subsection (2) below, and an agreement that the member will pay the amount calculated pursuant to subsection (3) below at the time and in the form and manner set forth therein. 
(2)  To receive retirement credit for such prior governmental service, a member must submit with such written election an original or certified copy of a certificate of service from any governmental agency showing the date of entry into active service, date of discharge under honorable conditions and a statement that no retirement benefit was obtained or will be obtained as a result of such service. 
(3)  To receive retirement credit for active prior governmental service, a member who is an active employee of the city, must pay the cost thereof, including interest, upon advice of the plan actuary and approved by the board of trustees. The member's required employee contribution hereunder shall be picked up by the city pursuant to I.R.S. Code Section 414(h)(2). In the case of a member who ceases to be an active city employee prior to the total payment of all amounts due and owing under this subsection (3), all amounts which remain payable under this subsection (3) at the time of the member's termination of employment shall immediately become due and payable in one (1) lump sum. 
(4)  All prior governmental service credited under this section shall be treated, for purposes hereof, as credited city service. The benefit percentage per year of service as applicable for this governmental service is three (3) percent of final average compensation. 
(5)  Prior governmental service shall become effective only after full payment as provided in subsection (3) above. 
    Department head means those employees of the city as who are responsible for overseeing city departments. 
    Disability retirement means retirement upon the disability retirement date. 
    Effective date means January 1, 1968. 
    Employee means any general employee, police bargaining unit member or police administrator employed by the city as a regular full-time employee in the normal employer-employee relationship, or firefighter who is a member of this pension plan. 
    Employer means the city and for firefighters, employer means Miami-Dade County. 
    Firefighter means any duly appointed and enrolled firefighter of the city who has transferred to Miami-Dade County and elected to remain in the city's pension system. 
    Fiscal agent means the person or entity designated to serve as the investment agent, adviser and custodian of the fund of the employees retirement system. 
    Fund means the fund established as part of the employees retirement system, which is intended to be a plan qualified under section 401(a) of the Code by meeting the requirements of section 414(d) of the Code. All funds, assets and contributions for the system shall be retained and accumulated in the fund. 
    General employee means any full-time employee of the city, including any classified or unclassified employee, as defined in section 15-9 of the City Code, other than sworn police personnel, who is employed by the city as a regular, full-time employee in the normal employee-employer relationship. 
    Mayor means that councilmember identified in the City Charter, Article III. 
    Member means any person employed as a general employee, sworn police personnel or firefighter by the city and who is included in the retirement system as provided in this article. 
    Police administrator means an employee classified as a police lieutenant, police captain, police major, deputy police chief or police chief, in accordance with the classification plan of the city. 
    Police bargaining unit member means a police officer or a police sergeant of the city who is a member of this plan. 
    Police officer means an employee classified as a police officer in accordance with the classification plan of the city. 
    Police sergeant means any employee classified as a police sergeant in accordance with the classification plan of the city. 
    Prior accumulated contributions means the sum of all amounts deducted from the compensation of a member and all credited contributions made by, for, or on behalf of an individual, and credited to his individual account prior to the city pickup date of this article, together with allowable interest credited annually on such amounts.
