    Prior contributions means the sum of all amounts deducted from the compensation of a member and credited to his individual account prior to the city pick-up date of this ordinance. 
    Prior vested benefit means the total dollar amount of a member's vested interest in his membership service reserve, as determined under the provisions of the city retirement system as such system existed immediately prior to the effective date of this article. 
    Regular interest means such rate of interest as shall be determined and allowed from time to time by the board. 
    Retiree means any former member who has retired under the provisions of this article and is receiving or has received benefits from the fund. 
    Retirement allowance means all retirement payments to which a member is entitled as provided in this article or contributed by the city on behalf of members in satisfaction of the members' mandatory contributions to the system. 
    Section 415 compensation means all compensation paid by the city that is taken into account under section 415 of the code, but shall not include contributions made by the city in satisfaction of the members' mandatory contributions to the system. 
    Service retirement means retirement upon the normal, early or delayed service retirement date. 
    Sworn police personnel means all police employees duly certified by the State of Florida as law enforcement officer and employed by the city in such capacity. 
    System means the city employees retirement system. 
    Vested benefit means the total nonforfeitable percentage of the benefits accruing to an individual under this pension plan. This percentage is based on years of credited service and is set forth below: 
(1)  Members not in the police bargaining unit: 
Years of Credited Service Vesting 
Percentage  
Less than 5 .....   0 
More than 5 but less than 6 .....  25 
More than 6 but less than 7 .....  40 
More than 7 but less than 8 .....  55 
More than 8 but less than 9 .....  70 
More than 9 but less than 10 .....  85 
More than 10 years of services ..... 100 
(2)  Members in the police bargaining unit: 
Years of Credited Service Vesting 
Percentage  
14 or more years of service ..... 100 
    Notwithstanding the foregoing, a member's right to his normal retirement benefit shall be fully vested upon his normal retirement date. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.11; Ord. No. 691.19, § 1(A), 3-28-90; Ord. No. 853, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 914, § 1, 3-22-94; Ord. No. 934, § 1, 6-13-95; Ord. No. 1306, § 2, 10-26-10; Ord. No. 1355, § 2, 5-28-13; Ord. No. 1361, § 2, 11-12-13; Ord. No. 1397, § 2, 3-8-16) 
Sec. 15-62. - Employees retirement system (Ord. No. 582) continued. 
(a)  It is deemed to be to the best interests of the city and the citizens, residents, inhabitants and taxpayers thereof that the city maintain a retirement system for its employees, sworn police personnel and firefighters and to that end the city employees retirement system initially established by prior ordinance (Ord. No. 582) is herewith continued as amended in its entirety by this article. 
(b)  All amendments to the system made on October 22, 1991, are adopted contingent upon and will be effective as set forth herein upon the receipt of a favorable advance determination letter from the Internal Revenue Service that the system, as amended by this article for the Tax Reform Act of 1986 and subsequent legislation, rulings and regulations, satisfies the requirements of sections 401(a) and 414(h)(2) of the code, and that the fund is tax exempt pursuant to section 501(a) of the code. If for any reason a favorable determination letter from the Internal Revenue Service cannot be issued, all amendments to the system made on October 22, 1991 shall be of no force or effect. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.10; Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 914, § 1, 3-22-94) 
Sec. 15-63. - Miscellaneous provisions. 
(a)  Correction of errors. Should any change or error in records result in any member or beneficiary receiving from the system more or less than he would have been entitled to receive had the records been correct, then on discovery of any such error the board shall cause the same to be corrected and as far as practicable shall direct that the payments be adjusted in such manner that the actuarial equivalent of the benefit to which the member or beneficiary was correctly entitled shall be paid. 
(b)  Illegality of part no effect on whole. If any section or part of any section of this article is declared illegal, the remainder of this article shall not thereby be invalidated. All provisions of any ordinances of the city, inconsistent with the provisions of this article are hereby repealed to the extent of such inconsistencies. 
(c)  Amendment and termination. 
(l)  This article establishing the system and fund and amending prior ordinances pertaining to retirement benefits for city employees, and subsequent ordinances pertaining to the system and fund, may be modified, terminated or amended, in whole or in part; provided that if this or any subsequent ordinance shall be amended or repealed in its application to any person benefiting pursuant to this article, the amount of benefits which at the time of any such alteration, amendment, or repeal shall have accrued to the member or beneficiary shall not be reduced thereby, except to the extent that the assets of the fund may be determined to be inadequate. 
(2)  Provided further, no recommendations to make changes in this system shall be made to the city council unless the same have been unanimously approved by the board of trustees or, in the absence of a unanimous vote of the board of trustees, recommendations to make changes to this system shall be upon a majority vote of the board of trustees and, in addition thereto, approval by a two-thirds ( 2/3 ) vote of the membership of the system. 
(3)  Provided further, if this article shall be repealed, the board shall continue to administer the system in accordance with the provisions of this article, for the sole benefit of the then members, any beneficiaries then receiving retirement allowances, and any future person entitled to receive benefits under one (1) of the options provided for in this article who are designated by any of the members. In the event of repeal, there shall be full vesting (one hundred (100) percent) of benefits accrued to the date of repeal and the assets of the system and shall be allocated in an equitable manner to provide benefits on a proportionate basis to the persons so entitled to benefits in accordance with the provisions of this article, with prior preference being directed towards the return of prior vested benefits and accumulated contributions. The allocation of assets of the system in event of repeal of this article shall be carried out through the payment of the benefits provided by this article as they become due, or by the transfer of such assets to any retirement system replacing this system, provided that the full vesting of benefits under the system are provided and fully maintained under such new retirement system. Any funds remaining in the assets of this system after all the vested benefits provided by this article have been paid shall revert to the general fund of the city. Any allocation of assets made in accordance with the provisions of this article shall be final and binding on all persons entitled to benefits under the system. 
(4)  Limitation of benefits on early termination. If the system is terminated for any reason other than the failure to obtain Internal Revenue Service approval then notwithstanding any provision in this article to the contrary, during the first ten (10) years after the effective date of this article, and if full current costs had not been made at the end of the first ten (10) years, until such full current costs are met, the benefits provided by the city's contributions for the members whose anticipated annual benefit at normal retirement date exceeds one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) and who at the effective date of the system were among the twenty-five (25) highest paid employees of the city will be subject to the conditions set forth in the following provisions: 
a.  The benefit payable to a member described in this section or his beneficiary shall not exceed the greater of those benefits purchasable by the greater of twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) or an amount equal to twenty (20) percent of the first fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) of the member's annual compensation multiplied by the number of years from the effective date of this agreement to the earlier of: 
1.  The date of termination of the system; or 
2.  The date the benefit of the member becomes payable; or 
3.  The date of a failure on the part of the city to meet the full current costs of the system; 
or the present value of the maximum benefit provided in section 4022(b)(3B) of the act. 
b.  If the system is terminated or the full current costs thereof have not been met at any time within ten (10) years after the effective date, the benefits which any of the members described in this section may receive from the city's contribution shall not exceed the benefits set forth in subsection (c)(4)a of this section. If at the end of the first ten (10) years the full current costs are not met, the restrictions will continue to apply until the full current costs are funded for the first time. If a member described in this section leaves the employ of the city or withdraws from membership in the system when the full current costs have been met, the benefits which may be received from the city contributions shall not at any time within the first ten (10) years after the effective date exceed the benefits set forth above except as provided in the case of a lump sum distribution described below. These conditions shall not restrict the full payment of any survivor's benefits on behalf of a member who dies while in the system and the conditions shall not restrict the current payment of full retirement allowance called for by the system for any retired member while the system is in full effect and its full current costs have been met, provided an agreement, adequately secured, guarantees the repayment of any part of the distribution that is or may become restricted. 
c.  If the benefits of, or with respect to, any member shall have been suspended or limited in accordance with the limitations of the above sections because the full current costs of the system shall not then have been met, and if such full current costs shall thereafter be met, then the full amount of the benefits payable to such member shall be resumed and the parts of such benefits which have been suspended shall then be paid in full. 
d.  If on the termination of the system within the first ten (10) years after the effective date, the funds under the system are more than sufficient to provide the full retirement allowance for members and their beneficiaries including full benefits for all members other than such of the twenty-five (25) highest paid employees as are still in the service of the city and also including retirement allowance as limited by this section for such twenty-five (25) highest paid employees, then any excess of such funds shall be used to provide retirement allowance for the twenty-five (25) highest paid employees in excess of such limitations of this section up to the benefits to which such employees would be entitled without such limitations. 
e.  If congress should provide by statute, or the treasury department or the Internal Revenue Service should provide by regulation or ruling, that the limitations provided for in this section are no longer necessary in order to meet the requirements for a governmental plan under the code as then in effect, the limitations in this section shall become void and shall no longer apply without the necessity of amendment to the system. 
f.  If a lump sum distribution is made to an employee subject to the above restrictions in an amount in excess of that amount otherwise permitted under this section, an agreement shall be made, with adequate security guaranteeing repayment of any amount of the distribution that is restricted. Adequate security shall mean property having a fair market value of at least one hundred twenty-five (125) percent of the amount which would be repayable if the system had terminated on the date of distribution of such lump sum. If the fair market value of the property falls below one hundred ten (110) percent of the amount which would then be repayable if the system were then to terminate, the distribution shall deposit additional property to bring the value of the property to one hundred twenty-five (125) percent of such amount. 
(d)  Takeover of city function by outside instrumentality. If any city function, agency or department or activity thereof is taken over in whole or in part by another city, county, governmental entity or instrumentality thereof, and such takeover or acquisition presents or poses any problem, threat or action adversely affecting the accrued benefits of a member under this system, such takeover or acquisition shall be deemed to be a termination as respects any member so affected and the provisions of subsection (c) of this section shall apply unless a member voluntarily relinquishes and waives such rights and consents in writing to an alternative course of action. 
(e)  Attachment or garnishment of benefits. No benefit whatsoever as provided in this article shall be subject to attachment, garnishment, execution or to any other legal process; provided, however, that subsequent to termination of employment, and prior to refund, a member may voluntarily assign such funds or a portion thereof to the city or any of its recognized agencies for the satisfaction of lawfully contracted obligations. 
(f)  No liability for sufficiency of fund. The trustee shall sustain no liability whatsoever for the sufficiency of the fund to meet the payments and benefits provided for in this article and shall be under no duty or obligation to inquire into the sufficiency of the payments made into the fund by the city. 
(g)  Resignation of trustee. A trustee may resign that trust at any time by giving sixty (60) days' written notice to the city. A trustee may be removed only for cause stated or for failure to attend meetings as stated in this article and by affirmative action of six (6) trustees. In the event of vacancy occurring at any time, a qualified successor trustee shall be chosen in the same manner as the prior trustee. 
(h)  Right to remain under prior system. All employees of the city as of the effective date of this system shall have the right for a period of ninety (90) days following the effective date to elect to remain under the city's retirement system as it existed immediately prior to the effective date of this article. Such election shall be irrevocable and employees who elect to remain under the prior system shall be governed exclusively by the provisions thereof and shall have no rights whatsoever as regards this system. Uniform procedures to be followed concerning election of coverage as between the respective systems shall be established by the city. 
(i)  Transfers into system. With the approval of the city manager, new employees of the city who have acquired assets to their credit under a pension plan or system in previous employment, and such assets are transferable to the city's system, shall have the right to have such assets transferred to the system and receive such benefits therefrom as may be financed by the assets so transferred, plus such additional benefits as may accrue by reason of being a regular member of this system. 
(j)  Editorial usage. Wherever the masculine is used in this article, it shall also refer to the feminine. The paragraph and section headings used in this article are for convenience only and shall not be interpreted apart from the accompanying text. 
(k)  Exclusive benefit. No pension provided hereunder shall be assignable and no part of the corpus or income of the fund shall be used for, or diverted to, purposes other than for the exclusive benefit of members and their beneficiaries and until those liabilities are satisfied, all city contributions will remain in the fund for the benefit of the members or beneficiaries in the event the plan is terminated or city contributions cease. 
(l)  Vesting. Upon the termination of the plan or on the complete discontinuance of contributions under the plan, each member shall have non-forfeitable, one hundred (100) percent vested rights to benefits accrued to date of the termination or discontinuance to the extent funded at that time. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.2; Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 929, § 2, 1-10-95; Ord. No. 1306, § 3, 10-26-10) 
Sec. 15-64. - Plan closed to new members; participation in the Florida Retirement System. 
(a)  Effective February 1, 2016 or as soon thereafter as administratively practical, the city will join the Florida Retirement System ("FRS") for general employees. The city's retirement system shall be closed to new members on the day before the city joins FRS. 
(b)  All employees hired by the city on or after the date the city joins FRS who would otherwise have been members of the city's retirement system will participate in FRS, in accordance with Chapter 121, Florida Statutes, and rules promulgated thereunder, as such statutes and rules may be amended in the future. 
(c)  All members who are employed by the city on the date the city joins FRS will have the option to remain in the retirement system or participate in FRS. For those members who have not reached the normal retirement date as of November 10, 2015 and elect to remain in the system, average final compensation, benefit levels and employee contributions shall be as provided in sections 15-61, 15-81, 15-90 and 15-95.1, as amended by this section. However, in no event shall a member's annual retirement benefit be less than the member's accrued benefit earned as of November 10, 2015, determined in accordance with the provisions of the plan in effect as of November 9, 2015. Upon retirement from the system, members who elect to continue participating in the system may elect to receive their accrued benefit as of November 10, 2015, or their benefit calculated on the date of retirement in accordance with the plan provisions in effect on that date. For those members who have reached the normal retirement date as of November 10, 2015 and elect to remain in the system, benefits and contributions shall be based on the provisions of the system in effect on November 9, 2015. 
(d)  Members hired prior to the date the city joins FRS who elect to join FRS will have the option of retaining their accrued benefit in the system, or receiving a refund of their accumulated contributions. Such member's accrued benefit shall be calculated based on the member's average final compensation and the system provisions in effect on the date the city joins FRS, and credited service through the day before the date the member joins FRS. Members who elect to receive a refund of their accumulated contributions may purchase prior service in the FRS at the member's expense, in accordance with applicable Florida statutes and rules. 
(e)  Regardless of whether a member elects to join FRS or continues participating in the system, in order to receive any benefit from this system (other than disability or death benefits) a member must reach the early or normal retirement date and terminate employment with the city. 
(Ord. No. 1397, § 3, 3-8-16) 
DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF TRUSTEES 

Sec. 15-65. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created a board of trustees of the retirement system for the city which shall serve as the trustee of the fund. In addition, the general administration, management and responsibility for the proper operation of the retirement system shall be vested in the board of trustees. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.19(1); Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91) 
Sec. 15-66. - Composition. 
    The board shall consist of seven (7) member trustees and two (2) non-voting ex-officio members as follows: 
(1)  The designee of the city manager; 
(2)  One (1) sworn police personnel member shall be elected as trustee, and one (1) sworn police personnel member shall be elected as an alternate by the sworn police personnel members; 
(3)  One (1) firefighter shall be elected as trustee, and one (1) firefighter shall be elected as an alternate by members of the fire department having any current vested rights; 
(4)  Four (4) general employees, other than department heads, shall be elected as trustees by the general employees of the city who are members of the plan to fill the following seats: 
a.  Public works general employee seat. One (1) public works general employee shall be elected as trustee, and one (1) public works general employee shall be elected as an alternate; 
b.  Non-public works general employee seat. One (1) non-public works general employee shall be elected as trustee, and one (1) non-public works general employee shall be elected as an alternate; 
c.  At-large general employee seats. Two (2) general employees shall be elected as trustees and an alternate for each shall be elected. 
(5)  The personnel manager or a designated alternate will serve as an ex-officio member; 
(6)  The finance director or a designated alternate will serve as an ex-officio member. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.19(1); Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 914, § 1, 3-22-94; Ord. No. 960, § 1, 3-11-97; Ord. No. 1070, § 1, 11-28-00; Ord. No. 1164, § 1, 9-28-04; Ord. No. 1243, § 2, 10-23-07; Ord. No. 1361, § 2, 11-12-13) 
Sec. 15-67. - Alternate representatives. 
    An alternate representative shall act as trustee with full voting rights in the absence of a trustee who is unable to attend pension board meetings. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.19(1); Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 960, § 1, 3-11-97; Ord. No. 1070, § 2, 11-28-00) 
Sec. 15-68. - Terms; oath of office; filling of vacancies. 
    Beginning with the regular election for terms to commence January 1, 2001, the term of office for each of the member trustees shall be changed to staggered terms. The sworn police personnel member trustee shall be elected for a two-year term, the firefighter shall be elected for a two-year term, the public works general member shall be elected for a three-year term, the non-public works general member shall be elected for a two-year term, and the at-large general member shall be elected for a one-year term. Thereafter all the general employee trustees and their respective alternates will be elected for three-year terms. 
    At the regular election for terms to commence January 1, 2006, trustees for the non-public works general employee seat, the sworn police personnel seat, and the firefighter seat shall be elected. At the regular election for terms to commence January 1, 2007, the trustee for the public works general employee seat shall be elected. At the regular election for terms to commence January 1, 2008, two (2) trustees shall be elected for the at-large general employee seats. 
    The candidate receiving the highest votes for sworn police personnel seat, the firefighter seat, the non-public works general employee seat and the public works general employee seat will fill each respective trustee seats. The candidate receiving the next highest number of votes will serve as the respective alternates for each of the seats. 
    The two (2) candidates receiving the highest number of votes for the at-large general employee seats shall fill those seats. The two (2) candidates receiving the third and fourth highest number of votes shall serve as alternates with the candidate receiving the third highest number of votes filling the first vacancy to occur in either of the at-large general employee seats. The candidate receiving the fourth highest number of votes shall fill the second vacancy to occur in either of the at-large general employee seats. 
    The personnel manager and finance director or their respective alternates shall serve continuously as ex-officio members. The designee of the city manager shall serve at the pleasure of the city manager. 
    Each trustee shall take an oath of office to be administered by the city clerk or a notary public. 
    Should a vacancy occur in the office of trustee, the respective alternate shall serve out the remaining term of office held by the vacating trustee. If an alternate fills a vacancy as trustee, and then subsequently vacates the office, an election will held to elect a trustee, and a respective alternate for the vacant trustee seat and shall both serve out the remaining term for that seat. 
    Provided there are enough trustees to establish a quorum, if no one is elected to a particular seat, the seat will remain vacant, until a trustee is elected in a subsequent election. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.19(1); Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 914, § 1, 3-22-94; Ord. No. 960, § 1, 3-11-97; Ord. No. 1070, § 3, 11-28-00; Ord. No. 1164, § 2, 9-28-04; Ord. No. 1243, § 3, 10-23-07; Ord. No. 1361, § 2, 11-12-13) 
Sec. 15-69. - Removal of members. 
    Any member of the board other than the designee of the city manager, personnel manager and finance director or their respective alternates may be removed upon the affirmative votes of six (6) members for cause shown to the board and including absence from three (3) consecutive board meetings or absence from four (4) meetings in any 12-month period, without appropriate reason therefor shown to the board. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.19(1); Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 914, § 1, 3-22-94; Ord. No. 960, § 1, 3-11-97; Ord. No. 1361, § 2, 11-12-13) 
Sec. 15-70. - Meetings; procedure; compensation; quorum. 
    The board shall hold meetings at least once every two (2) months and shall designate the time and place. The board shall adopt its own rules of procedure and maintain a record of its proceedings. All meetings of the board shall be public. Trustees shall serve without compensation for their services as trustees. Four (4) trustees shall constitute a quorum at any meeting of the board and each trustee shall be entitled to one (1) vote at meetings of the board. Four (4) concurring votes shall be necessary for a decision by the board. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.19(2); Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 1164, § 3, 9-28-04) 
Sec. 15-71. - Officers; legal advisor; actuary; medical director. 
    The board shall elect from its members a chairman, vice chairman and secretary. The financial director shall be treasurer of the retirement system and the custodian of its funds pending transfer of such funds to the regular fiscal agent for the plan. The city attorney, with the approval of the board shall be the legal advisor of the board. The board may appoint an actuary who shall be the technical advisor to the board on matters regarding the operation of the retirement system. The board may employ such additional professional and clerical services as may be required for proper operation of the retirement system. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.19(3); Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 1070, § 4, 11-28-00) 
Sec. 15-72. - Records. 
(a)  The secretary of the board shall cause to be kept the records of the proceedings of the board. Nominal compensation for the secretary may be authorized by the board. 
(b)  The finance director shall cause to be kept such data as shall be necessary for periodic actuarial valuation of the assets and liabilities of the retirement system. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.19(5); Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91) 
Sec. 15-73. - Medical committee. 
    A medical committee shall be appointed to investigate all matters of a medical nature by or on behalf of a member in connection with an application for benefits under this system. The medical committee shall consist of three (3) physicians, appointed by the board. The medical committee shall report in writing by certifying to the board its conclusions and recommendations on all matters referred to it. The final decision concerning entitlement to disability benefits shall be based upon and determined by the medical certification. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.19(4); Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 1070, § 5, 11-28-00) 
Sec. 15-74. - Functions and duties. 
(a)  The duties and functions of the board of trustees, in addition to investment functions, shall be as follows: 
(1)  Observing and overseeing the operation of the system and fund; 
(2)  Making recommendations for improvements and amendments of the system; however, no suggested amendments to the benefits of this system shall be recommended to the city council by the board until the opinion of the system's actuary shall have first been obtained, which opinion shall reflect the cost impact of the suggested amendments; 
(3)  Approving and authorizing all benefit payments; 
(4)  Determining by uniform rules all questions concerning credited service and membership; 
(5)  Performing or having maintained accurate records of credited service and accumulated contributions of members and such other data as may be necessary; 
(6)  Performing regular, periodic actuarial valuations and studies of the retirement system and fund, the periodic valuations of the system to be performed not less often than once every two (2) years; 
(7)  Preparing and rendering annually to the city council a complete accounting of the financial and other transactions of the retirement system and fund; 
(8)  Determining each year the amount of interest to be credited annually to prior vested benefit accounts and accumulated contributions of members; 
(9)  Establishing uniform rules and regulations for operation of the system. 
(b)  In carrying out its duties the board shall have full and total discretionary authority to interpret the ordinance and to make all decisions concerning the crediting of service and eligibility for benefits. 
(c)  The board of trustees shall assume, take over and be responsible for the discharge of all duties of the pension system advisory committee as enumerated in Ordinance Nos. 582, 583, and 587 of the city. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.19(6), (7); Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 914, § 1, 3-22-94) 
Sec. 15-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FUND 

Sec. 15-76. - Establishment and operation. 
(a)  There is hereby established a special fund, to be known as the fund, into which shall be deposited all of the contributions and assets whatsoever of the system, including all contributions and assets for retirement purposes on hand as of the effective date of this article. This fund may be joined for investment purposes with the pension fund required under section 15-115 provided that at all times appropriate bookkeeping records as set forth in subsection 15-77(d) are maintained. 
(b)  Subject to the overall supervision of the board of trustees, and other provisions of this article, the actual collection, custody and payment of the funds, and the fund established by this article, shall be vested in the finance director; provided, however, payment of benefits and disbursements from the fund shall be made only on authorization from the board of trustees, and all payments and disbursements shall be in accordance with the duly authorized procedures of the city as established by city ordinance or resolution. 
(c)  The board of trustees, shall hire and appoint such persons, agents or entities, including corporate fiduciaries, as in its discretion may be required or advisable to enable it to perform its duties pursuant to this article; provided, however, the board, shall enter into agency, investment advisory and custodial agreements for the purpose of securing investment and custodialship services for the system and fund. All funds and securities appertaining to the system shall be deposited with the city finance director who shall in turn deposit such funds and securities in the fund. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.20(A); Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 901, § 1, 7-13-93; Ord. No. 1060, § 1, 9-26-00; Ord. No. 1243, § 4, 10-23-07) 
Sec. 15-77. - City contributions. 
(a)  The city shall pay into the fund an amount which is equal to the difference between aggregate member contributions for the year and required normal cost for the year, as determined by the most recent actuarial valuation of the liabilities of the system. The city must deposit its contributions on a quarterly basis, but may make monthly contributions at its discretion. 
(b)  The city shall also pay into the fund, in addition to the amounts provided for in subsection (a) of this section, such amounts as shall be determined on an actuarial basis as necessary to amortize the accrued liability of the system over a period of not to exceed forty (40) years. The city must deposit its contributions on a quarterly basis, but may make monthly contributions at its discretion. 
Editor's note- It should be noted that the provisions of subsections (a) and (b) shall be effective December 31, 1999. 
(c)  Based solely upon recommendations of the actuary for the system, contributions required from either or both the city and members may be reduced by the board and city council. Any such reduction shall be spread as equitably as possible between the city and the members. It is recognized that investment gains in the fund can serve to reduce required contributions necessary to systematically fund the liabilities of the system. 
(d)  All funds and securities of the system may be commingled in the fund established for purposes of the system, provided that accurate records are maintained at all times reflecting the financial composition of the fund, including accurate current accounts and entries as regards the following: 
(1)  Current amounts of accumulated contributions and prior accumulated contributions of members on both an individual and aggregate account basis; and 
(2)  Prior vested benefits on both an individual and aggregate account basis; and 
(3)  Receipts and disbursements; and 
(4)  Payments to retirees; and 
(5)  Current amounts clearly reflecting all moneys, funds and assets whatsoever attributable to contributions and deposits from the state to or on behalf of sworn police personnel officers and firefighters. Further, all records pertaining to such moneys, funds and assets shall be maintained on a basis clearly reflecting the moneys and assets attributable to each such group, sworn police personnel and firefighters, and interest, dividends and gains credited thereto; 
(6)  All contributions by the city; and 
(7)  All interest, dividends and gains or losses whatsoever; and 
(8)  Such other entries as may be properly required so as to reflect a clear and complete financial report of the fund. 
(e)  Beginning on the city pickup date, the city shall be required to contribute to the system an amount equal to the mandatory employee contributions described in section 15-81, which contribution shall be in lieu of the contributions otherwise required of employees under that section. In no event may an employee elect to directly receive the amount contributed on his behalf by the city in lieu of such contribution. The contributions made by the city pursuant to this subsection are intended to comply with section 414(h)(2) of the code. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.20(B); Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 914, § 1, 3-22-94; Ord. No. 1060, § 2, 9-26-00) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1060, § 2, adopted Sept. 26, 2000, set out provisions amending § 15-77. The provisions of said ordinance were treated as amending subsections (a) and (b) of said section. See the Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 15-78. - Investments. 
    The board of trustees shall have the following investment powers and authority: 
(1)  The fund may be vested and reinvested in such securities or property, real or personal, wherever situated and of whatsoever kind, as shall be approved by the board of trustees, including but not limited to stocks, common or preferred, bonds, obligations of the city, and other evidences of indebtedness or ownership. As to such other evidences of indebtedness, there shall be no investments in unsecured obligations representing indebtedness of fixed amounts except as regards obligations issued by the United States, the State of Florida or political subdivisions or agencies thereof; provided, however, it is specifically provided that the fund may be invested in money market investments. The board of trustees, acting upon the advice of the trust advisors, shall be responsible for the establishment of limitations of the percent of total assets of the fund, figured on a cost basis, to be invested in common stocks. In no event may more than sixty (60) percent of the total assets of the fund be invested in common stocks. 
(2)  The board of trustees may retain in cash and keep unproductive of income such amount of the funds as it may deem advisable for purposes of fulfilling the cash requirements of the system. 
(3)  No person or entity shall be liable for the making, retention or sale of any diminishment of the fund, except that due to his or its own negligence, willful misconduct or lack of good faith. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.20(C); Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 914, § 1, 3-22-94) 
Sec. 15-79. - Gifts, bequests, devises, donations. 
    All gifts, bequests, devises and donations to the city retirement fund and all other accretions and additional sources of income shall be deposited in the fund to be administered under the terms of this article. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.20(D); Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91) 
DIVISION 4. - ELIGIBILITY AND MEMBER CONTRIBUTIONS 

Sec. 15-80. - Eligibility generally. 
(a)  All general employees hired before the date the city joins the Florida Retirement System (FRS) shall be eligible for membership and shall become members of the system immediately upon being employed on a full-time permanent basis pursuant to the city's administrative rules and regulations. All general employees who are members and employed by the city on the date the city joins FRS will have the option to remain in the system or participate in the FRS. The city attorney shall not be a member of any city retirement system, but shall participate in FRS if such participation is required by applicable law. For a city manager appointed before the date the city joins FRS, membership of the city manager in the city retirement system shall be optional upon the appointment to the position by the mayor and city council, provided he or she has been a city employee and plan member for at least ten (10) years. Upon such appointment, the city manager may elect to stay in the plan, if already a member. A city manager who is appointed after the date the city joins FRS shall become a member of the FRS, unless he or she elects not to participate in FRS in accordance with applicable law. Effective upon the date the city joins FRS, all general employees, sworn police personnel and firefighters who were members of this plan on or before April 3, 1994, may remain members of this plan or instead may elect to join the regular or senior management class of FRS, as applicable. 
    Any general employee who accepts an appointment as a police officer after April 3, 1994, shall be transferred to the Pension Ordinance 748 Pension Plan, said transfer to be effective on the date of the appointment as a sworn police officer. All members previously retired and currently drawing monthly retirement benefits and who have not taken such benefits in a lump sum, shall be eligible for the increased benefits provided pursuant to this article, retroactively only to the effective date of this article, provided they have had at least fourteen (14) years of service with the city.* The following shall not be eligible: 
(1)  Medical directors; 
(2)  Contractual employees; 
(3)  Appointed board members; 
(4)  Sworn police personnel and police administrators who are members of Pension Ordinance 748 Pension Plan. 
(b)  The deputy or assistant city managers, and the deputy or assistant city attorneys employed on or after the date the city joins the FRS shall become a member of FRS. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.12(1); Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 914, § 1, 3-22-94; Ord. No. 929, § 4, 1-10-95; Ord. No. 934, § 1, 6-13-95; Ord. No. 941, § 1, 3-26-96; Ord. No. 962, § 1, 4-8-97; Ord. No. 962, § 1, 4-8-97; Ord. No. 1306, § 4, 10-26-10; Ord. No. 1375, §§ 1, 5, 7-8-14; Ord. No. 1397, § 4, 3-8-16) 
Editor's note- Section 5 of Ord. No. 1375 provides that the ordinance shall become effective immediately upon adoption on second reading, and shall be made retroactive to May 24, 2014. 
* Interpretive note- Section 15-80 provided that retirees and members of Pension Ordinance 582 be eligible for retroactive benefits as of the effective date of this article, (January 1, 1968) from May 1, 1956 to January 1, 1968 only. 
Sec. 15-81. - Member contributions. 
(a)  Mandatory contribution rate. 
(1)  Members who have reached their normal retirement date on or before November 10, 2015 shall contribute to the fund at a rate of seven (7) percent of their annual compensation. 
(2)  Members with fifteen (15) or more complete years of credited service who have not reached their normal retirement date on or before November 10, 2015 shall contribute to the fund at a rate of eight (8) percent of their annual compensation. 
(3)  Members with ten (10) or more complete years and less than fifteen (15) complete years of credited service who have not reached their normal retirement date on or before November 10, 2015 shall contribute to the fund at a rate of seven (7) percent of their annual compensation. 
(4)  Members with less than ten (10) complete years of credited service who have not reached their normal retirement date on or before November 10, 2015 shall contribute to the fund at a rate of six (6) percent of their annual compensation. 
(b)  Payroll deduction. For periods prior to the city pickup date the city shall cause to be deducted from the compensation of each member for each payroll period the proper contribution authorized and payable by the respective members for such payroll period. 
(c)  Member contributions for service prior to effective date. Members shall have the right, at their option and pursuant to rules established by the board, to make additional contributions attributable to years of service prior to the effective date, so that the contributions previously made for such year, would be equal to either five (5) percent or seven (7) percent of annual compensation for any such years, plus three (3) percent interest per annum, in order to increase the member's pension formula for these years to one and four-tenths (1.4) percent or two (2) percent times years of service times average final compensation. Such contributions shall become a part of the employee's prior vested benefits and be matched dollar for dollar by the city. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.12(2); Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 914, § 1, 3-22-94; Ord. No. 1397, § 5, 3-8-16) 
Sec. 15-82. - Cessation of contributions. 
    The contributions required of a member under this article shall cease upon: 
(1)  Service retirement; 
(2)  Disability retirement; 
(3)  Death; 
(4)  Other termination of employment. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.12(3); Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91) 
Sec. 15-83. - Contributions by reinstated employee. 
    Should a member be discharged or suspended by reason of the rules and regulations of the personnel board of the city prior to the city pickup date, and should subsequently be reinstated as an employee, he may receive membership service credit for the period he was under suspension or discharge by making contributions for such period, including accrued interest, both of which shall be paid within six (6) months of employee's reinstatement and he shall in such case again become a member of the system. Beginning on the city pickup date, should a person be discharged or suspended by reason of the rules and regulations of the personnel board of the city and should subsequently be reinstated as an employee, then the city shall not be obliged to fund for the period during which the member was discharged or suspended; however, years of credited service prior to such period shall be restored. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.12(4); Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 914, § 1, 3-22-94) 
Sec. 15-84. - Reemployed person; change in employer. 
(a)  If a general employee who was previously employed by the city is reemployed by the city on or after the date the city joins FRS, such employee shall participate in FRS and not in this system. 
(b)  Should a person be employed by the city administration after having been employed by the office of the city attorney prior to October 1, 1989, the employee shall for the purposes of this article be deemed to be an employee as of his date of original employment with the city attorney; provided, however, that the employee pays into the fund the accumulated contributions that would have been made during the period of employment with the city attorney. Upon such payment to the fund such employee shall be credited with additional membership service beginning with the date of such payment to the fund. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.12(5); Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 914, § 1, 3-22-94; Ord. No. 1078, § 1, 3-13-01; Ord. No. 1397, § 6, 3-8-16) 
Sec. 15-85. - Leave of absence of member. 
(a)  Any member granted a leave of absence may elect to leave his prior vested benefit and accumulated contributions in the fund pending his return as an employee and member and receive credit for the years for which contributions had been made, provided such member returns to employment with one (1) month following the end of his leave of absence, except as regards former members on military leave of absence, who shall return to employment within twelve (12) months following return to civilian life; provided all such persons on leave of absence who had withdrawn their prior vested benefits and accumulated contributions shall have the right on their return to employment within one (1) month or twelve (12) months, respectively, to repay into the fund within six (6) months of the date that the employee returns to employment the amounts previously withdrawn plus accrued interest. Upon such payment the member shall again be entitled to credit service or such prior period of employment plus any service in the future as otherwise provided in this article. 
(b)  General employee members on military leave who return to employment shall have the additional right to repay into the system, for the period of such military leave up to a maximum of five (5) years, contributions for any part or all of such period at equal to three (3) percent, five (5) percent, seven (7) percent of their compensation at time of commencement of their leave, plus three (3) percent interest per annum; provided, that to receive full benefits under this article, repayment must be made at the rate effective during the member's leave. Upon such repayment being made, member shall be granted credited service for the period covered by such payment and the city shall finance the remaining portion of the liability for such coverage as determined by the actuary for the system. 
(c)  Sworn police personnel members on military leave who return to employment shall have the additional right, pursuant to F.S. § 185.02(5)(d), to credited service of up to a maximum five (5) years of the time spent in the military service. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.12(6); Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 1060, § 3, 9-26-00) 
Editor's note- The provisions of section 15-85 shall be effective December 31, 1999. 
Sec. 15-85.1. - Military service credit; contributions for military service. 
    Members shall have the option to purchase for up to four (4) years of active duty military service with the U.S. Armed Forces or her allies if each of the following requirements are also met: 
(1)  Members must complete ten (10) years of creditable service in the city system before becoming eligible to claim such military credit. A member must make a written election of this option within four (4) years of eligibility on a form provided by the city, with such election accompanied by the documentation set forth in subsection (2) below, and an agreement that the member will pay the amount calculated pursuant to subsection (3) below at the time and in the form and manner set forth therein. 
(2)  To receive retirement credit for active military service, a member must submit with such written election an original or certified copy of their certificate of service (Form DD214) showing the date of entry into active service and date of discharge under honorable conditions. 
(3)  To receive retirement credit for active military service, a member who is an active employee of the city must pay out of his salary a weekly amount equal to one fifty-second ( 1/52 ) of four (4) percent of his annual city salary, based on the amount earned in their first year of creditable service with the city, for each year of military service credit claimed, along with interest at five (5) percent compounded annually, with the members required contribution hereunder to be picked-up by the city pursuant to I.R.S. Code Section 414(h)(2). In the case of a member who ceases to be an active city employee prior to the total payment of all amounts due and owing under this subsection (3), all amounts which remain payable under this subsection (3) at the time of the member's termination of employment shall immediately become due and payable in one (1) lump sum. 
(4)  All military service credited under this section shall be treated, for purposes hereof, as credited city service. The benefit percentage per year of service as applicable for this military service is three (3) percent of final average compensation. 
(5)  Military service credit shall become effective only after full payment as provided in subsection (3) above. 
    Notwithstanding any provision of this plan to the contrary, effective as of December 12, 1994, contributions, benefits and service credit with respect to qualified military service will be provided in accordance with Section 414(u) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended, USERRA or F.S. chs. 175 and 185, as applicable. 
    For years beginning after December 31, 2008, (i) an individual receiving a differential wage payment, as defined in Section 3401(h)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code, shall be treated as an employee of the employer making the payment, (ii) the differential wage payment shall be treated as compensation, and (iii) the plan shall not be treated as failing to meet the requirements of any provision described in Section 414(u)(1)(C) of the Internal Revenue Code by reason of any contribution or benefit which is based on the differential wage payment. 
(Ord. No. 691.18, § 1, 12-12-89; Ord. No. 691.19, § 1(B), 3-28-90; Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 914, § 1, 3-22-94; Ord. No. 934, § 1, 6-13-95; Ord. No. 1306, § 5, 10-26-10; Ord. No. 1384, § 2, 4-28-15) 
Sec. 15-86. - Cessation of membership. 
    Upon complete cessation of membership each member shall thereafter lose all rights to any benefit under this article except as provided elsewhere in this article. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.12(7); Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91) 
Secs. 15-87, 15-88. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 858, § 1, adopted October 22, 1991, deleted § 15-87 in its entirety. Previously § 15-87 pertained to vesting and retirement benefits of the city manager and derived from the Code of 1958, § 19-14.20.1. 
DIVISION 5. - BENEFITS 

Sec. 15-89. - Retirement dates. 
    The respective retirement dates for members shall be as follows: 
(1)  Normal retirement date The permissive normal retirement date for a member shall be the first day of the month next following the attainment of age fifty-five (55) years and the completion of twenty (20) years of service, or attainment of age sixty-two (62) years and completion of ten (10) years of service for members other than sworn police personnel and firefighters. The permissive normal retirement date for sworn police personnel and firefighter members shall be the first day of the month next following the attainment of age fifty (50) years and the completion of twenty (20) years of service; provided, however, that the permissive normal retirement date for sworn police personnel and firefighter members of age fifty (50) years shall be contingent upon the sworn police personnel and firefighter members providing the necessary funds to amortize the added cost for the calendar years 1968 and 1969 only, with the city to bear the cost thereafter. If such funds are not so provided, the permissive normal retirement date for sworn police personnel and firefighter members shall be the first day of the month next following the attainment of age fifty-five (55) years and the completion of twenty (20) years' service. If such funds are so provided, and any individual sworn police personnel and firefighter shall not have contributed his pro rata share to the total of such funds, then and in that event, the permissive normal retirement date for such sworn police personnel and firefighter members shall be the first day of the month next following the attainment of age fifty-five (55) years and the completion of twenty (20) years of service. 
(2)  Early retirement. A member may retire from employment with the city on the first day of any month following: 
a.  General employees: The completion of at least fourteen (14) years of credited service; or attainment of age fifty-five (55) years and completion of ten (10) years of credited service. 
b.  Sworn police personnel and firefighters: The completion of at least fourteen (14) years of credited service. 
(3)  Disability retirement date. The disability retirement date shall be the first day of the month following the date of formal approval by the board of a member's application for disability retirement. 
(4)  Delayed retirement date. Delayed retirement date shall be that date subsequent to the normal retirement date, upon which a member actually retires. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.13; Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 914, § 1, 3-22-94; Ord. No. 1008, § 1, 2-23-99) 
Sec. 15-90. - Retirement benefits. 
    The retirement benefits for members shall be as follows: 
(1)  Normal retirement benefit for members who have reached their normal retirement date on or before November 10, 2015: 
a.  Benefit percentage per year of service. The regular monthly normal retirement benefit shall be an amount equal to two and one-half (21/2) percent of average final compensation times all years of credited service prior to July 1, 1969, and three (3) percent of average final compensation times all years of credited service after July 1, 1969, however, for any year prior to October 1, 1968, during which a member has contributed less than seven (7) percent of compensation the benefit percentage for each such year of service shall be as follows: 
Contribution 
rate (percentage) Benefit 
percentage 
per year 
of service 5 1.4 3 0.8  
b.  Normal form of benefit; life. Unless an option is selected, the normal form of benefit payment shall be monthly during the lifetime of the member. 
c.  Benefits in addition to special police benefits. Regarding sworn police personnel, any benefits received under the provisions of this article shall be entirely in addition to any benefits received or to be received by any sworn police personnel attributable to funds received from the state for the exclusive use of sworn police personnel except as provided in subsection 15-89(1). Upon retirement after the effective date, sworn police personnel who are active contributing members of the plan shall be entitled to receive a lump sum distribution of reserve chapter 185 premium taxes, which were allocated to the plan to provide minimum benefits for the sworn police personnel who did not transfer to the North Miami Police Pension Plan. 
(2)  Normal retirement benefit for members who have not reached their normal retirement date on or before November 10, 2015: 
a.  Benefit percentage per year of service for members with fifteen (15) or more complete years of credited service as of November 10, 2015: the regular monthly normal retirement benefit shall be an amount equal to three (3) percent of average final compensation times all years of credited service. 
b.  Benefit percentage per year of service for members with ten (10) or more complete years and less than fifteen (15) complete years of credited service as of November 10, 2015: the regular monthly normal retirement benefit shall be an amount equal to three (3) percent of average final compensation times all years of credited service prior to November 10, 2015, and two and one-half (21/2) percent of average final compensation times all years of credited service on or after November 10, 2015. 
c.  Benefit percentage per year of service for members with less than ten (10) complete years of credited service as of November 10, 2015: the regular monthly normal retirement benefit shall be an amount equal to three (3) percent of average final compensation times all years of credited service prior to November 10, 2015, and two (2) percent of average final compensation times all years of credited service on or after November 10, 2015. 
(3)  Delayed retirement benefit. A member shall upon retirement at his delayed retirement date receive a monthly retirement benefit which shall commence on such delayed retirement date and shall be continued on the first day of each month thereafter during the lifetime of the member. The amount of each such monthly retirement benefit shall be determined in the same manner as for retirement at his normal retirement date except that credited service shall be determined as of actual retirement date. 
(4)  Early retirement benefit. A member shall receive upon retirement at his early retirement date either a deferred or an immediate monthly retirement benefit, as follows: 
a.  A deferred monthly retirement benefit which shall commence on his normal retirement date and shall be continued on the first day of each month thereafter during the lifetime of the member. The amount of each such deferred monthly retirement benefit shall be determined in the same manner as for retirement at his normal retirement date except that credited service and average final compensation shall be determined as of his early retirement date; or 
b.  An immediate monthly retirement benefit which shall commence on his early retirement date and shall be continued on the first day of each month thereafter during the lifetime of the member. The amount of such immediate monthly retirement benefits shall be of the benefits provided in subparagraph (3)a. of this section reduced by 0.33 percent each month by which the early retirement date precedes the normal retirement date. 
c.  Accumulated contributions benefit. The contributions of a member formerly in Pension Ordinance 748 which is attributable to the period from January 1, 1977 through September 30, 1982, shall be payable to the member in a lump sum upon retirement. The contributions of a former 748 member which are attributable to the time period on and after October 1, 1982, shall remain in the fund to provide enhanced plan benefits. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.14; Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 895, §§ 1, 2, 2-23-93; Ord. No. 914, § 1, 3-22-94; Ord. No. 934, § 1, 6-13-95; Ord. No. 1397, § 7, 3-8-16; Ord. No. 1415, § 2, 6-27-17) 
Sec. 15-91. - Maximum annual benefit. 
(a)  (1)  Subject to the exceptions below, the maximum annual benefit payable to a member under the system in any limitation year shall equal the lesser of: Seventy-five thousand dollars ($75,000.00) or one hundred (100) percent of the member's section 415 compensation averaged over the three (3) consecutive limitation years (or actual number of limitation years for members who have been employed by the city for less than three (3) consecutive limitation years) during which the member had the greatest section 415 compensation. For purposes of applying the limitations, the limitation year shall be the fiscal year of the system. Notwithstanding anything in this article to the contrary, the maximum annual benefit for any participant in a defined benefit plan in existence on July 1, 1982, shall not be less than the protected current accrued benefit, payable annually, provided for under question T-3 of Internal Revenue Service Notice 83-10. 
(2)  For plan years beginning on or after October 1, 1997, subject to the exceptions below, the maximum annual benefit payable to a member under the system in any limitation year shall not exceed ninety thousand dollars ($90,000.00). For purposes of applying the limitation, the limitation year shall be the fiscal year of the system. Notwithstanding anything in this article to the contrary, the maximum annual benefit for any participant in a defined benefit plan in existence on July 1, 1982, shall not be less than the protected current accrued benefit, payable annually, provided for under question T-3 of Internal Revenue Service Notice 83-10. 
(3)  For limitation years ending after December 31, 2001, subject to the exceptions below, the maximum annual benefit payable to a member under the system in any limitation year shall not exceed one hundred sixty thousand dollars ($160,000.00). 
(b)  The limitation of one hundred sixty thousand dollars ($160,000.00) shall be adjusted annually as provided in section 415(d) of the code pursuant to the regulations prescribed by the secretary of the treasury (the section 415(b) dollar limitation). The adjusted limitation is effective as of January first of each calendar year and is applicable to limitation years ending with or within that calendar year. The percentage limitation stated above for members who have separated from service with a non-forfeitable right to an accrued benefit shall be adjusted annually as provided in section 415(d) of the code pursuant to the regulations prescribed by the secretary of the treasury. 
(c)  Adjustments to annual benefit and limitations. 
    If the annual benefit begins after age sixty-five (65) years, the section 415(b) dollar limitation shall be increased so that it is the actuarial equivalent of the limitation of the section 415(b) dollar limitation at age sixty-five (65) years. For purposes of adjusting the annual benefit to a straight life annuity, the interest rate assumption shall satisfy section 415(b)(2)(E), as specified by the board of trustees with the advice of the pension system actuary. 
    If the annual benefit begins prior to age sixty-two (62), the section 415(b) dollar limitation applicable to the participant at the earlier age is the annual benefit payable in the form of a straight life annuity commencing at the earlier age that is actuarially equivalent to the section 415(b) dollar limitation applicable to the participant at age sixty-two (62), calculated using assumptions that satisfy section 415(b)(2)(E). 
    For purposes of adjusting the section 415(b) dollar limitation applicable prior to age sixty-five (65) years, the interest rate assumption shall be the greater of five (5) percent or the rate specified by the board of trustees with the advice of the pension system actuary and the mortality decrement shall be ignored to the extent that a forfeiture does not occur at death. For purposes of adjusting the section 415(b) dollar limitation applicable after age sixty-five (65) years, the interest rate assumption shall not be greater than the lesser of five (5) percent or the rate specified (see above) and the mortality decrement shall be ignored to the extent that a forfeiture does not occur at death. For purposes of this section no adjustments under section 415(d) shall be taken into account before the limitation year for which such adjustment first takes effect. 
    For limitation years beginning on or after July 1, 2007, the following shall apply: 
(1)  In the event the annual benefit begins before age sixty-two (62), the benefit will be limited to: 
a.  If the annual benefit begins in a limitation year beginning before July 1, 2007, the annual amount of a benefit payable in the form of a straight life annuity that is the actuarial equivalent of the section 415(b) dollar limitation), with actuarial equivalence computed using whichever of the following produces the smaller annual amount: (1) the interest rate and mortality table or other tabular factor specified in the plan for determining actuarial equivalence for early retirement purposes; or (2) a five-percent interest rate assumption and the applicable mortality table. 
b.  if the annual benefit begins in a limitation year beginning on or after July 1, 2007, the lesser of (1) section 415(b) dollar limitation; and (2) the product of the dollar limitation under section 415(b)(1)(A) (as adjusted under section 415(d)) multiplied by the ratio of the annual amount of the immediately commencing straight life annuity under the plan at the participant's annuity starting date to the annual amount of the immediately commencing straight life annuity under the plan at age sixty-two (62), both determined without applying the limitations of section 415. The applicable mortality table is the mortality table described in Rev. Rul. 2001-62, as may be amended from time to time. 
(2)  If the annual benefit begins after age sixty-five (65), the section 415 dollar limitation is increased to: 
a.  if the annual benefit begins in a limitation year beginning before July 1, 2007, the annual amount of a benefit payable in the form of a straight life annuity commencing at the participant's annuity starting date that is the actuarial equivalence computed using whichever of the following produces the smaller annual amount: (1) the interest rate and mortality table or other tabular factor specified in the plan for determining actuarial equivalence for delayed retirement purposes; or (2) a five-percent interest rate assumption and the applicable mortality table. 
b.  if the annual benefit begins in a limitation year beginning on or after July 1, 2007, the lesser of (1) the adjusted dollar limitation determined in accordance with (ii); and (2) the product of the section 415(b) dollar limitation under section 415(b)(1)(A)(as adjusted under section 415(d)) multiplied by the ratio of the annual amount of the immediately commencing straight life annuity under the plan at the participant's annuity starting date to the annual amount of the immediately commencing straight life annuity under the plan at age sixty-five (65), both determined without applying the limitations of section 415. 
The applicable mortality table is the mortality table described in Rev. Rul. 2001-62, as may be amended from time to time. 
(3)  For purposes of applying the limits of section 415, a benefit that is payable in any form other than a straight life annuity and that is not subject to section 417(e)(3) shall be adjusted to an actuarially equivalent straight life annuity that equals: 
a.  for limitation years beginning on or after July 1, 2007, the greater of the annual amount of the straight life annuity (if any) payable under the plan at the same annuity starting date, and the annual amount of a straight life annuity commencing at the same annuity starting date that has the same actuarial present value as the participant's form of benefit computed using an interest rate of five (5) percent and the applicable mortality table under section 417(e)(3). 
b.  for limitation years beginning before July 1, 2007, the annual amount of a straight life annuity commencing at the same annuity starting date that has the same actuarial present value as the participant's form of benefit computed using whichever of the following produces the greater annual amount: (1) the interest rate and mortality table or other tabular factor specified in the plan for adjusting benefits in the same form; and (2) a five-percent interest rate assumption and the applicable mortality table. 
    The applicable mortality table is the mortality table described in Rev. Rul. 2001-62, as may be amended from time to time. 
(d)  The employer hereby elects pursuant to the provisions of section 415(b)(10) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended, to have the special limitations applicable to state and local government plans applicable. The limitations imposed by section 415 of the Code as related to this plan shall be calculated in accordance with the special rules set forth in section 415(b)(10). 
(e)  Reduction for services less than ten (10) years. Subject to the requirements of section 415 of the Code, if a member had less than ten (10) years of credited service with the city at the time he begins to receive benefits, the limitations of this section shall be reduced by multiplying such limitations by a fraction, the numerator of which is the number of the member's years of credited service, or part thereof, and the denominator of which is ten (10). For plan years beginning on or after December 31, 1996, subject to the requirements of section 415 of the Code, income received from this plan as the result of the member's becoming disabled by reason of personal injury or sickness and income received by the beneficiaries and survivors or estate of a member as the result of the death of the member shall not be subject to reduction pursuant to this section 15-91(e). 
(f)  For plan years beginning on or after December 31, 1996, in the case of a policeman or firefighter who is a "qualified participant" as defined herein below, the limitations contained in subsections (a), (b), (c) and (d) of this section 15-91 shall not be applicable. The maximum benefit provided hereunder to "qualified participants" shall be an annual benefit in the form of a straight life annuity not greater than one hundred sixty thousand dollars ($160,000.00) as adjusted from time to time pursuant to Code section 415(d). A "qualified participant" is a member of this plan whose period of service taken into account for benefit purposes includes at least fifteen (15) years of service as defined herein. Years of service shall include all service credited under the plan as a full time employee of any police department or fire department operated by the political subdivision maintaining this plan for any area within the jurisdiction of this political subdivision and all service credited under the plan for service as a member of the armed forces of the United States. 
(g)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of this plan, the benefit of a member shall be reduced to the extent that it exceeds amounts specified in section 415 of the Code. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.14; Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 982, § 1, 10-28-97; Ord. No. 1306, § 6, 10-26-10) 
Sec. 15-92. - Disability benefits. 
(a)  Service incurred disability benefit. There shall be paid any member entitled to a service incurred disability pension a monthly benefit of seventy-five (75) percent of compensation, for life or until recovery from disability, such benefit to be reduced by an offset as provided in subsection (c) of this section. 
(b)  Nonservice-incurred disability benefit. There shall be paid any member entitled to nonservice incurred disability pension a monthly benefit equal to two and one-half (21/2) percent of average final compensation times all years of credited service prior to July 1, 1969, and three (3) percent of average final compensation times all years of credited service after July 1, 1969. However, for any year prior to October 1, 1968, during which a member has contributed less than seven (7) percent of compensation, the benefit percentage for each year of service shall be as follows: 
    Any benefit payable as developed by the above formula, or by a combination of the above formulae, shall be subject in any event to a maximum of fifty (50) percent of compensation, such benefit to be reduced by any benefits received from social security; however, any member entitled to an early or normal service retirement benefit as of time of disability or entitlement to a disability benefit may elect to take an early or normal retirement benefit in lieu and instead of the disability benefit. 
Contribution 
rate (percentage) Benefit percentage 
per year of service 5 1.4 3 0.8  
(c)  Maximum benefit from all sources and benefit offset. The maximum disability benefit payable from all sources (benefits from system, worker's compensation, social security, benefits under the provisions of Ordinance No. 582 included in this chapter as article II) shall not in any event exceed a member's regular rate of compensation in city employment immediately preceding disability; therefore, benefits payable from the system shall accordingly be reduced so that the total benefit received from all sources as above set forth shall not exceed one hundred (100) percent of the disabled member's regular rate of compensation in city employment immediately preceding disability. 
(d)  Disability. "Disability" shall mean a physical or mental condition resulting from a bodily injury, disease, illness or mental disorder which renders a member incapable of performing work for the city which would provide compensation to such member at the following rates of the member's regular rate of compensation in his city employment immediately preceding disability: 
(1)  Service incurred disability. A rate not less than ninety (90) percent of the member's regular rate of compensation. 
(2)  Nonservice incurred disability. A rate not less than seventy-five (75) percent of the member's regular rate of compensation. 
(e)  Determination of disability; board decision; medical examination. In order for a member to be entitled to any type of disability benefit he shall apply in writing to the board of trustees, whereupon the board shall arrange with the medical director for physical examination of such applicant by the medical committee. The findings of the medical committee concerning the disabled status of such applicant and the question as to whether or not the disability is service-connected shall be final. Any person receiving a disability benefit pursuant to this article shall be subject to reexamination annually, in the sole discretion of the board of trustees, for the purpose of determining the then existing status of the disability of such pensioner. If found to be able to perform active duty, such retiree shall be reinstated in employment and shall receive full credit for credited service during the period of disability. In determining the nature and extent of any disability the board and the medical committee, following uniform rules of procedure, may if deemed necessary cause an applicant to be examined by other physicians designated by the board. Should any applicant or retiree refuse to submit to examination as specified by this section, his eligibility for and rights to a disability benefit shall cease. 
(f)  Optional methods of disability retirement payments. In lieu of the benefits otherwise provided, any police officer or firefighter member awarded a disability retirement pursuant to this section may elect to have his disability retirement benefit payable under either of the options set forth in subsections 15-95(1) or 15-95(2). The value of optional disability retirement benefits shall be actuarially equivalent to the value of benefits otherwise payable. 
Editor's note- The provisions of subsection (f) shall be effective Dec. 31, 1999. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.15; Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 895, § 3, 2-23-93; Ord. No. 914, § 1, 3-22-94; Ord. No. 934, § 1, 6-13-95; Ord. No. 1060, § 4, 9-26-00) 
Sec. 15-93. - Death benefits. 
(a)  Death before retirement. 
(1)  Service connected. Upon the death of a member where the cause of death is the direct result of an act or occurrence arising from employment there shall be paid to such deceased member's surviving spouse, till death or, as to general employees, remarriage, or for or on behalf of any child under age nineteen (19) years, a monthly benefit equal to fifty (50) percent of such deceased member's monthly compensation at the time of death, plus ten (10) percent of such member's monthly compensation to each child under age nineteen (19) years. Except as provided elsewhere in this section the total maximum death benefit shall be one hundred (100) percent of compensation, or fifty (50) percent if there is no surviving spouse. If survivors receive benefits from social security or workers' compensation the amount of compensation from this pension plan shall be reduced by an amount so that all funds collected from workers' compensations and social security and the pension plan shall not exceed one hundred (100) percent of the employee's salary at the time of death. Benefits payable from any veterans benefits or pension under state or federal law will not require an offset from this pension plan. If the deceased member had previously selected an option, such option shall apply to the exclusion of other provisions herein. Death benefits paid to a surviving spouse of a sworn police officer or fire fighter shall not be effected by remarriage, provided the city continues to receive state excise tax monies as provided in F.S. §§ 185.08 and 175.101. 
(2)  Nonservice-connected. 
a.  Upon the nonservice-connected death of a member not entitled to an early or normal retirement benefit there shall be paid to such deceased member's beneficiaries an amount equal to such member's prior vested benefit plus his accumulated contributions. 
b.  Upon the nonservice-connected death of a member entitled to an early or normal retirement benefit, without such member having previously selected an option under which survivorship benefits are payable, it shall be assumed that such member had elected Option B2 (life and ten (10) years certain basis) and retired immediately preceding his death. If the deceased member had previously selected an option, such option shall apply to the exclusion of other provisions in this section. 
(b)  Death after retirement. Any benefit payable by reason of the death of a retiree shall be pursuant to the option selected prior to retirement. If no option has been selected, the death benefit payable shall be the difference between the retired member's prior vested benefit plus his accumulated contributions as of his retirement date and the total monthly retirement benefits paid prior to his date of death. 
(c)  Death during qualified military service. In the case of a death or disability occurring on or after January 1, 2007, if a participant dies while performing qualified military service (as defined in Section 414(u) of the Internal Revenue Code), the survivors of the participant are entitled to any additional benefits (other than benefit accruals relating to the period of qualified military service) provided under the plan as if the participant had resumed and then terminated employment by the city on account of death. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.16; Ord. No. 858, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 914, § 1, 3-22-94; Ord. No. 934, § 1, 6-13-95; Ord. No. 944, § 1, 5-28-96; Ord. No. 1384, § 2, 4-28-15) 
Sec. 15-94. - Termination benefits. 
    Upon the termination of a member for any reason, including discharge, the minimum benefit to which a member shall be entitled is as follows:
