In the case of a member who ceases to be an active city employee prior to the total payment of all amounts due and owing under this subsection (3), all amounts which remain payable under this subsection (3) at the time of the member's termination of employment shall immediately become due and payable in one (1) lump sum. 
(4)  All increased military benefit percentage under this section shall be treated, for purposes hereof, as credited city service. The benefit percentage per year of service as applicable for this increased military benefit percentage is one (1) percent of final average compensation. 
(5)  Increased military benefit percentage shall become effective only after full payment as provided in subsection (3) above. 
(6)  No more than a total of six (6) years of combined military service credit and law enforcement service credit, as provided for in chapter 15, section 15-126, 15-126.1, 15-126.2 and 15-126.3 may be purchased. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 1, 12-14-99) 
Sec. 15-126.2. - Added military service credit; contributions for military service. 
    Members who have qualified for and purchased military service credit pursuant to section 15-126 and section 15-126.1 of this chapter shall have the option to purchase up to one (1) year added military service credit as provided in subsection (3) below, subject to the following requirements: 
(1)  Members must complete ten (10) years of creditable service in the city system before becoming eligible to claim such added military credit. A member must make a written election of this option within four (4) years of eligibility on a form provided by the city with such election accompanied by the documentation set forth in subsection (2) below, and an agreement that the member will pay the amount calculated pursuant to subsection (3) below at the time and in the form and manner set forth therein. 
(2)  To receive added retirement credit for active military service, a member must submit with such written election an original or certified copy of their certificate of service (Form DD214) showing the date of entry into active service and date of discharge under honorable conditions. 
(3)  To receive added retirement credit for active military service, a member who is an active employee of the city, must pay the cost thereof, including interest, upon advice of the plan actuary and approved by the board of trustees. The members' required contribution hereunder shall be picked up by the city pursuant to I.R.S. Code Section 414(h)(2). In the case of a member who ceases to be an active city employee prior to the total payment of all amounts due and owing under this subsection (3), all amounts which remain payable under this subsection (3) at the time of the member's termination of employment shall immediately become due and payable in one (1) lump sum. 
(4)  All added military service credited under this section shall be treated, for purposes hereof, as credited city service. The benefit percentage per year of service as applicable for this added military service is three (3) percent of final average compensation. 
(5)  Added military service shall become effective only after full payment as provided in subsection (3) above. 
(6)  No more than a total of six (6) years of combined military service credit and law enforcement service credit, as provided for in chapter 15, section 15-126, 15-126.1, 15-126.2 and 15-126.3 may be purchased. 
(Ord. No. 1038, § 1, 12-14-99) 
Sec. 15-126.3. - Law enforcement service credit; contributions for law enforcement service. 
    Members shall have the option to purchase credit for up to five (5) years of active duty sworn law enforcement service with any governmental law enforcement agency, subject to the following requirements: 
(1)  Members must complete ten (10) years of creditable service in the city system before becoming eligible to claim such law enforcement credit. A member must make a written election of this option within four (4) years of eligibility on a form provided by the city with such election accompanied by the documentation set forth in subsection (2) below, and an agreement that the member will pay the amount calculated pursuant to subsection (3) below at the time and in the form and manner set forth therein. 
(2)  To receive retirement credit for active sworn law enforcement service, a member must submit with such written election an original or certified copy of a certificate of service from any governmental law enforcement agency showing the date of entry into active service, date of discharge under honorable conditions and a statement that no retirement benefit was obtained or will be obtained as a result of such service. 
(3)  To receive retirement credit for active sworn law enforcement service, a member who is an active employee of the city, must pay the cost thereof, including interest, upon advice of the plan actuary and approved by the board of trustees. At the option of the member, the member's required contribution hereunder may be picked up by the city pursuant to I.R.S. Code Section 414(h)(2), or the member may elect to pay the cost of the service by lump sum payment, including rollover, or any combination thereof. Provided that a written election is submitted within ten (10) years of eligibility, the member shall have the flexibility to pay the required contributions at any time prior to separation from service. In the case of a member who ceases to be an active city employee prior to the total payment of all amounts due and owing under this subsection (3), all amounts which remain payable under this subsection (3) at the time of the member's termination of employment shall immediately become due and payable in one (1) lump sum. 
(4)  All law enforcement service credited under this section shall be treated, for purposes hereof, as credited city service. The benefit percentage per year of service as applicable for this law enforcement service is three (3) percent of final average compensation. 
(5)  Law enforcement service shall become effective only after full payment as provided in subsection (3) above. 
(6)  No more than a total of six (6) years of combined law enforcement service credit and military service credit, as provided for in chapter 15, section 15-126, 15-126.1, 15-126.2 and 15-126.3 may be purchased. 
(Ord. No. 1039, § 1, 12-14-99; Ord. No. 1415, § 3, 6-27-17) 
Sec. 15-127. - Cessation of membership. 
    Upon complete cessation of membership each member shall thereafter lose all rights to any benefit under this article except as provided elsewhere in this article. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.24(7); Ord. No. 748.7, § 1, 1212-89; Ord. No. 859, § 1, 10-22-91) 
DIVISION 5. - BENEFITS 

Sec. 15-128. - Retirement dates. 
    The respective retirement dates for members shall be as follows: 
(1)  Normal retirement date. The normal permissive retirement date for sworn police personnel shall be the earlier of the first day of the month following the attainment of: 
a.  Age fifty-five (55) years and the completion of ten (10) years of service; or 
b.  Age fifty (50) years and the completion of twenty (20) years of service. 
(2)  Early retirement. 
a.  Sworn police personnel may retire from employment on the first day of any month following attainment of either: 
1.  Age fifty (50) years and completion of ten (10) years of service; or 
2.  Completion of twenty (20) years of service; provided, however, that any person who is a member of the plan on December 31, 2006, shall, within the time established by the Board, irrevocably elect whether to waive his right to receive an early retirement benefit upon the completion of twenty (20) years of credited service. 
b.  Any person who becomes a member of the plan on or after January 1, 2007, may retire from employment on the first day of any month following the attainment of age fifty (50) years and the completion of ten (10) years of credited service. 
(3)  Disability retirement date. The disability retirement date shall be the first day of the month following the date of formal approval by the board of a member's application for disability retirement. 
(4)  Delayed retirement date. Delayed retirement date shall be that date, subsequent to the normal retirement date, upon which a member actually retires. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.25; Ord. No. 859, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 915, § 1, 3-22-94; Ord. No. 924, § 1, 10-25-94; Ord. No. 1005, § 1, 1-26-99; Ord. No. 1064, § 3, 10-10-00; Ord. No. 1215, § 2, 12-12-06) 
Sec. 15-129. - Retirement benefits. 
    The retirement benefits for members shall be: 
(1)  Normal retirement benefits. The regular monthly normal retirement benefit shall be one-twelfth ( 1/12 ) of one (1) percent of final average compensation multiplied by the number of years of credited service earned prior to July 1, 1979; one-twelfth ( 1/12 ) of three (3) percent of final average compensation multiplied by the number of years of credited service earned from July 1, 1979 through December 31, 1997; and one-twelfth ( 1/12 ) of three point five (3.5) percent of final average compensation multiplied by the number of years of credited service earned on or after January 1, 1998. Unless an option is selected, the normal form of benefit shall be monthly for life commencing on the first day of the first month immediately following the member's retirement date and the last payment will be the payment next preceding the member's death; except that, in the event the member dies after retirement but before receiving retirement benefits for a period of ten (10) years, the same monthly benefit will be paid to the beneficiary (or beneficiaries) as designated by the member for the balance of such ten-year period, or, if no beneficiary is designated, to the estate of the member, as provided in F.S. § 185.162. 
(2)  Delayed retirement benefit. Upon delayed retirement a member's benefit commences on the delayed retirement date and shall be continued for life. The amount of benefit shall be determined in the same manner as for normal retirement except that credited service shall extend to the actual retirement date. Retirement benefits shall be the normal retirement benefit unless an option is selected. 
(3)  Early retirement benefit. Upon early retirement a member may select either a deferred or immediate retirement benefit, as follows: 
a.  A deferred monthly retirement benefit which shall be the normal retirement benefit, payment of which shall be deferred until normal retirement age, with credited service and average final compensation determined as to the early retirement date; or 
b.  An immediate monthly retirement benefit which shall commence on the early retirement date and shall be continued on the first day of each month thereafter during the lifetime of the member determined as follows: 
1.  For any person who is a member of the plan on December 31, 2006, and who has irrevocably elected to waive his right to receive an early retirement benefit upon the completion of twenty (20) years of credited service, the amount of such immediate monthly retirement benefit shall be reduced by zero point twenty-five (0.25) percent per month for each month by which the early retirement date precedes the normal retirement date. Notwithstanding the foregoing, any member who has or will complete twenty (20) years of credited service on or before January 1, 2013, and who irrevocably elected to waive his right to receive an early retirement benefit pursuant to this paragraph shall have through December 31, 2012 to revoke the member's prior election. The member shall submit written notice of such revocation to the board; shall retire from city service on or before January 1, 2013; and shall have his benefit calculated using an annual average compensation of the highest fifty-seven (57) months out of the last ten (10) years of credited service and an early retirement penalty of one (1) percent for each year by which the member's early retirement date precedes the member's normal retirement date. 
2.  For any person who is a member of the plan on December 31, 2006, and who has not irrevocably elected to waive his right to receive any early retirement benefit upon the completion of twenty (20) years of credited service, the amount of such immediate monthly retirement benefit shall be reduced by zero point zero eight thirty-three (0.0833) percent per month for each month by which the early retirement date precedes the normal retirement date. 
3.  For any person who becomes a member of the plan on or after January 1, 2007, the amount of such immediate monthly retirement benefit shall be reduced by zero point twenty-five (0.25) percent per month for each month by which the early retirement date precedes the normal retirement date. 
c.  Any member who is entitled to receive either a deferred or immediate retirement benefit under subsection (3)a. or (3)b. of this section shall be considered a retired city employee and shall receive any other benefits provided by the city to other retired members including, but not limited to, a retiree identification card, health care stipend, and the retention of the member's service weapon. 
(4)  Accumulated contributions benefit. The contributions of a member which are attributable to the time period through September 30, 1982, shall be payable to the member in a lump sum upon retirement upon the member's written request in a form and manner determined by the board. The contributions of a member which are attributable to the time period on and after October 1, 1982, shall remain in the fund to provide enhanced plan benefits. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.26; Ord. No. 859, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 894, §§ 1, 2, 2-23-93; Ord. No. 1064, § 4, 10-10-00; Ord. No. 1188, § 1, 7-12-05; Ord. No. 1215, § 3, 12-12-06; Ord. No. 1264, § 3, 7-8-08; Ord. No. 1307, § 4, 10-26-10; Ord. No. 1344, § 1, 11-27-12) 
Sec. 15-129.1. - Cost-of-living adjustment of benefits. 
(1)  The purpose of this section is to provide compounding cost-of-living adjustments, hereinafter referred to as COLA, to the monthly benefits payable to retired members of the plan who retire on or after October 1, 2004, and their beneficiaries. COLA benefits shall only be available in cases where the retired member has selected any form of benefit other than the lump sum benefit option as provided in section 15-134(2). COLA benefits shall not be available to any member receiving a service-connected disability or non service-connected disability. 
(2)  As used herein, "benefit" means the monthly benefit payable to a retiree or beneficiary at the time of an adjustment date, as hereinafter set forth. 
(3)  Effective on or after October 1, 2004, a member who, prior to retirement, selects any form of benefit other than the lump sum option as provided in section 15-134(2), shall be entitled to make an election, which shall be irrevocable, as follows: 
(a)  The annuity portion of the benefit of each member shall be adjusted each April 1st, and shall be subject to pro-ration based on the number of months that the member has been retired during the twelve (12) months preceding each April 1st, as follows: 
(1)  The amount of the monthly benefit payable for the 12-month period commencing on the date coincident with the date on which the retired member has been retired for one (1) year and on each April 1st thereafter, shall be the amount of the member's benefit the preceding month, plus an amount equal to a 1.92 percent of the member's benefit; or 
(2)  The amount of the monthly benefit payable for the 12-month period commencing on the date coincident with the date on which the retired member has been retired for three (3) years and on each April 1st thereafter, shall be the amount of the member's benefit the preceding month, plus an amount equal to a two and five-tenths (2.5) percent of the member's benefit; or 
(3)  The amount of the monthly benefit payable for the 12-month period commencing on the date coincident with the date on which the retired member has been retired for five (5) years and on each April 1st thereafter, shall be the amount of the member's benefit the preceding month, plus an amount equal to a three (3) percent of the member's benefit. 
(b)  In case of a beneficiary becoming entitled to COLA benefits hereunder, the date of the retired member's retirement shall govern. 
(Ord. No. 1163, § 1, 9-28-04; Ord. No. 1361, § 2, 11-12-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1361, § 2, adopted November 12, 2013, redesignated the former section 15-129.2 as section 15-129.1. The historical notation has been preserved for reference purposes. 
Sec. 15-130. - Maximum annual benefit. 
(a)  Subject to the exceptions below, the maximum annual benefit payable to a member under the system in any limitation year shall equal the lesser of: Seventy-five thousand dollars ($75,000.00) or one hundred (100) percent of the member's section 415 compensation averaged over the three (3) consecutive limitation years (or actual number of limitation years for members who have been employed by the city for less than three (3) consecutive limitation years) during which the member had the greatest section 415 compensation. For purposes of applying the limitations, the limitation year shall be the fiscal year of the system. Notwithstanding anything in this article to the contrary, the maximum annual benefit for any participant in a defined benefit plan in existence on July 1, 1982, shall not be less than the protected current accrued benefit, payable annually, provided for under question T-3 of Internal Revenue Service Notice 83-10. For limitation years ending after December 31, 2001, subject to the exceptions below, the maximum annual benefit payable to a member under the system in any limitation year shall not exceed one hundred sixty thousand dollars ($160,000.00). 
(b)  The limitation of one hundred sixty thousand dollars ($160,000.00) shall be adjusted annually as provided in sections 415(d) and 415(b)(2)(F) of the Code pursuant to the regulations prescribed by the Secretary of the Treasury (the "section 415(b) dollar limitation"). The adjusted limitation is effective as of January first of each calendar year and is applicable to limitation years ending with or within that calendar year. The percentage limitation stated above for members who have separated from service with a nonforfeited right to an accrued benefit shall be adjusted annually as provided in section 415(d) of the Code pursuant to the regulations prescribed by the Secretary of the Treasury. 
(c)  Adjustments to annual benefit and limitations. If the annual benefit begins before age fifty-five (55) years, the limitation of one hundred sixty thousand dollars ($160,000.00) shall be reduced so that it is the actuarial equivalent of the limitation of one hundred sixty thousand dollars ($160,000.00) beginning at age fifty-five (55) years. 
    If the annual benefit begins after age sixty-five (65) years, the limitation of one hundred sixty thousand dollars ($160,000.00) shall be increased so that it is the actuarial equivalent of the limitation of one hundred sixty thousand dollars ($160,000.00) at age sixty-five (65) years. For purposes of adjusting the annual benefit to a straight life annuity, the interest rate assumption shall be the greater of five (5) percent or the rate specified by the board of trustees with the advice of the pension system actuary. 
    For purposes of adjusting the limitation of one hundred sixty thousand dollars ($160,000.00) applicable prior to age sixty-five (65) years or the limitation of one hundred sixty thousand dollars ($160,000.00) applicable prior to the age fifty-five (55) years, the interest rate assumption shall be the greater of five (5) percent or the rate specified by the board of trustees with the advice of the pension system actuary and the mortality decrement shall be ignored to the extent that a forfeiture does not occur at death. For purposes of adjusting the limitation of one hundred sixty thousand dollars ($160,000.00) applicable after age sixty-five (65) years, the interest rate assumption shall not be greater than the lesser of five (5) percent or the rate specified (see above) and the mortality decrement shall be ignored to the extent that a forfeiture does not occur at death. For purposes of this section no adjustments under code section 415(d) shall be taken into account before the limitation year for which such adjustment first takes effect. 
    For limitation years beginning on or after July 1, 2007, the following shall apply: 
(1)  If the annual benefit begins after age sixty-five (65), the section 415(b) dollar limitation is increased to: 
a.  If the annual benefit begins in a limitation year beginning before July 1, 2007, the annual amount of a benefit payable in the form of a straight life annuity commencing at the participant's annuity starting date that is the actuarial equivalence computed using whichever of the following produces the smaller annual amount: (1) the interest rate and mortality table or other tabular factor specified in the plan for determining actuarial equivalence for delayed retirement purposes; or (2) a five-percent interest rate assumption and the applicable mortality table. 
b.  If the annual benefit begins in a limitation year beginning on or after July 1, 2007, the lesser of (1) the adjusted dollar limitation determined in accordance with (ii); and (2) the product of the Section 415(b) dollar limitation under section 415(b)(1)(A)(as adjusted under section 415(d)) multiplied by the ratio of the annual amount of the immediately commencing straight life annuity under the plan at the participant's annuity starting date to the annual amount of the immediately commencing straight life annuity under the plan at age sixty-five (65), both determined without applying the limitations of section 415. 
The applicable mortality table is the mortality table described in Rev. Rul. 2001-62, as may be amended from time to time. 
(2)  For purposes of applying the limits of section 415, a benefit that is payable in any form other than a straight life annuity and that is not subject to section 417(e)(3) shall be adjusted to an actuarially equivalent straight life annuity that equals: 
a.  for limitation years beginning on or after July 1, 2007, the greater of the annual amount of the straight life annuity (if any) payable under the plan at the same annuity starting date, and the annual amount of a straight life annuity commencing at the same annuity starting date that has the same actuarial present value as the participant's form of benefit computed using an interest rate of five (5) percent and the applicable mortality table under section 417(e)(3). 
b.  for limitation years beginning before July 1, 2007, the annual amount of a straight life annuity commencing at the same annuity starting date that has the same actuarial present value as the participant's form of benefit computed using whichever of the following produces the greater annual amount: (1) the interest rate and mortality table or other tabular factor specified in the plan for adjusting benefits in the same form; and (2) a five-percent interest rate assumption and the applicable mortality table. 
    The applicable mortality table is the mortality table described in Rev. Rul. 2001-62, as may be amended from time to time. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.26.1; Ord. No. 859, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 894, § 3, 2-23-93; Ord. No. 1307, § 5, 10-26-10) 
Sec. 15-131. - Disability benefits. 
(a)  Generally. A member shall be deemed disabled when there is incurred by the member a mental or physical condition resulting from injury or disease or mental disorder which renders the member incapable of performing work for the city in a manner which is satisfactory to the city and which work is not injurious to the member's health. The determination of whether or not a member is disabled within the meaning of this subsection shall be determined by the board of trustees, in its sole discretion, after receiving findings and recommendations from the medical committee. Any member applying for disability compensation must apply in writing to the board of trustees and such member must agree to submit to medical examinations as the board, following uniform rules of procedure, shall require. Any member receiving a disability benefit pursuant to this section shall be subject to periodic reexamination at such times as are necessary in the sole discretion of the board of trustees. If any member shall subsequently be determined as able to perform satisfactory work for the city without injury to that member's health, such member shall be reinstated to active employment and shall receive full credit for credited service during the period of disability towards future retirement benefits. Any member who refuses to submit to examination as specified in this section shall relinquish all right to disability compensation. 
(b)  Service-connected disability. 
(1)  There shall be paid any member entitled to a service-connected disability pension a monthly benefit of seventy-five (75) percent of compensation, for life or until recovery from disability, and such benefit shall be reduced by an offset as provided in this section. In no event shall the service-connected disability benefit be less than the member's accrued pension, or forty-two (42) percent of final average final compensation, whichever is greater. 
(2)  The maximum disability benefit payable from all sources (benefits from system, workers' compensation, social security, or any other benefits) provided by the city shall not in any event exceed a member's regular rate of compensation in city employment immediately preceding disability; therefore, service-connected disability pension benefits payable from the system shall accordingly be reduced so that the total benefit received from all sources shall not exceed one hundred (100) percent of the disabled member's regular rate of compensation in city employment immediately preceding did ability. Service connected disability benefit payment may be approved for payment by the board subject to request of and following negotiations by the city manager or his designee, with the disabled employee. 
(3)  A service-connected disability is a disability incurred by an employee while directly or indirectly performing services for the city. 
(c)  Nonservice-connected disability. If a member receives a non-service connected disability, that member shall receive either in a lump sum or in a deferred retirement benefit as determined by the board of trustees the actuarial equivalent of the normal retirement benefit, computed by multiplying one (1) percent of average final compensation prior to July 1, 1979, and three (3) percent of average final compensation after to July 1, 1979, times the number of years of credited service attributable to the disabled member multiplied by the vesting percent attributable to the member. The minimum non-service connected disability benefit for a member with at least ten (10) years of credited service shall be the greater of twenty-five (25) percent of average final compensation or the accrued pension payable immediately. 
(d)  Optional methods of disability retirement payments. In lieu of the benefits otherwise provided, any member awarded a disability retirement pursuant to this section may elect to have his disability retirement benefit payable under either of the options set forth in subsections 15-134(1) or 15-134(3). The value of optional disability retirement benefits shall be actuarially equivalent to the value of benefits otherwise payable. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.27; Ord. No. 859, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 894, § 3, 2-23-93; Ord. No. 1005, § 2, 1-26-99; Ord. No. 1059, § 6, 9-26-00; Ord. No. 1188, § 2, 7-12-05) 
Editor's note- The provisions of subsection (d) shall be effective December 31, 1999. 
Sec. 15-132. - Death benefits. 
(a)  Service-connected death. Upon the service-connected death of a member there shall be paid to such deceased member's surviving spouse, if any, for life, an amount equal to fifty (50) percent of the final compensation paid to the member as determined from the average monthly wages paid to the deceased member during the twelve (12) months immediately preceding death. If there is no surviving spouse, this benefit shall be paid to the surviving minor children of the member during their minority or for a period of fifteen (15) years, whichever is greater. Absent a surviving spouse and surviving minor children, this benefit shall be paid to a beneficiary, designated by the member, for the beneficiary's life or a period of fifteen (15) years, whichever is less. This benefit shall be paid monthly commencing on the first day of the month following the death of the member. I addition to the foregoing benefit, there shall also be paid monthly to each surviving child of the deceased member under the age of eighteen (18) during that child's minority ten (10) percent of the final compensation paid to the deceased member. The total death benefit to be paid shall not, in any event, exceed one hundred (100) percent of the member's final compensation. A service-connected death is a death incurred while an employee is performing, directly or indirectly, services for the city. Death benefits paid to a surviving spouse shall not be effected by remarriage, provided the city continues to receive excise tax monies as provided in F.S. § 185.08. Notwithstanding the provisions described above in this subsection (a), in the event of the service-connected death of a member who is eligible for normal retirement, the benefit payable may not be less than the member's accrued pension benefit, and such benefit may not be payable for less than ten (10) years. An annual, compounded cost-of-living adjustment ("COLA") of three (3) percent shall be paid to any beneficiary receiving a service-connected death benefit pursuant to this subsection. 
(b)  Nonservice-connected death. Upon the nonservice-connected death of a member, there shall be paid to the beneficiaries of that member a lump sum consisting of the member's accumulated contributions, which are attributable to the time period through September 30, 1982, plus the actuarially reduced equivalent of the normal retirement benefit multiplied by the vesting percent attributable to the deceased member. Determination as to whether a death is nonservice-connected shall be made by the board of trustees after examination of findings and recommendations of the medical committee and from other evidence presented to the board. 
(c)  Death during qualified military service. In the case of a death or disability occurring on or after January 1, 2007, if a participant dies while performing qualified military service (as defined in Section 414(u) of the Internal Revenue Code), the survivors of the participant are entitled to any additional benefits (other than benefit accruals relating to the period of qualified military service) provided under the plan as if the participant had resumed and then terminated employment by the city on account of death. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.28; Ord. No. 859, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 945, § 1, 5-28-96; Ord. No. 1127, § 1, 4-8-03; Ord. No. 1188, § 3, 7-12-05; Ord. No. 1348, § 2, 2-12-13; Ord. No. 1385, § 2, 4-28-15) 
Sec. 15-133. - Termination benefits. 
    Upon the termination of a vested or partially vested member for any reason, that member shall receive a monthly benefit for the rest of the member's life payable at the member's normal or early retirement date, as the member shall elect within six (6) months of the early retirement date, as a normal or early retirement benefit as determined by the provisions of this plan. In lieu thereof, the board may elect to make an immediate lump sum payment to the terminated member of the actuarially reduced equivalent of the monthly lifetime benefit multiplied by the vesting percentage attributable to the terminated member. This actuarially reduced equivalent shall be determined by reducing the lump sum amount by an average of zero point twenty-five (0.25) percent each month by which the termination date precedes the normal retirement date. In any event, a terminated member shall receive as a lump sum payment at the time of termination, if the member so elects, the member's contributions accumulated prior to October 1, 1982. A terminating member with less than five (5) years creditable service shall receive the member's contribution plus accrued interest accumulated since initial employment. Partially vested members shall receive the greater of the member contribution plus accrued interest or the member's vested benefits. Notwithstanding the foregoing in this section 15-133, no lump sum payment shall be made to a terminating member under this section unless the terminating member elects in writing in a form and manner determined by the board to receive such payment. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.29; Ord. No. 859, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 1064, § 5, 10-10-00; Ord. No. 1215, § 4, 12-12-06; Ord. No. 1307, § 6, 10-26-10) 
Sec. 15-134. - Optional methods of retirement payments. 
    Each member shall have the right at any time within six (6) months prior to his retirement date to irrevocably elect in lieu of benefits otherwise provided in this division and with the trustees' consent, one (1) of the retirement options set forth in this section. The ration of optional retirement benefits shall be actuarially equivalent to the value of benefits otherwise payable. The election by such member shall be by written request to the board of trustees. 
(1)  Joint and last survivor option. A member may elect to receive a decreased retirement benefit which provides a lifetime continuation of this benefit to another person, designated a "joint pensioner." The retiree will have the power to change such designation from time to time but any change shall be deemed a new election and will be subject to approval by the pension board. The amount of retirement income payable shall be actuarially redetermined taking into account the ages and sex of the previous joint pensioner, the new joint pensioner and the employee. The previous joint pensioner must be alive at the time the retiree elects to make a change. 
(2)  Lump sum option. A member may elect to receive in a lump sum at retirement an amount which is the actuarial equivalent to him under this plan. This option shall be calculated without reference to any cost of living allowance. However, employees who first become members on or after October 1, 2004 shall not be eligible for this lump sum option. 
(3)  Five or ten years certain basis. A member may elect to take a reduced benefit on a basis providing that such benefit shall be payable for a period of life and five (5) or ten (10) years certain in any event. 
(4)  Social security option. A member retiring under either early or normal retirement provisions and not for disability may elect to receive an increased benefit from the system until such time as social security benefits commence and a reduced benefit thereafter in order to provide, to as great extent as possible, a more level retirement allowance throughout the period of his retirement. 
(5)  Partial lump sum/annuity option. A member may elect to receive a portion of his benefit in the form of a lump sum and a portion of his benefit in the form of an annuity option provided for in the plan. The value of the lump sum and annuity shall be the actuarial equivalent of the value of the benefits to which the member is otherwise entitled. The actuary for the system shall calculate the amount of a member's lump sum benefit and the amount of the annuity benefit in accordance with the actuarial assumptions set forth in the system. The lump sum portion of the benefit shall be calculated without reference to any cost of living allowance. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.30; Ord. No. 859, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 894, § 4, 2-23-93; Ord. No. 1059, § 7, 9-26-00; Ord. No. 1163, § 2, 9-28-04) 
Sec. 15-135. - Mandatory distribution date. 
(a)  A member's retirement allowance shall be distributed to him not later than the April 1 of the calendar year following the later of the calendar year in which he attains age seventy and one-half (701/2) years. Alternatively, distributions to a member must begin no later than the April 1 following such calendar year and must be made over the life of the member (or the lives of the member and the member's designated beneficiary) or the life expectancy of the member (or the life expectancies of the member and his designated beneficiary). 
(b)  For purposes of this section, the life expectancy of a member and the beneficiary of a participant (other than in the case of a life annuity) may be redetermined, but not more frequently than annually. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this plan to the contrary, a form of retirement income payable from this plan, shall satisfy the following conditions: 
(1)  If the retirement income is payable before the member's death: 
a.  It shall either be distributed or commence to the member not later than April 1 of the calendar year following the later of the calendar year in which the member attains age seventy and one-half (701/2), or the calendar year in which member retires; 
b.  The distribution shall commence not later than the calendar year defined above; and (a) shall be paid over the life of the member or over the lifetimes of the member and spouse, issue or dependent, or (b) shall be paid over the period extending not beyond the life expectancy of the member and spouse, issue or dependent. 
Where a form of retirement income payment has commenced in accordance with the preceding paragraphs and the member dies before his entire interest in the plan has been distributed, the remaining portion of such interest in the plan shall be distributed no less rapidly than under the form of distribution in effect at the time of the member's death. 
(2)  If the member's death occurs before the distribution of his interest in the plan has commenced, member's entire interest in the plan shall be distributed within five (5) years of member's death, unless it is to be distributed in accordance with the following rules: 
a.  The member's remaining interest in the plan is payable to his spouse, issue or dependent; 
b.  The remaining interest is to be distributed over the life of the spouse, issue or dependent or over a period not extending beyond the life expectancy of the spouse, issue or dependent; and 
c.  Such distribution begins within one (1) year of the member's death unless the member's spouse, is the sole designated beneficiary, in which case the distribution need not begin before the date on which the member would have attained age seventy and one-half (701/2) and if the member's spouse dies before the distribution to the spouse begins, this section shall be applied as if the spouse were the member. 
(Code 1958, § 19-14.30; Ord. No. 859, § 1, 10-22-91; Ord. No. 1307, § 7, 10-26-10) 
Sec. 15-136. - Assignment of benefits. 
    All retirees shall be permitted to assign up to one hundred (100) percent of their benefits hereunder to another person or to a trust or up to ten (10) percent of their benefits hereunder to the City of North Miami; provided, however that such assignment shall be made voluntarily and shall be revocable. It is the intent of this provision to permit retirees to assign a portion of their benefits to the city so that such benefits may be contributed by the city to the city's flexible benefit plan. All assignments hereunder shall be revocable upon thirty (30) days' written notice provided to the board. Upon the effective date of a revocation all benefits to which the retiree is entitled shall from that point forward be paid to the retiree. 
(Ord. No. 894, § 5, 2-23-93; Ord. No. 928, § 3, 1-10-95) 
Sec. 15-137. - Direct transfers of eligible rollover distributions. 
(a)  General. This section applies to distributions made on or after January 1, 1993. Notwithstanding any provision of the system to the contrary that would otherwise limit a distributee's election under subsection 15-133(2) and subsection 15-134(2) or (5), a distributee may elect, at the time and in the manner prescribed by the board, to have any portion of an eligible rollover distribution paid directly to an eligible retirement plan specified by the distributee in a direct rollover. 
(b)  Retiree medical premiums for public safety officers. The plan may allow a public safety officer to elect a tax free distribution of up to three thousand dollars ($3,000.00) annually directly to a retiree accident or medical plan or long-term care insurance contract on a pre-tax basis, so long as the public safety officer separates from service either at the plan's normal retirement age or due to his or her disability. Insurance premiums may be paid for the public safety officer, his spouse or his dependents while he is alive, but once he is deceased, the benefit ceases and may not be used by his spouse or beneficiaries to pay for their insurance premiums. Insurance premiums payments may only be made directly to the provider of the accident or health plan or qualified long-term care insurance contract. "Public safety officers" include law enforcement officers, firefighters, chaplains, rescue crew members or ambulance crew members. 
(c)  Definitions. 
(1)  Eligible rollover distribution: An eligible rollover distribution is any distribution of all or any portion of the balance to the credit of the distributee, except that an eligible rollover distribution does not include: any distribution that is one (1) of a series of substantially equal periodic payments (not less frequently than annually) made for the life (or life expectancy) of the distributee or the joint lives (or joint life expectancies) of the distributee and the distributee's designated beneficiary, or for a specified period of ten (10) years or more; any distribution to the extent such distribution is required under section 401(a)(9) of the Code; and the portion of any distribution that is not includable in gross income. 
(2)  Eligible retirement plan: An eligible retirement plan is an individual retirement account described in section 408(a) of the Code, an individual retirement annuity described in section 408(b) of the Code, an annuity plan described in section 403(a) of the Code, or a qualified trust described in section 401(a) of the Code, that accepts the distributee's eligible rollover distribution. Effective for distributions made after December 31, 2001, an eligible retirement plan shall also mean an annuity contract described in section 403(b) of the Internal Revenue Code and an eligible plan under section 457(b) of the Internal Revenue Code which is maintained by a state, political subdivision of a state, or any agency or instrumentality of a state or political subdivision of a state and which agrees to separately account for amounts transferred into such plan from this plan. 
(3)  Distributee: A distributee includes an employee or former employee. In addition, the employee's or former employee's surviving spouse is a distributee with regard to the interest of the spouse. Effective as of January 1, 2008, an employee's or former employee's non-spouse beneficiary is distributee with regard to the interest of the employee or former employee. 
(4)  Direct rollover: A direct rollover is a payment by the plan to the eligible retirement plan specified by the distributee. Effective as of January 1, 2008, a non-spouse beneficiary may make a direct rollover only to an "inherited" individual retirement account as described in section 408(b) of the Internal Revenue Code. If a non-spouse beneficiary receives a distribution from the plan, the distribution is not eligible for a 60-day (non-direct) rollover. 
(Ord. No. 928, § 3, 1-10-95; Ord. No. 1307, § 8, 10-26-10; Ord. No. 1385, § 2, 4-28-15) 
Secs. 15-138-15-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - POLICE OFFICERS' RETIREMENT FUND; ORD. NO. 592.1[7] 

Footnotes:

Editor's note- See note at article V. 
Cross reference- Insurance premium taxes levied, § 18-41. 
State Law reference- Municipal Police Officers Pension Fund, F.S. Ch. 185. 

Sec. 15-141. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Credited service means the sum of police prior service and police membership service. 
    Police membership service means years of service rendered by police officers subsequent to May 1, 1956, regardless of whether or not the membership requirements of article I of this chapter have been satisfied. 
    Police membership service allowance means that portion of police retirement allowance to which a police officer is entitled because of police membership service. 
    Police officer means any duly appointed and enrolled police officer of the city, who has satisfied the membership requirements of article I of this chapter. 
    Police officers' fund means the special police fund created by this article. 
    Police prior service means years of service rendered prior to May 1, 1956 by police officers employed on that date. 
    Police prior service allowance means that portion of police retirement allowance to which a police officer is entitled because of police prior service. 
    Police retirement allowance means the total monthly retirement allowance, consisting of police prior service allowance plus police membership service allowance. 
Cross reference- Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1.2. 
Sec. 15-142. - Fund established. 
    A separate fund shall be set up in the administration of the retirement system for the city to be known as the special police officers' fund. 
(Code 1958, § 19-16) 
Cross reference- Funds, § 7.16. 
Sec. 15-143. - State funds placed in. 
    The funds heretofore and hereafter obtained from the state under F.S. ch. 185 shall be placed in the special police officers' fund of the city. 
(Code 1958, § 19-17) 
Sec. 15-144. - Commingling with other retirement assets. 
    The assets and funds referred to in section 15-142 and section 15-143 above may be commingled with pension fund assets of other retirement systems maintained by the city, for investment purposes only, and provided further that complete records are maintained at all times reflecting the respective assets of such commingled fund. 
(Code 1958, § 19-18) 
Sec. 15-145. - Donations, bequests, etc. 
    The police officer's fund may be augmented by donations, bequests, legacies or contributions in any form from persons desiring to remember or reward the police department of the city, and all such donations, bequests, legacies or contributions shall, as directed by the donor to be left to the police department, be placed in the police officers' fund. 
(Code 1958, § 19-19) 
Sec. 15-146. - Actuarial examinations required. 
    The amount of funds in the special police officer's fund and the liabilities thereunder, shall be actuarially examined once in every three (3) years. The date of such examination shall conform to the date of actuarial examination provided for in this chapter. It shall be the duty of the actuary to determine what amounts must be maintained in the special police officers' fund to defray all liabilities under sections 15-148 and 15-150 and to determine if there be a surplus. 
(Code 1958, § 19-20) 
Sec. 15-147. - Application of other retirement provisions to police. 
    The provisions of article II of this chapter establishing the retirement system for employees of the city shall apply to police officers of the city, except insofar as such provisions are inconsistent with those herein. 
(Code 1958, § 19-21) 
Sec. 15-148. - Computing basic monthly allowance. 
(a)  The basic monthly police retirement allowance shall be determined as follows: 
(1)  Two (2) percent of average monthly basic compensation during final year's service; times 
(2)  Years of credited service, subject however to such upward or downward adjustment as may result from application of the provisions of subsection 15-149(3). 
(b)  The retirement allowance shall be payable monthly for the life of a police officer, payments to commence on the normal or early service retirement date, whichever is applicable. If paid on other than the normal service retirement date the amount payable shall be the actuarial equivalent benefit. 
(Code 1958, § 19-22) 
Sec. 15-149. - Contents of fund for payment of retirement allowance. 
    The fund required for payment of the police retirement allowance shall be obtained from: 
(1)  Such sums as have been provided for prior service under the provisions of article II of this chapter, as therein provided; plus 
(2)  The membership reserve account of the respective, retired police officer, to the extent of depletion thereof; plus 
(3)  Such sums as may be required from the police officer's fund; provided, however, the amount payable from the police officers' fund shall be computed in all cases as though the retiring police officer had contributed at the rate of five (5) percent during his period of membership in the North Miami Employees' Retirement System. 
(Code 1958, § 19-23) 
Sec. 15-150. - Total disability-Allowed. 
    All police officers shall be entitled to total permanent disability benefits, if eligible in accordance with the provisions of section 15-151. The benefit shall be an amount equal to seventy-five (75) percent of compensation at time of incident of such disability. The funds required for payment of the benefits shall be obtained as follows: 
(1)  An amount equal to sixty (60) percent of such disabled police officers' compensation shall ensure to the benefit of the police officer under the provisions of sections 15-202 through 15-204 of this Code. 
(2)  An amount equal to fifteen (15) percent of such compensation shall ensure to the benefit of the police officer and be paid from the police officers' fund. 
(Code 1958, § 19-24) 
Sec. 15-151. - Same-When payments commence; determination. 
    Actual payment of total permanent disability benefits shall commence immediately on approval of a claim. Total permanent disability of a police officer under this article shall be determined by the same criteria as was set up by F.S. ch. 440 the worker's compensation statute. The first check payable shall be on a retroactive basis so that benefits will be paid from date of disability. 
(Code 1958, § 19-25) 
Sec. 15-152. - Prorating benefits when funds insufficient. 
    All benefits provided hereunder are contingent upon sufficient funds being in the police officer's fund and when depleted or insufficient funds are on hand in the police officer's fund to provide for all liability thereunder, such benefits shall be prorated to the police officers entitled thereto in an equitable manner as directed by the special police officers' fund committee provided for in section 15-153 following. 
(Code 1958, § 19-25.1) 
Sec. 15-153. - Committee established; tenure, powers, compensation. 
(a)  The special police officers' fund committee shall consist of three (3) members who shall be the chief of police, or acting chief of police currently holding such position, the mayor of the city and one (1) police officer to be selected by all police officers then employed by the city. The committeeman selected by the members of the police force shall serve for two (2) years commencing with the effective date of the ordinance from which this section was derived or until a successor has been named. If a vacancy occurs on the committee, the vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner that the office was previously filled. The committee shall serve without compensation. 
(b)  Each committeeman shall within ten (10) days of his appointment or election take an oath of office before the city clerk of the city that so far as is devolved upon him that he will diligently and honestly administer the affairs of the committee and that he will not permit to be violated any of the provisions of law applicable to the general retirement system or special police officer's fund. Such oath shall be subscribed to by the committeemen and it shall be certified by the clerk and filed in his office. 
(c)  The committee by majority vote, shall decide all matters of policy concerning the disposition of funds in the special police officer's fund in the event either of a shortage of funds to meet the liability of the provisions of this article or a total lack of funds therein. 
(Code 1958, § 19-25.2) 
Cross reference- Boards, committees and commissions, § 2-31. 
Sec. 15-154. - Contributions by police to general pension fund. 
    Any police officer participating in the provisions of this article shall make contributions to the general pension fund as established under section 15-27. 
(Code 1958, § 19-25.3) 
Secs. 15-155-15-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - POLICE OFFICERS' RETIREMENT FUND AMENDMENT; ORD. NO. 592.1.1[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- See note at article V. 
Cross reference- Insurance premium tax levy, § 18-41. 
State Law reference- Municipal police officers retirement trust funds, F.S. Ch. 185. 

Sec. 15-171. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Active duty shall mean actual services as a police officer with regular status in the police department of the City of North Miami, Florida, except for approved leaves of absence as set forth below. 
    Committee shall be understood to mean special police officers' fund committee of the special police officer's fund as provided in section 15-174 to administer the affairs of this fund. 
    Fund shall mean the special police officers' fund as provided for herein. 
    Participant shall mean every police officer of the city as defined herein, who is eligible to have monies credited to his individual account and to receive benefits therefrom under this article who shall automatically become a participant. 
    Police officer shall mean the police chief and all police officers of the city with regular status in the police department of the city as the committee shall determine to be engaged directly in enforcement of the ordinances of the City of North Miami, County of Dade, and statutes of the State of Florida. 
    Regular status shall have the meaning ascribed to it from time to time by the rules and regulations of the civil service board of the city. 
    Service shall mean all time served as a police officer regularly appointed under the rules and regulations of the civil service board of the city for which regular compensation is paid by the city and all time not to exceed a period of five (5) years during which a participant is absent on a military leave of absence. It shall include all leaves of absence without pay for sickness, for such period of time as may be determined by the board in excess of accumulated sick time for which compensation is received. 
(Code 1958, § 19-25.12) 
Sec. 15-172. - Purpose; repayment of certain funds; state funds. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to amend ordinance number 592.1 which is codified as sections 15-141 through 15-154 so as to implement the provisions of F.S. ch. 185 and to provide means whereby police officers of the city may receive benefits from the funds provided for that purpose by F.S. ch. 185. The fund hereby created is derived from monies received from the state and not from a tax levied by the city and shall be in addition to any other pension plan of the city. Nothing herein shall be construed to in any way affect the operation of benefits of any other pension plan of the city that presently exists. 
(b)  The city employees' retirement system, ordinance number 691, section 15-62 et seq., shall pay into the special police officers' fund all monies received from the state' during years 1955 through 1967 plus interest earned at the rate of three (3) percent per annum less benefits that have been paid to retirees. This shall be accomplished as the cash becomes available in the employees' retirement system, and in no event shall become completed later than December 31, 1968. 
(c)  In addition to the repayment of monies received by the city prior to the year of 1968 the city shall pay into the fund all monies when received from the state pursuant to F.S. ch. 185. 
(Code 1958, § 19-25.11) 
Sec. 15-173. - Special police officers' fund created. 
    There is hereby created in the city a special fund to be known as the special police officers' fund, into which shall be paid all monies received by the city under the provisions of Laws of Florida, 1953, chapter 28230, and all monies which are hereafter paid to the city under the provisions of chapter 28230. 
(Code 1958, § 19-25.13) 
Cross reference- Funds, § 7-6 et seq. 
Sec. 15-174. - Special police officers' fund committee-Created; members; terms; officers; duties of officers; quorum; compensation. 
(a)  There is hereby created a special police officers' fund committee which shall consist of the mayor of the city, the police chief and three (3) police officers of the police department to be elected by police participants. At the first election of the committee members there shall be elected one (1) police officer to serve as a committee member for a one-year term, one (1) police officer to serve as a committee member for a two-year term, and one (1) police officer to serve as a committee member for a three-year term. Thereafter, each year, one (1) police officer shall be elected to serve as a committee member for a three-year term. 
(b)  The committee shall annually elect from its membership a secretary, a treasurer and a vice chairman. The mayor when present shall preside at meetings and in his absence the vice chairman shall assume his duties. The secretary shall keep complete minutes of all proceedings of the committee. The treasurer shall supervise the books and records which record-the receipts and disbursements of the fund and the inventory of assets of the fund. He shall report at each quarterly meeting the assets and liabilities of the fund as of the date of such meeting. All elections of committee shall be by a majority vote, a quorum being present. Three (3) or more members shall constitute a quorum. Committee members shall receive no compensation as such. 
(Code 1958, § 19-25.14) 
Cross reference- Boards, committees and commissions, § 2-31 et seq. 
Sec. 15-175. - Same-Election of police officer members. 
(a)  All elections of police officers to the committee shall be by secret written ballot. Only participants in the fund shall be eligible for nomination and election to the committee and only participants shall be eligible to vote in such elections. 
(b)  Notice of each election shall be posted in the police station of the city at least two (2) weeks prior to the date upon which such election shall be held. 
(Code 1958, § 19-25.15) 
Sec. 15-176. - Same-Replacement of committee members. 
    If at any time between elections a vacancy occurs on the committee for any reason, the remaining committee members by majority vote shall fill the vacancy. The new members chosen shall serve until the next election of the special police officers' fund committee. At the next election a new committee member shall be elected to serve the remainder of the term of any committee member whose membership was terminated. 
(Code 1958, § 19-25.16) 
Sec. 15-177. - Same-Meetings; termination of committee membership for failure to attend meetings. 
    The special police officers' fund committee will hold regular meetings quarterly or more often as determined by the committee. Special meetings may be called by the chairman and secretary or by any three (3) members of the committee. Five (5) days' written notice of a special meeting shall be given in writing to all committee members. The notice shall contain the purpose, date, time and place of this special meeting. If any elected members of the special police officers' fund committee shall fail to attend meetings of the board on two (2) consecutive meeting dates without cause as determined by the special police officers' fund committee, his membership shall be terminated. Written notice shall be given to the member whose membership is thus terminated. 
(Code 1958, § 19-25.17) 
Sec. 15-178. - Same-Powers of the committee. 
    The committee shall have the power and authority as follows: 
(1)  To invest and reinvest monies of the fund and in making such investments they shall be governed by the laws of the state relating to the investments of fiduciary funds; 
(2)  To approve disbursements, pay claims, and authorize payments from the funds by voucher signed by the chairman and secretary of the committee, and by checks signed by the chairman and the treasurer; 
(3)  To interpret the provisions of this article where the meaning is not clear or ambiguity exists; 
(4)  To promulgate necessary rules respecting the operation of the fund, or elections of committee members, not in conflict with the wording or clear intent of this article; 
(5)  To authorize expenditures in connection with preliminary research, technical services, legal services and accounting services; 
(6)  To contract for employees necessary to the general administration of the fund; and 
(7)  To employ legal counsel and auditors necessary to the proper administration of the fund. 
(Code 1958, § 19-25.18) 
Sec. 15-179. - Custody of funds and securities. 
    The custody of all securities and cash of the fund shall be with the special police officers' fund committee. The committee shall deposit all funds not invested in a national or state chartered bank located within the city whose deposits are insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. All securities shall be kept in a safe deposit box or deposited with a corporate trustee. Current inventories of such securities shall be kept as a part of the permanent records of the committee, which shall be audited annually by a certified public accountant. 
(Code 1958, § 19-25.19) 
Sec. 15-180. - Bond required for persons signing checks, etc. 
    All persons, including the police officers' fund committee members and employees, who sign checks or handle money or securities of the fund shall be bonded by a qualified surety. 
(Code 1958, § 19-25.20) 
Sec. 15-181. - Payment of costs, expenses and fees for setting up funds. 
(a)  At the first meeting of the police officers' fund committee the members shall examine all known bills of expense for setting up the fund and shall approve and allow for payment all those that are found to have been necessary and proper charges against the fund, and these bills shall be paid promptly. 
(b)  All costs and expenses for setting up the fund shall be paid from the monies received from the state in the year of 1968. Legal fees as affixed by the court or as fixed by contract for services rendered in securing monies due the fund from the city for the years 1955 through 1967 both inclusive shall be chargeable against funds received from the state in the year 1968. 
(Code 1958, § 19-25.21) 
Sec. 15-182. - Individual accounts to be established; credits to individual accounts. 
(a)  An individual account shall be established for each police officer of regular status on the effective date of this article, and for each police officer currently employed or retired who was in the employ of the city at any time after the enactment of Laws of Florida, 1953, chapter 28230 and for each police officer who attains regular status subsequent to the passage of this article. 
(b)  After payment of all costs, expenses and fees as monies are received from the state, the expenses of administering the fund for the preceding year shall be prorated by the committee and charged against monies received for police officers participants during the year. The balance of such monies shall be credited to the several individual participants in amounts directly proportionate to the total number of months of duty performed by the several police officers in the calendar year preceding the date the monies were received from the state. The length of time of service during the calendar year preceding the date upon which payment is received from the state is the only criterion upon which the amount due each participant out of the state monies received annually is to be calculated. No credit is to be given on account of seniority, rank or amount of compensation which the participants receive. Twenty (20) or more days' work in a calendar month shall be counted as a full month. Twenty (20) workdays shall be considered a full month. If a participant works less than twenty (20) days in a calendar month, he shall be credited with a fractional month, the fraction to be the number of days worked over twenty (20). For example, twelve (12) days worked would create a fraction of twelve-twentieths of a month. 
(c)  The amount of earnings from investments credited to the account of the participant shall bear the same ratio to the total amount of annual earnings as the invested funds belonging to the participant in the fund bear to the total monies invested on behalf of the fund. 
(d)  In addition to the monies received from the state and as earnings on investments, there shall be prorated and credited to the accounts of the individual participants, all forfeitures from police officers as provided for in subsection 15-183(1). Such sums shall be prorated to their individual accounts in the same manner as monies received from the state. 
(e)  Subsequent to the effective date of this article after a police officer as retired and ceased to be a member on active duty as defined in section 15-171, no credits shall be made to his account. Police officers who retire after the enactment of F.S. ch. 185 and prior to the effective day of this article, shall be entitled to participate in the monies they would have participated in had this article been in effect on the day of the enactment of F.S. ch. 185, but they shall not participate in any other monies. Benefits paid prior to the effective date of this article shall be deducted from his account. Monies credited to a participant's account shall be payable only upon the filing of an application with the special police officer's fund committee. The application shall be on a form prescribed by the committee and shall be sworn to by the applicant or his surviving wife or child or if the child is a minor by the guardian of the child or by any other person legally qualified to apply for such monies under the laws of the state. 
(Code 1958, § 19-25.22) 
Sec. 15-183. - Participant's benefits. 
    No participants shall receive benefits from the fund in excess of the amount credited to his account. Subject to this provision, a participant shall receive benefits as follows: 
(1)  Subsequent to the passing of this article, if a participant shall separate except by death from the service of the police department for any reason except as hereinafter provided, such participant shall have no claim on the fund and all monies remaining in an account after separation shall be forfeited to the fund. Police officers who separated from the city prior to the passage of this article and since enactment of Laws of Florida, 1953, chapter 28230, shall have no claim whatsoever on this fund. 
(2)  If a participant shall die while a member of the police department, the entire amount of his credit as of the date of his death shall be paid to the surviving spouse primarily for the purpose of defraying final illness and burial expenses. If there is no surviving spouse and there is a child or children, the entire amount of participant's credit as of the date of death shall be paid to the person designated in writing by the participant to be used for payment of final illness and burial expenses with any excess to be paid to legal guardian of the child or children for their benefit. If there is no surviving spouse or children, there shall be paid to the person designated in writing by the participant to be used for payment of final illness and burial expenses, an amount not to exceed the entire amount of his credit and any excess after payment of final illness and burial expenses shall be paid as designated by the deceased. If the person designated to act for a participant shall predecease him or cannot be located by reasonable effort or shall refuse to act or if the deceased participant has failed to designate anyone, the committee shall have the right to name a person to carry out the purposes of this subsection. In carrying out the purpose of this subsection, the committee shall endeavor to distribute any excess monies after payment of last illness and burial expenses in the same manner in which they would have been distributed in estate administration proceeding. The designation shall be in writing, sworn to, and shall be filed with the secretary of the committee. 
(3)  A participant who has been, since the enactment of Laws of Fla., 1953, chapter 28230, or shall hereafter be retired by reason of length of service or disability under any other pension plan of the city, or who shall voluntarily resign or terminate his employment with the city, shall be paid a graduated amount standing to his credit as of the date of such retirement or voluntary termination. The requirement or termination benefit to be paid to the retired or voluntarily terminated member shall, after five (5) years of service, be five-tenths of the amount standing to his credit. Each year after the fifth year of service, an amount equal to one-tenth will be added to the participant's retirement or termination benefit until the date of the tenth year of service, when the participant shall be entitled to the entire amount standing to his credit as a retirement or termination benefit. Resignation or termination must be voluntary in order that the participant may receive the termination benefits described in this subsection. The participant may elect to take such amount in a lump sum, or to take it in annual payments in a period not to exceed five (5) years. A written notice of election to receive payments other than in a lump sum must be filed with the committee upon a form prescribed by the committee therefor and must be sworn to by the person entitled to receive such monies. A retired participant who has elected to receive the monies due in annual payments, rather than in a lump sum as above, shall not be an active participant as defined by section 15-171. 
(4)  Settlement as provided in [subsections] (1), (2) and (3) above shall be in full settlement of all claims of a participant against the fund. He shall thereupon cease to be a participant. He shall have no further interest in the fund, and shall receive no further benefits. 
(5)  As an alternative to the above benefits, in the event that a court of competent jurisdiction shall find and order that a participant is entitled to benefits under Laws of Florida, 1953, chapter 28230 different from the benefits which that participant is entitled to receive under the terms of this article and such participant does not waive the benefits decreed by the court and accept benefits as provided by this article, the committee shall pay to such participant benefits as required by the decree or order of the court. Such benefits shall be paid from the fund, and in the event that it is necessary to pay such participant a greater amount than he would have received had he accepted benefits under this article, such additional amount shall be deducted from the counts of the other participants on a pro rata basis as determined by the committee. The fund shall indemnify the city against all claims of participants as aforesaid and shall pay all expenses including court costs and attorneys' fees incurred in defending the law suits brought by participants in asserting such claims. 
(Code 1958, § 19-25.23; Ord. No. 592.1.3, § 1, 10-25-88) 
Sec. 15-184. - City's relationship to fund. 
    The city shall have no responsibility for the operation of the fund except those specified herein u and shall bear no expenses in connection therewith. 
(Code 1958, § 19-25.24) 
Sec. 15-185. - Implementation of age retirement benefit. 
    After all monies now in the special police officers' fund are paid over to the special police officers' fund committee, the committee shall immediately pay into the North Miami employees' retirement system as provided by ordinance number 691 such sums as are necessary in the approximate amount of thirty-six thousand dollars ($36,000.00) in order to implement the age fifty (50) retirement benefit for police officers. The cost of such added benefit shall be borne equally by all current participants. 
(Code 1958, § 19-25.25) 
Sec. 15-186. - Disposition of monies received from city for years 1955-1967 pursuant to section 19-25.13. 
    All monies received from the city as provided for in section 15-173 for the years 1955 through 1967 shall be credited to the individual accounts of the police officer participating in the fund during the year for which the money was received plus interest earned for that year on the same pro rata basis as provided in subsection 15-183(2). Such benefits shall only apply to those still employed by the police department or those who have retired or retired and since died but not to those who have separated from the police department without retirement. The share of any retiree shall be reduced by the benefits already paid from this fund during such retirement. 
(Code 1958, § 19-25.26) 
Secs. 15-187-15-200. - Reserved.

ARTICLE IX. - SOCIAL SECURITY[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- See note at article V. 

Sec. 15-221. - Social security extended. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend, effective as of October 1, 1952, to the employees and officials thereof, not excluded by law, and whether employed in connection with a governmental or proprietary function, the benefits of the system of old age and survivors' insurance, as authorized by the Federal Social Security Act and amendments thereto, including Public Law 734 of the 81st Congress, and by chapter 26841, Laws of Florida, 1951; and to cover by such plan all services which constitute employment as defined in section 2 of the chapter 26841, Laws of Florida, 1951, performed in the employ of the city by employees thereof. In pursuance of the policy, and for that purpose, the city shall take such action as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1958, § 19-39) 
Sec. 15-222. - Execution of necessary agreements; administration. 
    The mayor or other chief executive officer of the city is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments with the state for the purpose of extending the benefits provided by the system of old age and survivors' insurance to the employees and officials of this city as provided in section 15-221 which agreement shall provide for such methods of administration of the plan by the city as are found by the state agency to be necessary for the proper and efficient administration thereof, and shall be effective with respect to services in employment covered by such agreement performed after the thirtieth day of September, A.D., 1952. 
(Code 1958, § 19-40) 
Sec. 15-223. - Withholdings. 
    Withholdings from salaries, wages, or other compensation of employees and officials for the purpose provided in section 15-221 hereof are hereby authorized to be made, and shall be made, in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the state agency designated by such laws or regulations to receive such amounts. 
(Code 1958, § 19-41) 
Sec. 15-224. - Payment by city; appropriation. 
    There shall be appropriated from available funds, derived from and valorem taxes, such amounts, at such times, as may be required to pay promptly the contributions required of the city as employer by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, which shall be paid over to the lawfully designated state agency at the times and in the manner provided by law and regulation. 
(Code 1958, § 19-42) 
Sec. 15-225. - Records. 
    The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall adhere to the rules and regulations of the state agency for the enforcement of the laws and regulations. 
(Code 1958, § 19-43) 
Sec. 15-226. - Authority to make agreements excluded. 
    There is hereby excluded from this article any authority to make any agreement with respect to any position or any employee or official now covered, or authorized to be covered, by any other law creating any retirement system for any employee or official of the city. 
(Code 1958, § 19-44) 
Sec. 15-227. - Federal Social Security Act adopted. 
    The city does hereby adopt the terms, conditions, requirements, reservations, benefits, privileges, and other conditions thereunto appertaining, of Title II of the Social Security Act as amended by Public Law, No. 734, 81st Congress, for and on behalf of all the officers and employees thereof and of its departments and agencies, save and except any of such officers and employees now covered or authorized to be covered by any retirement system provided by law, and further excepting any official or employee who occupies any position, office, or employment not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1958, § 19-45) 
Sec. 15-228. - Custodian of funds. 
    The director of finance or the city clerk and treasurer, as directed by the city council, of the city, is hereby designated the custodian of all sums withheld from the compensation of officers and employees and of the appropriated funds for the contribution of the city, and director of finance or city clerk and treasurer of such city is hereby made the withholding and reporting agent and charged with the duty of maintaining personnel records for the purposes of this article. 
(Code 1958, § 19-46)
