ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC LIBRARY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Library department created, § 2-231. 
State Law reference- Public libraries, F.S. Ch. 257. 

Sec. 16-16. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a public library and reading room to be forever free for the use of the inhabitants of the city, which shall be known as North Miami Community Library. 
(Code 1958, § 16-17) 
Sec. 16-17. - Library board-Established; composition; appointment, term. 
    There is hereby created a library board for the North Miami Community Library also known as E. May Avil North Miami Public Library. Each member of the city council shall nominate one (1) member of the library board, which nomination shall be subject to approval of a majority of the city council. The five (5) members thus appointed by the city council shall be residents of the city. The term of board members shall be coterminous with the appointing elected official's term of office. The city council may at any time remove a member from office and appoint a qualified person to serve out the unexpired term of any member so removed. Such action shall require three (3) positive votes. If any member fails to attend two (2) out of three (3) successive meetings without cause and without prior notice and approval of the chairman, the board shall declare the member's office vacant and the city council shall promptly fill such vacancy for the remainder of the term. The city council may reappoint the person removed provided there is at least a majority vote of the city council to do so. The board members shall serve without compensation. Members of the library board shall elect a chairperson, who shall be the presiding member; a vice-chairperson, who shall preside in the absence or disqualification of the chairperson; and shall appoint a secretary. Terms of all officers shall be for one (1) year, with eligibility for re-election. The library board shall give at least five (5) days notice of all meetings by posting such notice on the bulletin board of city hall. 
(Ord. No. 853, § 1, 9-10-91; Ord. No. 1371, § 1, 4-22-14) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 853, §§ 1 and 2, adopted Sept. 10, 1991, amended the Code to read as herein set out in §§ 16-17 and 16-18. Prior to inclusion of said ordinance, §§ 16-17 and 16-18 pertained to the creation, powers and duties of the board of directers and derived from the Code of 1958, §§ 16-18, 16-19; Ord. No.817, § 4, adopted July 11, 1989. 
Sec. 16-18. - Same-Powers, duties. 
    The library board may, subject to supervision by the city manager, and control by the city council, make and adopt bylaws and rules and regulations for their guidance and for use and administration of the library and its facilities, as may be deemed necessary to maintain the usefulness and efficiency of the library, including recommendations regarding library programs and policies, penalties for trespasses or injury to the library grounds, books or other property, or failure to return any books, or for violation of any such bylaw or regulation. Any bylaw or regulation established by the board may be amended by the city council. The board shall make recommendations with regard to all monies collected or donated to the credit of the library fund. 
(Ord. No. 853, § 2, 9-10-91) 
Note- See the editor's note at § 16-17.

Chapter 17 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; code enforcement by special magistrates, § 2-96 et seq.; public works department created, § 2-231; animals, Ch. 4; dogs required to be on leashes in certain places, § 4-4; buildings and building regulations, Ch. 5; beautification or improvement fund, § 7-26 et seq.; city of progress capital improvement fund, § 7-41 et seq.; fire prevention, Ch. 8; garbage and trash, Ch. 9; junked, wrecked, stolen, abandoned property, Ch. 10; land business regulations, Ch. 11; loud noises and speaking devices used by peddlers prohibited, § 11-145; use of streets by peddlers restricted, § 11-146; nuisances, Ch. 12; parks and recreation, Ch. 14; utilities, Ch. 19; land development regulations, alcholic beverages, vegetation, Ch. 29; zoning, App. A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 17-1. - Concealment of storage from public rights-of-way. 
    The storage of two (2) or more motor vehicles, operable or inoperable, and boats which are inoperable in the rear of residential property shall be prohibited unless the storage area is shielded from view of any public rights-of-way. 
(a)  Public rights-of-way shall mean any street, alley, highway or any waterway. 
(b)  Motor vehicle shall mean any land-based self-propelled vehicle not operated upon rails or guideway, excluding motorized scooters, mopeds, motorcycles, and electric personal assistive mobility devices. 
(c)  Storage shall mean the maintaining of any motor vehicles and inoperable boats, regardless whether registered or not, for a period of thirty (30) days or more, in the rear of the property. 
(d)  Shielding shall consist of a permanent or temporary solid fence or wall, hedges or other method of concealment at least six (6) feet in height so as to completely block the view of those traveling on the public rights-of-way of the storage area. 
(e)  The failure to conceal the view of the storage area as required by this section shall be deemed a violation of the Code of Ordinances and will subject the owner of the property to a penalty under the code enforcement procedures of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1236, § 1, 6-26-07) 
Secs. 17-2-17-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREETS 

Sec. 17-11. - Streets, alleys and rights-of-way in plats; bond. 
    Unless specifically waived by the city council in the resolution approving any particular plat, all persons, firms and corporations submitting any plat to the planning commission for subsequent approval by the council shall accompany such proposed plat with an agreement providing for the construction of such streets, alleys and other rights of-way in accordance with the specifications hereinafter set forth, and providing further for drainage of all lands included within such plat in accordance with good engineering principles and practices, to be approved by the city engineer. Such agreement shall be accompanied by a surety bond in the penal sum of not less than one hundred ten (110) percent of the estimated cost of such construction. Such agreement and bond shall be on forms approved by the city engineer and furnished by the city clerk. The condition of such bond shall be such that if the principal shall fully and faithfully perform all the terms and conditions of the principal's agreement and within the times therein specified, then the same shall be void; otherwise the city shall have the right to construct such streets, alleys and other rights-of-way, or at its option, to cause the same to be constructed pursuant to public advertisement and receipt and acceptance of bids. The principal and surety jointly and severally shall agree to pay and indemnify the city upon completion by the city, the final total cost of such construction, including but not limited to engineering, legal and contingent costs together with any damages, either direct or consequential, which the city may sustain on account of the failure of the principal to comply with the terms of such agreement. 
(Code 1958, § 23-1) 
Sec. 17-12. - Time limitation for construction. 
    Such agreement shall provide for the construction of such streets, alleys and other rights-of-way within six (6) months from and after the date of the approval of any such plat by the city council; provided, however, that the council may, in case of unusual circumstances, extend the time for completion of such construction for not to exceed an additional six (6) months, provided the principal first obtains and furnishes the council with the surety's written consent to such extension. 
(Code 1958, § 23-2) 
Sec. 17-13. - Standards of design. 
    Unless otherwise noted in this chapter or as may be waived by the city council, all details of design for streets and sidewalks shall conform to the latest edition of the Metropolitan Dade County Public Works Manual. When alternate design details are shown, the city engineer shall determine the requirement. 
Sec. 17-14. - Street specifications. 
    Unless otherwise noted in this chapter or as may be waived by the city council, all construction specifications shall conform to Divisions II and III of the latest edition of the Florida Department of Transportation Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction, except for references to measurement and payment. References to the state department of transportation shall mean the City of North Miami. 
Sec. 17-15. - Restoration of trenches. 
(a)  Description. The work specified in this section consists of backfilling trenches and restoring surfaces disturbed by the installation or maintenance of underground facilities within the limits of a public right-of-way or easement. This work shall be done in accordance with these specifications and the Metropolitan Dade County Public Works Manual. For the purpose of this section a trench cut two hundred (200) feet or less in length shall be considered a short trench, and a trench cut more than two hundred (200) feet in length shall be considered a long trench. The city will require either a concrete slab for restoring paved base course, boring under the pavement, copies of density tests showing compliance to the following requirements or copies of 10:1 cement mix backfill material. 
(b)  Trenches cut in new roadway prior to the construction of the base course. 
(1)  Before any excavation for underground facilities is begun, all required fill shall be in place and graded to subgrade elevation. 
(2)  After the structure is installed and inspected the trench and space around the structure to a level plane one (1) foot above the structure shall be backfilled in six-inch layers (compacted thickness) and shall be compacted to a density of not less than one hundred (100) percent of the maximum density as determined by the latest edition of AASHTO Specification T-99. Material shall be of selected fine earth material, one hundred (100) percent of which passes a one-inch sieve. Backfilling and compaction shall be carried out evenly on both sides of the structure in approximately level layers, and shall be performed in such a manner so as not to crack, damage or displace the structure. 
(3)  The remaining portion of the trench from a level plane one (1) foot above the top of the structure to the top surface of the subgrade or to the bottom of the base course shall be backfilled and compacted in layers not exceeding eight (8) inches to a density not less than one hundred (100) percent of maximum density as determined by the latest edition of AASHTO Specification T-99. All material used for backfill shall be of a quality acceptable to the city and shall be free from large lumps, wood or other extraneous material. 
(4)  Unless otherwise approved by the city engineer, trenches for direct burial cable or conduit shall be not less than six (6) inches in width and shall be deep enough to provide a minimum cover of twenty-four (24) inches whenever possible. 
(c)  Repair to trenches cut across pavement or short trenches cut parallel to roadway centerline requiring restoration of base course with or without a surface course. 
(1)  Back fill and compaction. Backfill and compaction shall be performed as specified above. 
(2)  Reinforced concrete slab. 
a.  The thickness of the slab shall be a minimum of six (6) inches. 
b.  The width of the slab shall be no less than two (2) feet greater than the width of the trench in order to provide a minimum bearing width of one (1) foot on each side. 
c.  Material. The slab shall be constructed of Class I concrete, and shall have a minimum strength of three thousand (3,000) pounds per square inch and shall be reinforced with No. 6 gauge, six (6) inches by six (6) inches, wire mesh which shall meet the requirements of the latest edition of AASHTO Specification M-55. 
(3)  Limerock base. 
a.  The base shall meet the requirements for long trench restoration. 
b.  Compaction tests shall be furnished the city from a certified testing company. The tests shall be taken after each vertical foot of backfilling plus the base course and at such intervals as may be required by the city. 
c.  The city may waive the compaction tests if the applicant furnishes the city a cash bond equal to one hundred fifty (150) percent of the cost of the restoration and backfilling work. The cost of the bond shall be as estimated by the city engineer with a minimum bond of two hundred dollars ($200.00). If during the period of one (1) year after completion of the work no street failures have occurred, the city will refund the bond upon request of the applicant. If during the one-year period street failure occurs, the applicant will be notified to restore the street failure within forty-eight (48) hours to the satisfaction of the city. If repairs are not made by the applicant, the city will utilize the bond to cause the repair to be made. The city reserves the right to extend the one-year requirement for refunding the bond to the applicant. 
(4)  Roadway surface. For all courses where a permanent pavement exists the concrete slab and the surrounding pavement edges shall be tack coated and a one-inch Type I asphaltic surface source shall be placed on the slab. 
(d)  Repair to long trenches cut parallel to roadway centerline requiring restoration of base course with or without surface course. 
(1)  Back fill and compaction. Backfill and compaction shall be performed as specified above. 
(2)  Limerock base course. 
a.  A limerock base course is required for cases falling within this subsection. 
b.  A reinforced concrete slab as specified above may be substituted for the limerock base. 
c.  The base course shall have a minimum compacted thickness of eight (8) inches or equal to the existing base course thickness if greater than eight (8) inches. 
d.  The width shall be no less than two (2) feet greater than the width of the trench. 
(3)  Roadway surface. Where permanent pavement exists, the base course shall be primed, tack coated and surfaced with one (1) inch of Type I asphaltic concrete. Care shall be taken to tack coat and bond the edges of surrounding pavement. 
(e)  Miscellaneous restoration. Trenches cut across driveways, sidewalks, parkways, and concrete curbs, or curb and gutter shall be backfilled and compacted in accordance with this Code. The surface restoration shall be as follows: 
(1)  Driveways. A minimum of six (6) inches of limerock base, but not less than the thickness of the existing base, shall be placed above the subgrade. The width of the base shall be not less than two (2) feet greater than the width of the trench. The finish surface shall match the existing surface in type and thickness of material. 
(2)  Sidewalks. Concrete sidewalks shall be restored in full sections or blocks to a minimum thickness of four (4) inches and six (6) inches at driveways. 
(3)  Park ways and easements. Parkways shall be restored to match exactly the existing section of parkway. Care shall be taken to prevent damage to trees, shrubs or bushes growing in the parkway area. 
(4)  Concrete curb or curb and gutter. All concrete curb or curb and gutter shall be restored to the existing height and cross section in full sections or lengths between joints. 
(f)  Special requirements. 
(1)  The restoration of all trenches and road surfaces disturbed by the installation or repair of underground facilities shall be completed as soon as reasonable and practical. 
(2)  No more than one thousand (1,000) feet of continuous trench shall be opened at any one (1) time under any single permit. Where deemed necessary by the city in the interest of public safety, convenience or traffic maintenance, the length of continuous open trench permitted may be reduced to less than one thousand (1,000) feet. In general it is not anticipated that any trench would be restricted to less than six hundred (600) feet except in a case of unusual circumstance. 
(3)  The contractor shall be responsible for the safety of any existing underground structure encountered during any part of the work. Incorrect locations or elevations shown on any plans shall not relieve the contractor of his responsibility for ensuring the safety of underground structures. 
(4)  In areas where traffic is to be maintained, a temporary asphalt mix shall be placed over the trench immediately after backfilling. 
(5)  The existing pavement shall be trimmed to neat, straight lines parallel or perpendicular to the roadway centerline. The width shall be equal to the maximum required by the trench excavation, before the permanent pavement replacement is made. The pavement replacement shall be smooth and even with the existing pavement. A bump or depression may justify the complete removal and replacement of the surface restoration. 
(6)  All other restoration shall be restored to a better condition than existed prior to commencement of the work. 
(g)  Traffic maintenance. Traffic maintenance shall conform to the requirements of Metropolitan Dade County. 
Sec. 17-16. - Grades to comply with specific maps. 
    No plat shall be approved when all or any part of the grade of any street or other thoroughfare, however designated, depicted on such plat, is lower than the street grade established by the city engineer. 
(Code 1958, § 23-11) 
Sec. 17-17. - Plans required. 
    No street shall be constructed or reconstructed in the city unless and until a plan (or working drawing) for construction thereof has been approved by the city engineer. Plans shall be prepared by a qualified engineer duly licensed in the State of Florida. Plans shall show the width of right-of-way held by the city, existing paving, proposed paving, and all necessary lines, grades, elevations, dimensions and notes pertaining to the streets shown thereon. 
(Code 1958, § 23-12) 
Sec. 17-18. - Building permits dependent on street provisions, exceptions. 
    No building permit shall be issued for the construction of any improvement on real property, whether residential, business or otherwise, unless the application for such permit and accompanying plans make provision that a street and sidewalk will be constructed, if there be none, or reconstructed, if a street exits but was not originally constructed in substantial compliance with the minimum specifications as set forth in this article, along the full frontage width of the lot or tract for which such permit is sought. At corner lots or tracts the building permit application and plans shall require construction or reconstruction of street along both thoroughfares abutting such lot or tract. No certificate of occupancy shall be issued unless the construction or reconstruction of the street shall have been completed in accordance with the specifications set forth in this article and in accordance with plans approved by the city engineer, however, that either upon application of the owner of the property or upon recommendation of the city manager or city engineer or upon its own initiative, the council may, in its sole discretion and for good cause shown, authorize the issuance of a certificate of occupancy without completion of construction or reconstruction of such street. 
Sec. 17-19. - Issuance of certificate of occupancy by surety bond. 
    The city council, at its sole discretion and for good cause shown, may authorize the issuance of a certificate of occupancy without completion of construction or reconstruction of a street as is set forth in section 23-13 by allowing the substitution of a surety bond in the penal sum of not less than one hundred ten (110) percent of the estimated cost of such construction or reconstruction for the cash bond so required, such surety bond to be in a form acceptable to the city. 
(Code 1958, § 23-13.1) 
Sec. 17-20. - Obstructing streets and traffic; consent of council required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to trespass upon, to block, attempt to block, or in any way impede the free passage of traffic on any of the public streets or alleys of the city without first having secured the consent of the city manager. 
(Code 1958, § 23-15.2) 
Sec. 17-21. - Violations, penalty. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to do any construction on any street right-of-way that does not conform to the plans and specifications referred to in this article, or to construct without first having obtained a grade permit therefor as required by section 17-76, together with the payment of the grade permit fee as provided therein. 
(Code 1958, § 23-15.16) 
Sec. 17-22. - Placement of traffic markers regulated. 
(a)  Permitted markers. For the purpose of preserving grass and other landscaping within dedicated right-of-way areas such as swales, parkways and the like, the following devices may be used by owners of abutting property, as prescribed below: 
(1)  Dome type traffic markers. When used these markers shall not exceed twelve (12) inches in diameter and six (6) inches in height, shall be made of concrete, and shall be white in color. Furthermore dome-type traffic markers shall not be placed closer than twelve (12) inches to the nearest edge of a paved traveled way of a street, road, alley or the like. Within fifteen (15) feet of an intersection of a street, road, alley or driveway, dome-type traffic markers shall not be placed closer than six (6) inches to the nearest edge of the paved travelway. 
(2)  Railroad ties and solid curbing. As an alternate to dome markers, railroad ties and solid curbing may be used as means of protecting grass and other landscaping within aforementioned dedicated right-of-way areas. When used, these devices shall be securely fastened to the ground; their placement shall be dictated as follows: Where no curb and gutter system exists, railroad ties and solid curbing may not be placed closer than twelve (12) inches from the edge of the paved travelway, nor extend more than six (6) inches above its uppermost edge. 
(3)  Berming of swale area. Berming of swale areas may be used as a means of protecting and beautifying same. Where berming is opted for, a ratio of three (3) to one (1) shall be used; provided, however, that no berm shall exceed three (3) feet at its highest point. 
(b)  Submission of plans/obtaining permits for work within the dedicated right-of-way. 
(1)  City streets. In the event a property owner should choose alternative (2) above and/or (3) above, he shall submit a plan denoting proposed improvements of swale area to the department of community planning and development for its review. The department shall then approve in full, approve with modifications, or disapprove the proposed plan, based on aesthetics, safety factors, and any other applicable criteria. In addition, in every case, an indemnity agreement prepared by the city attorney's office in favor of the City of North Miami shall be signed by the property owner prior to obtaining a building permit. The department of community planning and development shall subsequently proceed with the permitting plan, accordingly. 
(2)  County/state roads. In the event a property owner should choose alternative (2) above and/or (3) above for implementation within county or state-dedicated rights-of-way, the owner shall submit the proposed improvement plan to the appropriate agency for its review and action, in addition to the procedures outlined above. 
(c)  Prohibited marker. It shall be unlawful to install or place within dedicated rights-of-way of the City of North Miami, such as swales, parkways and the like, any pyramid-type concrete traffic markers or other hard material markers, such as cinder blocks, steel- or iron-made devices, or other similar devices. 
(d)  Structures rendered nonconforming. Structures existing as of November 9, 1982, not in conformance with this section, but which are well maintained and which do not pose a danger of personal injury or property damage, shall not be found to be a violation of this Code; however, once such structures are removed, they must be replaced only by structures which conform to the terms of this section. 
(Code 1958, § 23-16.1) 
Secs. 17-23-17-45. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 17-46. - Damaging sidewalks-Prohibited. 
    Any person who shall injure or damage any sidewalk in the city shall repair or replace the same within thirty (30) days after notice given by the city at his own expense. 
(Code 1958, § 23-17) 
Sec. 17-47. - Same-Replacement and repair by city. 
    If the repair or replacement has not been done within the thirty-day period, as above set forth, then and in that event, the cost thereof shall be imposed or charged as a lien against the abutting property and collected as provided by law. 
(Code 1958, § 23-18) 
Sec. 17-48. - Sidewalk specifications. 
    The specifications for sidewalks in the city shall be as follows: 
(1)  Official elevations. The back of sidewalk elevations shall be shown on the plans and shall be not less than the street center elevations. Sidewalk elevations may exceed the street center elevations only with the approval of the city engineer. 
(Code 1958, § 23-20) 
Sec. 17-49. - Plans. 
    No sidewalk shall be constructed in the city unless and until a plan (or working drawing) for construction thereof has been approved by the city engineer. 
(Code 1958, § 23-21) 
Sec. 17-50. - Sidewalk construction mandatory. 
(a)  New subdivisions. Unless specifically waived by the city council in the resolution accepting and approving any particular plat, all persons, firms or corporations submitting any plat to the planning and planning commission for the subsequent acceptance and approval of the city council shall accompany such proposed plat with an agreement providing for the construction of sidewalks along the full length of all streets shown thereon. All sidewalks shall be included in the dedicatory provision set forth on the plat or in any separate dedicatory instrument to be filed therewith. Such agreement shall be accompanied by a surety bond in the penal sum of not less than one hundred ten (110) percent of the estimated cost of such construction. The agreement and bond shall be on forms approved by the city engineers and furnished by the city clerk. The condition of the bond shall be such that if the principal shall fully and faithfully perform all the terms and conditions of the principal's agreement and within the time therein specified, then same shall be void, otherwise the city shall have the right to construct such sidewalks, or, at its option, to cause the same to be constructed pursuant to public advertisement and receipt and acceptance of bids. The principal and surety jointly and severally shall agree to pay and indemnify the city, upon completion by the city, the final total cost of such construction, including, but not limited to, engineering, legal and contingent costs together with any damages, either direct or consequential, which the city may sustain on account of the failure of the principal to comply with the terms of such agreement. The agreement shall provide for the construction of sidewalks within six (6) months from and after the date of the approval of any such plat by the city council; provided, however, that the city council may, in case of unusual circumstances, extend the time for completion of such construction for not to exceed an additional six (6) months; provided, the principal first obtains and furnishes the city council with the surety's written consent to such extension. The agreement and performance bond for construction of sidewalks required by this section may be combined with the agreement and performance bond for construction of streets, alleys and other rights-of-way required by article I of this chapter. 
(b)  Old subdivisions. In old subdivisions or tracts of land not subdivided, no permit shall be issued for any construction in excess of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) unless and until the person, firm or corporation applying for the permit agrees to repair any unsafe sidewalk or, where no sidewalk exists, agrees to construct a sidewalk for the full footage abutting the public right-of-way, except alleys, as part of the permit sought or by entering into an agreement with the city providing for construction thereof except as to properties located in a block where sidewalks do not exist or are exempted by the city council after a public hearing. At corner lots or tracts such agreement shall require construction of a sidewalk along both thoroughfares abutting such corner lot or tract for which the permit is sought. The agreement shall provide, among other things, that before a certificate of occupancy will be issued, construction of the sidewalk shall be completed in accordance with the city specifications and in accordance with plans approved by the city engineer. Upon application of the owner of the property the council, in its sole discretion and for good cause shown, may authorized the issuance of a certificate of occupancy without construction and completion of such sidewalk upon the condition that the owner shall execute and deliver to the city clerk an agreement (together with the deposit as referred to therein and an amount sufficient to pay the cost of its recording) in form as follows: 
"AGREEMENT 
THESE PRESENTS WITNESS: That in consideration of the issuance by the City of North Miami, Florida of a certificate of occupancy for the following described premises: ___________ the undersigned as owner(s) thereof have deposited with the city, and the city hereby acknowledges receipt of the sum of $_____, which is an amount equivalent to one hundred ten (110) percent of the estimated cost of constructing a sidewalk along the full frontage width of said premises computed at a construction cost as computed by the city engineer. 
It is agreed that the city shall hold said sum in a special fund or account for a period not to exceed ten (10) years for the purpose of paying the cost of constructing and completing such sidewalk in accordance with the requirements and specifications of the City of North Miami, Florida, the city hereby reserving the option to cause such sidewalk to be constructed and completed within such period and at such time as in its sole discretion it is deemed proper so to do; provided, however, that the owner(s) or successors in title may at their election so construct and complete such sidewalk, in which event, upon application, the city will refund said deposit to the owner(s) or successors in title. If under its option the city causes such sidewalk to be constructed, it will pay the cost thereof out of the deposit and, upon application, will refund any excess to the owner(s) or successors in title. If at the expiration of ten (10) years the city has not exercised its option to construct and complete such sidewalk, it shall, upon application, refund the deposit to the owner(s) or successors in title. The written receipt of the person to whom any refund is made under the terms of this agreement shall constitute a full and complete discharge of any and all liability of the city to any and all persons. If the city, under its option, shall cause the sidewalk to be constructed and completed, and the cost thereof exceeds the amount of the deposit herein mentioned, the owner(s) or successors in title as the case may be, within ten (10) days after the mailing of a written demand therefor, shall pay such excess to the city and in the event of a failure so to do the city may assess and enforce a lien against the premises for the amount of such excess, with interest at the highest legal rate of interest allowed by law at the time of such lien per annum, it being agreed that any and all formalities, requirements of law or other conditions precedent to the making of such an assessment are hereby expressly waived. As used herein the term "owner(s)" means the person(s) who advanced the deposit herein mentioned. The term "successors in title" means the person(s) who, at the time referred to are shown as the owner(s) of the property on the tax roll of the city. This agreement is made by and for the owner(s) and ________ heirs, successors, personal representatives and assigns. 
IN WITNESS WHEREOF, the parties have caused this agreement to be executed this _____ day of ________, 19___.

(c)  Sidewalk not required in certain areas. In that portion of the city known as Sans Souci Estates Subdivision, Plat Book 50, Page 86, no construction of sidewalks in single-family residential areas designated as R-1 zoning shall be required. 
(d)  Improved property without sidewalks. Other than in that area described in subsection (c) hereof, the owner of any improved parcel or lot in North Miami shall provide a sidewalk in accordance with the requirements of this chapter, notwithstanding the failure of such owner to have provided a bond as required by this section. If the owner fails to complete construction of a sidewalk within thirty (30) days after notification by the city to do so, the city may provide such sidewalk in the same manner as provided for repairs in this Code. 
(Code 1958, § 23-22) 
Sec. 17-51. - Notice. 
    If the city exercises its option to construct a sidewalk in accordance with the foregoing agreement, the city manager shall cause written notice thereof to be sent to the property owner not less than ten (10) days prior to commencement of construction. The failure to give such notice shall not invalidate or in any way impair the city's lien afforded by the foregoing agreement or the property owner's obligation to pay for the sidewalk. Such notice shall specify the estimated cost of construction. If, within such ten-day period, the property owner obtains a commitment from a qualified contractor licensed in the city for construction of the sidewalk at a price less than the estimate specified in the notice, a contract for the work shall be awarded to such contractor. 
(Code 1958, § 23-23) 
Sec. 17-52. - Unlawful acts; grade permits; fees. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to construct any sidewalk that does not conform to the plans and specifications referred to in this Code, or to construct any sidewalk without first having obtained a grade permit therefor together with the payment of the grade permit fee as provided therein. 
(Code 1958, § 23-24) 
Sec. 17-53. - Duty of maintenance by abutting owners or occupants-Declared. 
    It is hereby declared and determined to be contrary to the public welfare, safety and property of the people of the city, and therefor unlawful and in violation of the provisions of this Code for any owner, occupant or agent of any property to which a sidewalk, walk or curb is contiguous, to allow such walk, sidewalk or curb to remain in such a condition as to be dangerous or detrimental to citizens on such property. Where a sidewalk or curb is in public right-of-way and in an unsafe condition, the property owner, occupant or agent thereof shall immediately notify the city by both written and verbal communications that such a condition exists. Upon investigation by the city that the condition was not caused by action of the owner, occupant or agent thereof, the city will make the necessary repairs at no cost to the owner, occupant or agent. 
(Code 1958, § 23-24.1) 
Sec. 17-54. - Same-Determination of dangerous condition and notification of abutting owner or occupant. 
(a)  Following a determination by the city manager, or his designee, that the surface of any walk or sidewalk in the city has become so uneven or broken as to make walking over it dangerous or detrimental, or if the curbing shall become decayed, worn out or broken so as to create a similar hazard, and where investigation has determined that such condition was caused by the property owner, occupant or agent thereof, it shall be the duty of the city manager, or his designee, to notify the owner or owners, and if the owner cannot be served, to notify the occupant and if there is no occupant, then to notify the agent of the owner of the property to which the sidewalk is contiguous, to repair such walk, sidewalk or curb. In the event that notice cannot be served on any of the above persons then notice shall be posted upon the property itself. 
(b)  Such notice shall be in writing and allow such owner, occupant or agent thirty (30) days in which to repair such walk, sidewalk or curb, shall describe the walk, sidewalk or curb to be repaired, and shall set forth that such walk, sidewalk or curb shall be repaired, if surface work is to be done, with the same material as such walk, sidewalk or curb was originally constructed, and if curbing is to be put in, with concrete; and shall be served a copy of such notice filed in the office of the city manager, or his designee. 
(Code 1958, § 23-24.2) 
Sec. 17-55. - Same-Duty of city manager to inspect; credits to owner or occupant if portions must be removed. 
    When it shall become necessary that a part of a walk, sidewalk or a curb must be replaced in the interest of the public welfare, it shall be the duty of the city manager, or his properly appointed representative, to investigate the condition of such walk, sidewalk, or curb, and if a part or parts thereof must be taken out in order to construct the complete walk, sidewalk or curb, the city manager or his appointed representative shall determine the value or equity remaining in the unbroken or undamaged portion of such walk, sidewalk or curb, and, upon approval of the city council, a credit of this amount shall be made to the abutting property owner in determining the amount of the assessment which he shall pay. 
(Code 1958, § 23-24.3) 
Sec. 17-56. - Same-Correction if owner or occupant fails. 
    In the event the owner or owners of such property shall, following the service of notice as provided in section 17-54, fail or refuse to correct the condition complained of, then and in such event the city manager, or his properly appointed department head, shall be and hereby is empowered and authorized to cause such condition to be corrected. For such purpose the city manager, or his properly appointed department head, and such persons as may be employed, may enter upon property to which such sidewalk, walk or curb is contiguous in order to effect the necessary repairs. 
(Code 1958, § 23-24.4) 
Sec. 17-57. - Same-Assessment of actual cost of repairs. 
    There is hereby levied and assessed against each and every property, the walk, sidewalk or curb contiguous to which is repaired pursuant to the provisions of section 17-56 hereof, the actual cost to the city to repair such property in the manner provided in section 17-54 hereof as a tax which shall be in addition to any and all other taxes levied and assessed against such property. Nothing herein contained, however, shall be construed as being an exclusive remedy, or in lieu of a fine or imprisonment of the person or persons found guilty of a violation of the provisions of sections 17-54 through 17-57. 
(Code 1958, § 23-24.5) 
Sec. 17-58. - Same-Penalty for failure to repair. 
    Any person who, following the service of notice as provided in section 17-54 hereof, fails or refuses to correct the condition complained of within the time allotted by the notice shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment of not more than sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Code 1958, § 23-24.6) 
Secs. 17-59-17-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - GRADE PERMITS 

Sec. 17-76. - Required; plans; bond; inspection. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to pave or construct any street, alley, right-of-way, sidewalk, curb or curb and gutter in the city without first having obtained a grade permit for such construction. 
(b)  The applicant for such permit shall submit three (3) sets of plans for review, comments and approval by the city engineer. Where restoration of public right-of-way is required, the city engineer may require a cash bond be posted equal to one hundred ten (110) percent of the cost of restoring the right-of-way. The cost shall be as determined by the city engineer. The applicant shall notify the public works department a minimum of forty eight (48) hours in advance of any construction. 
(c)  The contractor shall contact the public works department for final inspection of the work to ensure conformity to this Code. Prior to backfilling excavations that cross over or under sanitary sewer laterals or pipes, the contractor shall notify the public works department for inspection to ensure the pipes have not been damaged. 
(Code 1958, § 23-25) 
Sec. 17-77 - Contractor to furnish stakes, pins, labor. 
    The contractor shall furnish all stakes or pins and such ordinary labor as may be necessary for setting grades, and shall take the necessary steps to protect and care for the stakes after grade is set, and if any one (1) of the stakes is disturbed, the grade is to be reset at the contractor's expense. 
(Code 1958, § 23-27) 
Sec. 17-78. - Inspection. 
    After the grades are set and before actual construction is begun, the city engineer, upon notice from the contractor, shall inspect the grades as set, and if found to conform with the grades established therefor on the aforesaid maps, the city engineer shall so certify in the writing to the building inspector, whereupon the construction can proceed, otherwise it shall be unlawful for the contractor, his agents or servants to proceed with the construction until such conformance is had. 
(Code 1958, § 23-28) 
Sec. 17-79. - Nonconformity. 
    If, during the course of construction, the building inspector observes that the construction is not in conformity with the established lines and grades, the inspector shall have the right and power to stop the work, and it shall be unlawful for the contractor, his agents or servants to proceed with the construction unless or until the same is in conformity with the established lines or grades. 
(Code 1958, § 23-29) 
Sec. 17-80. - Fees. 
    The fees to be charged for grade permits are those set by the city council, as maintained on file in the city engineer's office. 
(Code 1958, § 23-30) 
Secs. 17-81-17-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DRIVEWAYS 

Sec. 17-96. - Requirements for placing of driveways. 
(a)  After September 1, 1973, driveways, serving other than properties zoned for single-family purposes, shall be placed at the time of the development of properties heretofore undeveloped unless specifically waived by the city council pursuant to resolution. 
(b)  Placement of a driveway where no driveway exists, and/or replacement or reconstruction of an existing driveway shall be as hereinafter provided. 
(Code 1958, § 23-31) 
Sec. 17-97. - Specifications. 
    The maximum square footage of impervious public right-of way area, allowed between the edge of the street paving and the front edge of the sidewalk, adjacent to commercial and residential property, shall be forty (40) percent of that total area. Residential lots less than forty (40) feet wide on the street frontage and commercial property may exceed this allowance subject to the property owner's agreeing to and providing for the installation and future maintenance of drainage facilities as approved by the city engineer. 
(Code 1958, § 23-32) 
Sec. 17-98. - Driveways for other than singled family residential properties. 
(a)  New driveways. 
(1)  A permit shall be obtained from the community planning and development department on forms provided by such department for the installation of all driveways. 
(2)  No certificate of occupancy shall be issued by the community planning and development department until driveway and/or driveways have been placed in accordance with the issuance of a driveway permit. 
(b)  Replacement of driveway. Prior to the replacement and/or reconstruction of existing driveway, a permit shall be obtained from the community planning and development department on forms provided by such department. 
(c)  Replacement of a portion of an existing driveway. Prior to the replacement and/or reconstruction of a portion of an existing driveway, a permit shall be obtained from the community planning and development department on forms provided by such department. Such replacement or reconstruction shall be of the same material as that used in the construction of the existing driveways. 
(Code 1958, § 23-33) 
Sec. 17-99. - Driveways for single-family residential properties. 
(a)  New driveways. Prior to the installation of asphaltic pavement or concrete driveways, a permit shall be obtained from the community planning and development department on forms provided by such department. 
(b)  Replacement of driveway. Prior to the replacement and/or reconstruction of an existing asphaltic pavement or concrete driveway, a permit shall be obtained from the community planning and development department on forms provided by such department 
(c)  Replacement of a portion of an existing drive way. Prior to the replacement and/or reconstruction of a portion of an existing asphaltic pavement or concrete driveway, a permit shall be obtained from the community planning and development department on forms provided by such department. Such replacement or reconstruction shall be of the same materials as that used on the construction of the existing driveway. 
(d)  Sodding in place of driveway. Where no driveway is to be provided, the area between the sidewalk and the nearest edge of street pavement, or where no sidewalk exists, from the property line to the nearest edge of street pavement, shall place sod, gravel or other approved surfaces in accordance with the provisions of article VI, Sodding Between Streets and Sidewalks, of this chapter. 
(Code 1958, § 23-33.1) 
Sec. 17-100. - Noncompliance with article provisions; penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to extend driveways that do not conform to the specifications referred to in this article. 
(b)  Any person who violates any provision of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-11 of this Code. 
(Code 1958, § 23-24) 
Secs. 17-101-17-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SODDING BETWEEN STREETS AND SIDEWALKS 

Sec. 17-116. - Required of persons building homes after certain date. 
    All persons constructing homes in the city shall be required to solid sod and the area between the sidewalk and the street as constructed. 
(Code 1958, § 23-36) 
Sec. 17-117. - Sodding specifications. 
    The planting of sod as required herein shall be in accordance with specifications prepared by the community planning and development department of the city and filed with the clerk of the city. 
(Code 1958, § 23-37) 
Sec. 17-118. - Sodding mandatory. 
New subdivisions. 
(1)  Hereafter, unless specifically waived by the city council in the resolution accepting and approving any particular plat, all persons, firms or corporations submitting any plat to the planning commission for the subsequent acceptance and approval of the city council, shall accompany such proposed plat with an agreement providing for the planting of sod and subsequent maintenance of same along the full length of all streets zoned thereon between the sidewalk and edge of the street to be constructed. Such agreement shall be accompanied by a surety bond in the penal sum of not less than one hundred ten (110) percent of the estimated cost of such planting; such agreement and bond shall be on forms approved by the city engineer and furnished by the city clerk. The condition of such bond shall be such that if the principal shall fully and faithfully perform all the terms and conditions of the principal's agreement and within the time therein specified, then the same shall be void, otherwise the city shall have the right to plant such sod or, at its option, cause the same to be planted pursuant to public advertisement and receipt and acceptance of bids. The principal and surety jointly and severally agree to pay and indemnify the city upon completion by the city the final total cost of such planting together with any damages either direct or consequential, which the city may sustain on account of the failure of the principal to comply with the terms of such agreement. 
(2)  The said agreement shall provide for the planting of sod within six (6) months from and after the date of the approval of any such plat by the city council; provided, however, that the city council may, in case of unusual circumstances, extend the time for completion of such planting or not to exceed an additional six (6) months; provided the principal first obtains and furnishes the city council with the surety's written consent of such extension. 
(3)  Sodding agreement and performance bond may be combined with sidewalk agreement and performance bond and street agreement and bond. The agreement and performance bond for laying of sod as herein required may be combined with the agreement and performance bond for construction of sidewalks, streets, alleys and other rights-of-way as required by articles II and III of this chapter. 
(b)  Old subdivisions. From and after February 24, 1959, no building permits shall be issued for the construction of any residential building unless and until the person, firm or corporation applying for such permit enters into an agreement with the city providing for the planting of sod and subsequent maintenance of same along the full frontage of the lot or tract for which the permit is sought between the constructed street and the sidewalk line. The agreement shall provide among other things, that before a certificate of occupancy will be issued, planting of the sod shall be completed in accordance with the specifications set forth in section 17-117 of this article. 
(Code 1958, § 23-38) 
Sec. 17-119. - Noncompliance with sod and grade specifications; penalty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to plant sod that does not conform to the specifications referred to in this article or to plant such sod at other than the grade approved for sidewalk under the provisions of section 17-48 et seq. 
(b)  Any person who violates any provision of this section shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-11. 
(Code 1958, § 23-39) 
Sec. 17-120. - Effective date and application of article provisions. 
    This article shall take effect upon its passage and adoption; provided, however, it shall not be applied to any person, firm or corporation who has applied, before such effective date, for an institutional construction loan which does not contemplate the planting of sod, and who presents to the city manager satisfactory evidence that such loan application was timely filed and was filed in good faith and not for the purpose of avoiding compliance with this article. 
(Code 1958, § 23-40) 
Secs. 17-121-17-199. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - TELECOMMUNICATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- All fees, charges and financial obligations previously accrued pursuant to any ordinances and resolutions repealed pursuant to this article shall continue to be due and owing until paid. 

Sec. 17-201. - Title. 
    This article shall be known and may be cited as the City of North Miami Telecommunications Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1072, § 1, 12-12-00) 
Sec. 17-202. - Intent and purpose. 
    It is the intent of the city to promote the public health, safety, and general welfare by providing for the use of the public rights-of-way within the city, to adopt and administer reasonable regulations consistent with state and federal law, including F.S. §§ 337.401, 362.01, and 337.29(3), and the City's home-rule authority in accordance with the provisions of the Telecommunications Act of 1996, to provide for the payment of compensation and other consideration by a telecommunications service provider to the city for the cost of regulating and maintaining the public rights-of-way and for the privilege of using the public rights-of-way within the city for constructing and maintaining telecommunications facilities, and to establish the reasonable regulations concerning the use of the public rights-of-way by all telecommunications service providers after the effective date of this article. In regulating its public rights-of-way, the city shall be governed by and shall comply with all applicable federal, state and local laws and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 1072, § 1, 12-12-00) 
Sec. 17-203. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and derivations shall have the meanings given. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future tense, words in the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number include the plural number. The words "shall" and "will" are mandatory, and "may" is permissive. Words not otherwise defined or in any permit that might be granted shall be given the meaning set forth in the Communications Act of 1934, 47 U.S.C. § 151 et seq., as amended (collectively the "Communications Act"), and, if not defined, as defined by Florida Statutes; and, if not defined therein, be construed to mean the common and ordinary meaning. 
    City shall mean the City of North Miami, an incorporated municipality of the State of Florida, in its present form or in any later reorganized, consolidated, or enlarged form. 
    Gross receipts shall mean all cash, credits or property of any kind or nature, with deductions for bad debt expense, reported as revenue items to the registrant's audited income statements arising from, or attributable to recurring local service revenues of registrant within the city. The city reserves the right to amend the definition contained herein as permitted by applicable law. The definition herein shall not be applicable as of October 1, 2001, or such other date as provided by law, provided that F.S. § 337.401, is amended effective October 1, 2001, as set forth in Chapter 00-260, Laws of Florida, 2000. 
    Law shall mean any local, state or federal legislative, judicial or administrative order, certificate, decision, statute, constitution, ordinance, resolution, regulation, rule, tariff, guideline or other requirements, as amended, now in effect or subsequently enacted or issued including, but not limited to, the Communications Act of 1934, 47 U.S.C. § 151 et seq. as amended by the Telecommunications Act of 1996, Pub. L. No. 104-104 § 101(a), 110 Stat. 70 codified at 47 U.S.C., and all orders, rules, tariffs, guidelines and regulations issued by the federal communications commission or the governing state authority pursuant thereto. 
    Person shall mean any individual, corporation, partnership, association, joint venture, organization or legal entity of any kind, and any lawful trustee, successor, assignee, transferee or personal representative, but shall not mean the city. 
    PSC shall mean the Florida Public Service Commission. 
    Public rights-of-way shall mean the surface, the airspace above the surface and the area below the surface of any public street, highway, road, boulevard, concourse, driveway, freeway, thoroughfare, parkway, sidewalk, bridge, tunnel, park, waterway, dock, bulkhead, wharf, pier, court, lane, path, alley, way, drive, circle, public easement, public place, or any other property in which the city holds any kind of property interest or over which the city exercises any type of lawful control and may lawfully grant access to pursuant to applicable law, but shall not include private property. "Public rights-of-way" shall not include any real or personal city property except as described above and shall not include city buildings, fixtures, and other structures or improvements, regardless of whether they are situated in the public rights-of-way. 
    Recurring local service revenues shall mean revenues from the monthly recurring charges for local service, including but not limited to (1) recurring basic area revenues derived from the provision of flat-rated basic area services; (2) recurring optional extended area revenues derived from the provision of optional extended area services; (3) local private line revenues derived from local services which provide communication between specific locations, either through dedicated circuits, private switching arrangements, predefined transmission paths, whether virtual or physical, or any other method of providing such services; (4) revenues from the sale of local services for resale; and (5) other local service revenues from the provision of secondary features that are integrated with the telecommunications network, including, without limitation, services such as call forwarding, call waiting, and touchtone line service. Except as provided herein, revenues from all recurring local services provided by a registrant over a telecommunications facility or system in the public rights-of-way shall constitute recurring local service revenues subject to this article. Recurring local service revenues do not include revenues from (1) toll charges for the transmission of voice, data, video, or other information; (2) access charges paid by carriers for origination and/or termination of toll telephone service as defined in F.S. § 203.012(7), or other charges required by the federal communications commission which are directly passed through to end users; (3) interstate service; (4) ancillary services such as directory advertising, directory assistance, detailed billing services, inside wire maintenance plans, bad check charges, and non-recurring charges for installation, move, changes or termination services; (5) cellular mobile telephone or telecommunications services; or specialized mobile telephone or telecommunications service; or specialized mobile radio, or pagers or paging service, or related ancillary services; (6) public telephone charges collected on site; (7) teletypewriter or computer exchange services as defined in F.S. § 203.012(6); or (8) local message rated (message, unit or time basis) and minutes of use charges in excess of the minimum flat-rated charges for similar services. This definition shall not be applicable as of October 1, 2001, or such other date as provided by law, provided that F.S. § 337.401, is amended effective October 1, 2001, as set forth in Chapter 00-260, Laws of Florida, 2000. 
    Registrant or "facility owner shall mean a telecommunications company that has registered with the city in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
    Registration and register shall mean the process described in section 17-204 whereby a telecommunications service provider provides certain information to the city. 
    Telecommunications company shall have the meaning set forth in F.S. § 364.02(12), as amended. The term "telecommunications company" does not include an open video system or cable services provider. 
    Telecommunications service shall include, without limitation, local service, toll service as defined in F.S. § 203.012(7), telegram or telegraph service, teletypewriter service, private communication service as defined in F.S. § 203.012(4), or any other provision of two-way communications services to the public for hire. "Telecommunications service," as contemplated herein, does not include the provision of service via an open video system, or cable services which shall require separate authorizations from the city. 
    Telecommunications service provider shall refer to any person providing telecommunications services, as defined herein, through the use of a telecommunications facility. 
    Telecommunications facilities, facilities or systems means cables, conduits, converters, splice boxes, cabinets, handholes, manholes, vaults, equipment, drains, surface location markers, appurtenances, and related facilities located, to be located, used, or to be used, by a telecommunications service provider in the public rights-of-way of the city and used or useful for the transmission of telecommunications services. 
(Ord. No. 1072, § 1, 12-12-00) 
Sec. 17-204. - Registration. 
(a)  Each telecommunications service provider that desires to erect, construct, install, maintain, repair, expand, or use any telecommunications facilities in, or under, public right-of-way in the city shall first register with the city in accordance with the terms of this article. As to toll service providers, such registration shall be accepted by the city as a resolution of the city council. 
(b)  Any telecommunications service provider desiring to use the public right-of-way shall file a registration with the city which shall include the following information: 
(1)  Identity of the applicant and name, address and telephone number of applicant's primary contact person in connection with the registration; 
(2)  A statement of whether the applicant is or expects to be a local service provider and/or a toll service provider; 
(3)  Evidence of the insurance coverage required under this article and acknowledgment that registrant has received and reviewed a copy of this article, which acknowledgment shall not be deemed an agreement; 
(4)  A copy of federal and/or state certification authorizing the applicant to provide telecommunications services; 
(5)  A security fund in accordance with section 17-214 of this article. 
(c)  The city will review the information submitted by the applicant. Such review will be by the city manager or a designee. If the applicant submits information in accordance with subsection (b) above, the registration shall be effective and the city shall notify the applicant of the effectiveness of registration in writing. If the city determines that the information has not been submitted in accordance with section (b) above, the city shall notify the applicant of the non-effectiveness of registration, and reasons for the non-effectiveness, in writing. The city shall so reply to an applicant within thirty (30) days after receipt of registration information from the applicant. A registrant may cancel a registration upon written notice to the city noticing that it will no longer provide local service or toll service using public rights-of-way within the city and will no longer need to pull permits to perform work in the public right-of-way. 
(d)  A registration shall not convey title, equitable or legal, in the public right-of-way. Registrants may only occupy public rights-of-way for telecommunications facilities. Registration does not excuse a telecommunications service provider from obtaining appropriate access or pole attachment before locating its facilities on another person's facilities. Registration does not excuse a provider from complying with all applicable city ordinances, including this article. 
(e)  Each application for registration, transfer or renewal shall be accompanied by a non-refundable application fee in the amount of eight hundred dollars ($800.00). The fee amount shall be equal to the city's costs and expenses incurred in connection with approving the registration, transfer or renewal. If the application fee is insufficient to cover all costs or expenses incurred by the city in connection with approval of the registration, transfer or renewal, the applicant shall reimburse the city for any such costs and expenses in excess of the application fee. Fee amounts, may be amended from time to time, by resolution of the city council. This application fee may be credited against fees due under section 17-205. 
(f)  Registration with the city shall be nonexclusive. Registration does not establish any priority for the use of the public right-of-way by a registrant or any other registrants. Registrations are expressly subject to any future amendment to or replacement of this article and further subject to any additional city ordinances, as well as any state or federal laws that may be enacted during the term of the registration. 
(Ord. No. 1072, § 1, 12-12-00) 
Sec. 17-205. - Fees and payments. 
(a)  In consideration for the rights, privileges and permission granted hereunder, a registrant shall pay to the city a sum equal to one (1) percent of gross receipts of the registrant on recurring local service revenues for services provided within the corporate limits of the city. Included within such one (1) percent maximum fee or consideration are all taxes, licenses, fees, in-kind contributions accepted pursuant to F.S. § 337.401(5), and other impositions except ad valorem taxes and amounts for assessments for special benefits, such as sidewalks, street pavings, and similar improvements, and local business taxes levied or imposed by the city upon a registrant. In the event that applicable law currently permits or is amended to permit the city to collect a fee higher than one (1) percent, or permits the city to calculate the fee on revenues not specified herein, the registrant agrees to increase, following written notice from the city, its fee payments to the city to that higher amount on the effective date of such law. In the event applicable law is amended to require the city to collect a fee lower than the current statutory limit, the city shall take all necessary steps to conform the requirements hereof to applicable law. All of the afore stated payments shall be made to the city quarterly, with such payments made within twenty (20) days following the end of each calendar quarter. Payments received after the 21st day shall be subject to interest at the maximum allowed by law, and late charges of one and one-half (11/2) percent per month. 
(b)  In the event a telecommunications company provides telecommunications services defined as toll services in F.S. § 203.012(7), or other services, as a condition for granting permission to occupy or use the public rights-of-way of the city, the registrant shall pay to the city annually no less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per linear mile of any cable, fiber optic, or other pathway that makes physical use of the public rights-of-way. The city may adopt additional fees or other consideration, provided that any fee or other consideration imposed by the city in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per linear mile shall be applied in a nondiscriminatory manner and shall not exceed the sum of: 
(1)  Costs directly related to the inconvenience or impairment solely caused by the disturbance of the public rights-of-way; 
(2)  The reasonable cost of the regulatory activity of the city; and 
(3)  The proportionate share of cost of land for such street, alley or other public way attributable to utilization of the public rights-of-way by a telecommunications service provider. 
The fee or other consideration imposed pursuant to this subsection shall not apply in any manner to any telecommunications company which provides telecommunications services as defined in F.S. § 203.012(3), for any services provided by such telecommunications company. 
(c)  Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, the city shall at all times require the maximum compensation allowed under applicable law. 
(d)  Except to the extent prohibited by applicable law: (1) the fee payments to be made pursuant to this section shall not be deemed to be in the nature of a tax; (2) such fee payments shall be in addition to any and all taxes of a general applicability; (3) a registrant shall not have or make any claim for any deduction or other credit of all or any part of the amount of the fee payments from or against any of city taxes or other fees or charges of general applicability which a registrant is required to pay to the city, except as required by law; and (4) the fee specified herein is consideration for use of the public rights-of-way, including all public easements, for the purpose of installing and maintaining a telecommunications facility. 
(e)  Registrant shall not enter into any transaction or arrangement which has the effect of circumventing payment of required fees and/or evasion of payment of fees by non-collection, non-reporting of gross receipts, collection of revenues by its parent, affiliates or subsidiaries, bartering or any other means which evade the actual collection of revenues subject to the fee by registrant. 
(f)  The payments required under this section shall not apply as of October 1, 2001, or such other date as provided by law, provided that F.S. § 337.401, is amended effective October 1, 2001, as set forth in Chapter 00-260, Laws of Florida, 2000. 
(Ord. No. 1072, § 1, 12-12-00; Ord. No. 1229, § 1, 5-23-07) 
Sec. 17-206. - Reports and records. 
(a)  The city may, at its option, upon sixty (60) days notice to the registrant, but in no event more often than once per year, examine the records and accounting files, and such other books and records, if such records relate to the calculation of fee payments or any other payments due to the city under the terms of this article. The examination of such books, accounts, records or other materials necessary for determination of compliance with the terms, provisions, and requirements of this article shall be during regular hours of business of the registrant at an office of the registrant located within Miami-Dade County, or at another location satisfactory to the city. In the event that the city, pursuant to an audit, determines that there exists a discrepancy in the amount paid and the amount owed to the city by the registrant in excess of two (2) percent, registrant shall pay all costs, fees and expenses of the audit. Registrant shall pay interest at the rate of twelve (12) percent per annum on the amount underpaid or not paid calculated from the date the amount was due through to the date it was finally paid. Both the underpayment and interest, and payment of any costs, fees and expenses hereunder, shall be paid within thirty (30) days after receipt of demand from the city. This section shall not apply for periods after October 1, 2001, or such other date as provided by law, provided that F.S. § 337.401, is amended effective October 1, 2001, as set forth in Chapter 00-260, Laws of Florida, 2000. 
(b)  Upon request, a registrant shall provide the following documents to the city as received or filed: 
(1)  Any pleadings, petitions, notices, applications, communications, reports and documents, which may directly impact the obligations under this article and which are reasonably necessary for the city to protect its interests under this article; 
(2)  Any request for protection under bankruptcy laws, or any judgment related to a declaration of bankruptcy; 
(c)  In addition, the city may, at its option, and upon reasonable notice to the registrant, inspect the facilities in the public rights-of-way to ensure the safety of its residents; 
(d)  The city shall keep any documentation, books and records of the registrant confidential to the extent required under Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 1072, § 1, 12-12-00) 
Sec. 17-207. - Underground installation; relocation. 
(a)  To the extent required by section 19-1 of the City Code and not inconsistent with applicable FPSC rules and regulations, a registrant shall install its facilities underground. 
(b)  Every registrant which places or constructs telecommunications facilities underground shall maintain appropriate participation in the regional notification center for subsurface installations. 
(c)  Any telecommunications facilities heretofore or hereafter placed under any public rights-of-way that is found by the city to be unreasonably interfering in any way with the convenient, safe or continuous use or the maintenance, improvement, extension or expansion of such public rights-of-way shall, upon thirty (30) days written notice to the registrant or its agent, be removed or relocated by such registrant at its own expense except as explicitly provided under F.S. 337.403. The city manager may waive or extend the time within which a registrant shall remove or relocate a telecommunications facility, for good cause shown. 
(d)  The registrant shall not in any way displace, damage, or destroy any sewer, water main, pipe or any other facilities belonging to the city, or to any third party who placed such facilities therein by express authority of the city and in compliance with all of the requirements which accompany such express authority. The registrant shall be liable to the city for the costs of any repairs made necessary by any such displacement, damage or destruction of facilities belonging to the city, and the registrant shall pay such costs upon demand. In the case of an emergency, the city may commence repairs without any prior notice to the registrant. The term emergency shall mean a condition that may affect the public's health, safety or welfare. In the event of an emergency the city may cause the repairs to be made at the registrant's expense, utilizing city employees, agents or contractors, charge any and all costs, plus a sum equal to ten (10) percent of the cost against the registrant, and require reimbursement within thirty (30) days after the submission of the bill by the city to the registrant. Rates for labor and equipment shall be in accordance with City of North Miami Administrative Regulation 1-23, as amended. In all other non-emergency circumstances, the registrant shall be given prior written notice. If such repairs are not performed in a reasonable and satisfactory manner within the thirty (30) calendar days after receiving notice, the city may, cause the repairs to be made at the facility's owner expense, utilizing city employees, agents or contractors, charge any and all costs, plus a sum equal to ten (10) percent of the cost against the registrant, and require reimbursement within thirty (30) days after the submission of the bill by the city to the registrant. Rates for labor and equipment shall be in accordance with City of North Miami Administrative Regulation 1-23, as amended. 
(e)  Subject to F.S. 337.403, whenever an order of the city requires such removal or change in the location of any telecommunications facility from the public rights-of-way, and the facility owner fails to remove or change the same at its own expense to conform to the order within the time stated in the notice, the city may proceed to cause the telecommunications facility to be removed. The expense incurred, except as provided in [F.S.] § 337.403(1)(a)-(c), shall be paid out of any money available, and such expense shall be charged against the owner of the telecommunications facility and levied, collected and paid to the city. 
(f)  Subject to F.S. § 337.403, whenever it shall be necessary for the city to remove or relocate any telecommunications facility, the owner of the telecommunications facility, or the owner's chief agent, shall be given written notice of such removal or relocation and an order requiring the payment of the costs thereof, and shall be given reasonable time, which shall not be less than twenty (20) nor more than thirty (30) days in which to file an appeal with the city manager to contest the reasonableness of the order. Upon receipt of a written appeal, the city manager shall place the matter on a council agenda for consideration within forty-five (45) working days. Should the owner or the owner's representative not appear the determination of the cost to the owner shall be final, in accordance with F.S. § 337.404. 
(g)  A final order of the city imposed pursuant to Florida Statutes, and applicable provisions of the City Code, if any, shall constitute a lien on any property of the owner and may be enforced as provided therein. 
(h)  The city retains the right and privilege to cut or move any facilities located within the public rights-of-way of the city, as the city manager in the exercise of reasonable discretion may determine to be necessary or appropriate in response to any public health or safety emergency. If circumstances permit, the city shall attempt to notify the owner of the facility, if known, prior to cutting or removing a facility and shall notify the owner of the facility, if known, after cutting or removing a facility. 
(i)  Upon cessation of all use of a facility within the public rights-of-way of the city, the owner of the facility shall notify the city within ninety (90) days. Following receipt of such notice, the city may direct the facility owner to remove all or any portion of the facility if the city determines that such removal will be in the best interest of the public health, safety and welfare. In the event that the city does not direct the removal of the abandoned facility by the owner of the facility, such owner, by its notice of cessation of all use to the city, shall be deemed to consent to the alteration or removal of all or any portion of the facility by the city, another utility or person. 
(j)  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary, a facility owner agrees to provide the city, within thirty (30) days of filing or receipt of such, any document that may prevent compliance with the requirements of a permit in connection with the installation, construction or maintenance of its facilities, or use of facilities in the public right-of-way. This obligation shall only extend to such work in the public right-of-way for which a facility owner has applied for, or obtained a permit from the city. 
(Ord. No. 1072, § 1, 12-12-00) 
Sec. 17-208. - Use of rights-of-way. 
(a)  A facility owner agrees at all times to comply with and abide by all applicable provisions of the state statutes and local laws including, but not limited to, applicable zoning regulations not inconsistent with state and federal laws. 
(b)  Except in the case of an emergency, which shall include without limitation an out of service condition affecting 911 service, and which shall require subsequent notification to the city, no telecommunications service provider shall construct any facility under or within any public right-of-way which disrupts the public rights-of-way without first filing an application with and obtaining a permit from the city, pursuant to applicable permitting requirements of the city except as otherwise provided in this article. In case of the repair or maintenance of an existing facility, the city may impose lesser requirements than those set forth herein. Unless otherwise required by the City Code, no permit shall be required for installation and maintenance of service connections to customers' premises where there will be no disruption of the public rights-of-way. 
(c)  As part of any permit application, the facility owner shall provide a proposal for construction of the telecommunications facility that sets forth at least the following: 
(1)  The location of the proposed facility, including a description of the feet of plant to be installed, where it is to be located, and the approximate size of facilities and equipment that will be located in the public rights-of-way.
