Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 1311, adopted Nov. 14, 2010, changed the title of § 19-98 from "Water supply impact fees" to "Water and sewer capacity fees." 
Sec. 19-99. - Fire flow demand charge. 
(a)  A fire flow demand charge is established to facilitate the expansion and upgrading of the water facilities for the fire flow system of the water service area of the city. 
(b)  The charge shall be paid to the city prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy or within thirty (30) days of demand by the city. Where a building permit is issued to replace an existing building which has previously paid a fire flow demand charge, the fee for the new building shall be adjusted to reflect this previous charge. 
(c)  The fire flow demand charge shall be fifty cents ($0.50) per gross square foot of floor area for new buildings, conversions of or additions to existing buildings that require two thousand (2,000) gallons per minute or less fire flow rate as set forth in section 2-103.21 of the Metropolitan Dade County Code, or as the same may hereafter be amended. Developers of projects with one hundred thousand (100,000) square feet or more of building area may apply for approval of a lower rate. 
(d)  The fire flow demand charge shall be one dollar ($1.00) per gross square foot of floor area for all new buildings and conversions of or additions to existing buildings that require greater than two thousand (2,000) gallons per minute as set forth in section 2-103.21 of the Metropolitan Dade County Code, or as the same may hereafter be amended. Developers of projects with fifty thousand (50,000) square feet or more of building area may apply for approval of a lower rate. 
(e)  A conversion shall be defined as a change in the existing building to a use requiring a higher degree fire protection as determined by the city engineer. 
(f)  Specifically exempted from payment of a charge shall be a structure requiring a fire flow rate of less than one thousand (1,000) gallons per minute and parking garages under three (3) stories. 
(g)  Where water main extensions including fire hydrants are needed to meet the requirements of section 2-103.21 of the Metropolitan Dade County Code, or as the same may hereafter be amended, the fire flow demand charge shall be reduced by the cost of the improvements when constructed by the developer in accordance with law. Where the cost of such improvements exceed the fire flow demand charge, the developer shall fund the entire cost with no participation by the city. 
(h)  The computation of the gross square foot area shall be made from the exterior dimensions, including all columns, stairways, hallways and vestibules. 
(i)  All monies collected shall be held in a fire flow demand fund account. 
(j)  The allocation of funds may be made for any water system capital improvement project including fire hydrants, to correct fire flow system deficiencies, as approved by the Dade County Fire Department and the City Council of North Miami. 
(k)  This section shall apply to buildings to be constructed or converted under a building permit issued after May 25, 1984, unless a prior water service-agreement for such building or conversion existed prior to this date. 
(Code 1958, § 28-11) 
Sec. 19-100. - Inspection of new facilities. 
(a)  Where water facilities are installed by other than city employees, the work shall be inspected and certified to ensure compliance with all federal, state, county and city requirements. The city shall perform the following mandatory inspections at the listed fees: 
(1)  Connection to existing water main, each ..... $25.00 
Reinspection, each ..... 10.00 
(2)  Pressure test water main extension, each ..... 100.00 
Reinspection, each ..... 50.00 
(b)  The contractor may elect to use a professional registered engineer or a city approved technician to certify other mandatory inspections or may utilize the city forces at the following schedule: 
(1)  Backflow certification other than lawn sprinklers, each ..... $100.00 
Reinspection, each ..... 50.00 
(2)  Backflow certification for lawn sprinkler systems, each ..... 25.00 
(3)  Field inspection to certify compliance to specifications, per hour for a period as determined by the city ..... 35.00 
(c)  All costs are based on normal working hours of city employees and other hours of service will result in increased fees. All fees must be paid prior to the work being performed unless otherwise approved by the director of public works. The contractor shall pay for all laboratory testing as may be required by regulatory agencies. 
(Code 1958, § 28-32) 
Sec. 19-101. - Discontinuance of service for failure to pay water or sewerage bills. 
    The water and sewer department is hereby authorized and empowered to interrupt and discontinue its water and sewerage services to any user thereof upon the subject user's failure to pay either the water or sewerage charges, or both, so long as such water or sewerage charges shall remain unpaid, as provided by law. 
(Code 1958, § 28-13) 
Sec. 19-102. - Private fire service protection. 
(a)  The charges or rates for special private fire service based upon the size of the connection with the water department's distributing system thereof, are as follows: 
Per month 
4-inch private fire service connection ..... $15.00 
6-inch private fire service connection ..... 18.00 
8-inch private fire service connection ..... 25.00 
(b)  The cost of the installation of private fire service is to be paid for by the owner at actual cost plus ten (10) percent. 
(c)  The water department shall install fire line connections into a building up to the property line upon the owner signing a regular form of contract containing the following conditions: 
(1)  This connection is to be used for fire purposes only and is to have no connection whatsoever with any taps that may be used for other than fire purposes. And because of the danger of pollution shall have no connection with any other source of supply with the exception in case a tank or fire pump is installed as secondary supply. There shall be a check valve installed in each city connection to prevent the water from these secondary supplies running back into the city mains. 
(2)  The owner shall not draw any water what ever through this connection for any purpose except the extinguishment of fires, or for periodic tests of the fire system, which tests shall be made in the presence of a representative of the water department. 
(3)  Any authorized representative of the water department shall have free access to the buildings at any reasonable time for the purpose of inspecting any equipment of the water department. 
(4)  At some future date when convenient with the water department, and if and in the event the water department so desires and instructs such owner, the owner shall set in this connection at the line dividing the property of the owner and the street or alley, a weighted check valve, which check valve shall be satisfactory to the insurance companies, and also to the water department; such check valve shall be fitted with a bypass, on which shall be set a meter, the purpose of which shall be to indicate whether or not water is being used through this connection, and for the further purpose of showing any leakage, if same exists. 
(5)  Violation by the owner of any of the provisions in this section shall terminate the contract, disconnect pipe or pipes, or stop the flow of water through same. 
(6)  The right is reserved by the water department to shut off the supply at any time in case of accident, or to make alterations, extensions, connections or repairs and if possible the water department agrees to give due and ample notice of shutoff. 
(7)  The water department shall not make any guarantee as to a certain pressure in this pipe or in the main supplying the same, and shall not be under any circumstances, held liable for loss or damage to the owner for a deficiency or failure in the supply of water, whether occasioned by shutting off water in case of accident or alterations, extensions, connections or repairs, or for any cause whatsoever. 
(8)  When fire line valves or connections are used in case of fire or for any other reason whatsoever, the owner shall immediately notify the water department and the water department shall forthwith reseal the used valves or connections. 
(Code 1958, § 28-14; Ord. No. 881, § 7, 9-24-92) 
Sec. 19-103. - Application for service; binding contract; cancellation of application. 
(a)  All applications for water supply service must be made at the office of the water department in the city, on a blank prepared by the water department for that purpose. 
(b)  The owner or owners of the premises proposed to be connected for water supply service, or his or their agents thereunto duly authorized in writing, must sign the application for service pipe and water supply, except as hereinafter provided. 
(c)  Such application becomes a binding contract upon both the owner and the water department when the service connection for water supply service applied for has been installed and completed. Prior to the installation and completion of such service connection, the owner may cancel or withdraw the application made, upon his written order so to do, after payment to the water department of the actual expense not less than one dollar ($1.00) incurred by the water department in connection therewith. 
(Code 1958, § 28-15) 
Sec. 19-104. - Term of contract for water service. 
    All contracts for water supply service shall expire at the end of the next succeeding calendar month from date of application, but all contracts shall continue in force by renewal without act or notice from either party to the other, from month to month, unless ten (10) days' notice in writing is given by either party to the other of a desire to terminate the contract at the expiration of the then calendar month, and the charging for and payment of water rates or rents weekly, or in a manner, and at any interval or period, other than monthly, shall not be construed as altering the period of the contract or any renewal thereof under this section. 
(Code 1958, § 28-16) 
Sec. 19-105. - Change of ownership or occupancy of premises. 
    In the event of any change in ownership or occupancy of any premises connected to the system, the water department shall be immediately notified in writing of such change, giving in such notice the name and address of the new owner or occupant. In the absence of such application by such new owner or occupant, the use of the water department service may, at the option of the water department, be taken and construed to be an acceptance by such new owner or occupant of all the contract obligations of the preceding owner with and to the water department. In the event any owner fails to notify the water department in writing of a change in ownership or occupancy of any premises for water supply service, such owner shall continue to be liable to the water department for all rates and charges accrued and accruing for such service until either the end of the contract period, in which he may later notify the water department of his desire to cancel, or the water department shall, of its own volition, have cancelled the contract with the owner, but this clause shall not preclude the water department from also demanding from the new owner or occupant the payment of all or any charges and rates which shall, at the time of such demand, be unpaid or unsecured, without regard to whether the same accrued prior or subsequent to such change in ownership or occupancy. Upon failure of such new owner to comply with such demand within twenty-four (24) hours after written notice thereof, the water department shall have the right to shut off the water supply and discontinue its service. In no case of change of ownership shall the preceding owner or owners be released from any contract obligations to and with the water department until the expiration of the contract period, properly terminated in accordance with this chapter except at the option of the water department, evidenced by a written release from the water department. 
(Code 1958, § 28-17) 
Sec. 19-106. - Date charges commence. 
    When application for water supply service is made, the service together with the charges and rates therefor, shall begin on the date of the completion of the service connection by the water department, unless the owner shall state in writing in the application that such service connection shall be shut off immediately upon its installation in which even the said connection shall be shut off, and shall thereafter be turned on by the water department only upon the request, in writing, of the owner and the charges and rates for water supply service shall commence from date of such turn-on in accordance with this chapter in every respect as though such turn-on request had been an original application. Whenever, in a case as hereinabove provided, there shall have been a change in ownership prior to the turn-on of the service connection, the new owner must sign the application for water supply upon the regular form. 
(Code 1958, § 28-18) 
Sec. 19-107. - Grounds for cancellation and discontinuation of service. 
    All contracts shall be subject to cancellation and service thereunder discontinued by the water department: 
(1)  For misrepresentations or concealment in the application as to the premises, of fixtures to be furnished with water supply service, or the use to be made of such service. 
(2)  For waste or excessive use of water through improper or imperfect pipes, fixtures, or appliances, or in any other manner. 
(3)  For refusal or neglect to make any advance payment, if such is required by the water department, or for refusal or neglect to comply with any requirement of the water department as to meter or service connection maintenance, alteration or renewal or other requirement relating to the water supply service of the water department. 
(4)  For the use of water supply service for or in connection with or for the benefit of any other premises or purpose than that in the application. 
(5)  For any interference or tampering, whether by act of commission or omission, with the meter measuring the water supply, or with seals of any meter, or with any meter box or vault, or with service pipes, or valves of any seals thereon, or with the curb stopcock, or with any appliance of the water department or with any appliance of the owner, which was or is required by the water department for controlling or regulating the water supply service, and for the purpose of this section, and interference or tampering with any appliance used in connection with or for controlling or regulating the water supply service to any premises, shall be construed and taken to be the act of the owners or consumers using water service at the premises. 
(6)  In case of continued vacancy of the premises. 
(7)  For violation of any rule of the water department. 
(8)  Where there has been a change in ownership of the premises, but no application from the new owner or owners has been made and approved by the water department. 
(9)  Where there has been a discontinuance of the use of water or the service of the water department. 
(10)  Where the contract has been in any way terminated by the owner. 
(11)  Where any owner or consumer refuses or neglects payment of bill, account or charge, by whomsoever incurred, for or on account of the premises where such water supply is furnished. 
(12)  Where the water department has been or is being defrauded in any way. 
(Code 1958, § 28-19) 
DIVISION 5. - WATER SHORTAGE REGULATIONS 

Sec. 19-108. - Intent and purpose. 
    It is the intent and purpose of this division to protect the water resources of the city from the harmful effects of over-utilization during periods of water shortage or water shortage emergencies and allocate available water supplies by assisting the South Florida Water Management District in the implementation of its water shortage plan. A regulatory framework is hereby established to ensure that water conservation will be consistent throughout the city. 
(Ord. No. 1224, § 1, 5-23-07) 
Sec. 19-109. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this ordinance, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    District means the South Florida Water Management District. 
    Person means any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind, or other legal entity, whether public or private, for profit or not-for-profit. 
    Water resources means any and all water on or beneath the surface of the ground, including natural or artificial watercourses and canals, lakes, ponds, or diffused surface water, and water percolating, standing, or flowing beneath the surface of the ground. This includes, but is not limited to, any system, whether privately owned or publicly owned, that uses groundwater water or interconnected surface waters for a water source. 
    Water shortage or water shortage emergency is the declaration of such by the South Florida Water Management District pursuant to F.S. ch. 373 and Chapter 40E-21, F.A.C. 
(Ord. No. 1224, § 1, 5-23-07) 
Sec. 19-110. - Application. 
    The provisions of this division shall apply to all persons using the water resources within the geographical areas of the city subject to water shortage or water shortage emergency as determined by the district, whether from public or privately owned water utility systems, private wells, or private connections with surface water bodies. 
(Ord. No. 1224, § 1, 5-23-07) 
Sec. 19-111. - Declaration of water shortage; water shortage emergency. 
(a)  The declaration of a water shortage or water shortage emergency within all or any part of the city by the district shall invoke the provisions of this division. Upon such declaration, all water use restrictions or other measures adopted by the district applicable to the city, or any portion thereof, shall be subject to enforcement action pursuant to this division. Any violation of the provisions of Chapter 40E-21, F.A.C., as may be amended from time to time, or any order issued pursuant thereto, shall be a violation of this division. 
(b)  The provisions of this regulation shall remain in effect during water shortages or water shortage emergencies as declared by the district pursuant to F.S. ch. 373. At all other times when such water shortage or water shortage emergency does not exist, the provisions of this regulation shall not be in effect. 
(Ord. No. 1224, § 1, 5-23-07) 
Sec. 19-112. - Enforcement. 
    Every police officer and code enforcement officer shall, in connection with all other duties imposed by law, be authorized and empowered to enforce the provisions of this division in accordance with state and local laws. Code enforcement officers may issue citations or civil violation tickets to any person violating the provisions of this division, pursuant to chapter 2 of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 1224, § 1, 5-23-07) 
Sec. 19-113. - Penalties. 
(a)  Violation of any provision of this division shall be subject to the following penalties: 
(1)  First violation, fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(2)  Second violation, one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(3)  Any individual who has been convicted of a violation of this division three (3) or more times, during the same water shortage or water shortage emergency, upon conviction of each offense after the second violation, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment not to exceed sixty (60) days in the Miami-Dade County Jail or both, pursuant to a court order for each offense after the second such violation. 
(b)  Each day in violation of this division shall constitute a separate offense. In the initial stages of a water shortage or water shortage emergency, law enforcement officials and code enforcement officers may provide violators with no more than one (1) written warning. The city, in addition to the criminal sanctions contained in this division, may take any other appropriate legal action, including but not limited to emergency injunctive action, to enforce the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 1224, § 1, 5-23-07) 
Sec. 19-114. - Water users to accept provisions of division. 
    No water service shall be furnished to any person by a public or private utility unless such person agrees to accept all the provisions of this division. The acceptance of water service shall be in itself the acceptance of the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 1224, § 1, 5-23-07) 
Sec. 19-115. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SEWERS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Public service tax levied, § 18-21 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 19-116. - Septic tanks prohibited when sewer service is available; temporary use of septic tanks permitted. 
    When sewer service is available to property, the disposal of sanitary sewage by the use of septic tanks is prohibited in the City of North Miami, and no building permit or certificate of occupancy shall be issued for any structure utilizing a septic tank for the disposal of sanitary sewage. When sewer service is not available, septic tanks may be temporarily utilized, subject to approval of all appropriate governmental agencies and subject to the regulations set out in section 19-215. 
(Code 1958, § 28-42) 
Secs. 19-117-19-131. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SEWER USE REGULATIONS 

Sec. 19-132. - Regulation of discharges. 
(a)  Purpose. It is the purpose of this section to establish rules and regulations concerning discharges to the system, including the determination of the acceptability or unacceptability of discharges; the pretreatment of discharges; and establishing specific limitations on certain discharges. 
(b)  Access to premises for inspection of discharge; inspection chamber may be required. The public works director or his designated representative shall at all times have free access to the premises of any user of its facilities, and free access to the premises of any person reasonably believed by the public works director to be a user or possible user of its facilities, for the purpose of inspecting, sampling or testing the discharge emanating therefrom, or any discharge which may emanate therefrom in order to determine whether such discharge, or potential discharge, is acceptable or unacceptable to the utility. Where necessary, the public works director may require the owner of any premises which discharges to the system to install a suitable inspection chamber together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the discharge or potential discharge. Such chambers, when required, shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the director. The chamber shall be installed at the owner's expense and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(c)  Acceptability or unacceptability of discharge; determination by utility. The public works director shall determine the acceptability or unacceptability of any discharge to the system. Such a determination shall be made on the basis of sound engineering and operational evaluations, taking into consideration the nature and concentration of the discharge, other discharges in the system, its compatibility with the treatment facility receiving it, and all other factors pertinent to the effect of the discharge on any part of the system or treatment process. 
(d)  Unacceptable discharges. Unacceptable discharges shall include, but not necessarily be limited to those which have been determined by the public works director to: 
(1)  Contain materials or substances which would constitute a hazard to life and limb of personnel engaged in inspection, maintenance and operation of the system. 
(2)  Contain materials or substances which are toxic as defined in these regulations. 
(3)  Contain materials or substances which are in any way deleterious to any part of the system. 
(4)  Contain concentrations of any toxic or deleterious materials or substances in excess of any limits set thereon in accordance with these regulations. 
(5)  Cause excessive expense in the handling or treatment thereof. 
(6)  Be incompatible with the treatment process or inhibit the performance of the treatment process at the treatment facility. a 
(7)  Be of such volume or contain such BOD, w suspended solids or other material load which could cause the treatment facility to exceed its design capabilities. 
(8)  Cause the treatment facility to fail to meet effluent requirements set by state and federal regulatory agencies or cause such effluent to have a degrading effect on the receiving body of water. 
(9)  Contain viable pathogenic organisms in such quantities as to be a hazard to public health. 
(10)  Cause a treatment facility to fail to meet effluent requirements as established under the operation permit for sewage treatment plants. 
(e)  Unacceptable discharges; refusal of service. The public works director may refuse the service of the utility's facilities to any person whose discharge is determined by the public works director to be unacceptable. 
(f)  Unacceptable discharges; pretreatment permitted. Any person whose facility discharge has been determined by the public works director to be unacceptable in accordance with the provisions of this chapter may apply to the public works director and the Dade County Water and Sewer Authority for permission to pretreat such discharge by the use of a method of pretreatment designed to render such discharge acceptable. 
(g)  Acceptable methods of pretreatment; review by city; refusal of pretreatment method. The acceptability of a pretreatment method for any given discharge, an application for which has been made in accordance with these regulations and the terms for the installation and use thereof shall be reviewed by the city. Such a review shall be made on the basis of sound engineering and operational evaluations taking into consideration all factors pertinent to the effect of the discharge both before and after pretreatment on any part of the system. 
(h)  Inspection of pretreatment facilities by city. Pretreatment facilities shall at all times be subject to inspection by the city in order to determine if such facilities are efficiently performing the function for which they are installed. 
(i)  Cost of pretreatment to be borne by user. All costs incident to pretreatment and all expenses incident to the acquisition, installation, operation, maintenance and repair of pretreatment facilities shall be borne by the user. In addition, any extraordinary administrative or investigative expenses incurred by the city as a result of the installation and use of pretreatment facilities shall be charged to the user. 
(j)  Discharge of certain materials and substances prohibited. No person shall release or cause to be released or allow to run, leak or escape into the utility's sewerage system any discharge containing any materials or substances considered by the applicable governmental agency to be toxic as defined in these regulations or to be in any way deleterious to any part of the sewerage system or treatment process. Certain materials shall by their nature be considered to be toxic or deleterious except in small quantities or concentrations. Such materials or substances shall include, but not necessarily be limited to: 
(1)  Construction materials, ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastic, wood, paunch manure, fur, wax, or any solid or viscous substance capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interference with the proper operation of the sewerage system. 
(2)  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or explosive liquids, solids, or gases. 
(3)  Steam or hot water above one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit (sixty-five (65) degrees centigrade). 
(4)  Any water or waste containing fats, wax, grease or oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of one hundred (100) mg/l or containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures between thirty-three (33) degrees and one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit (one (1) degree centigrade and sixty-five (65) degrees centigrade). 
(5)  Any water or waste having a pH lower than 5.5 or higher than 10 or having any other corrosive property apt to cause damage or hazard to structures, equipment of the sewerage system, or personnel employed in its operations. 
(6)  Any water or waste containing readily releasable cyanide (cyanide released at a temperature of one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit (sixty-five (65) degrees centigrade) and pH equal to 2.5) in excess of two (2) mg/I; any water or waste containing total cyanide in excess of five (5) mg/I. 
(7)  Coal tar, its derivatives and waste. 
(8)  Any liquid or waste containing toxic or poisonous substances in sufficient quantities or rate of flow as to injure or interfere with any of the sewage treatment process, to constitute a hazard to human beings or animals, or to create any hazard in the receiving waters. 
(k)  Discharge of certain materials permitted conditionally. Certain toxic substances and pathogenic bacteria, admission of which into the system would otherwise be prohibited, shall be acceptable in a discharge if (1) reduced by treatment at the source to a point that will meet the general purposes of these rules and regulations or come within any applicable standards set thereon now or hereafter in accordance with these regulations or (2) discharged in such small concentrations so as to not be injurious to personnel; sewers; any biochemical, biological or other sewage treatment process; or receiving waters. Such substances shall include, but not necessarily be limited to: 
(1)  Any alcohols, antibiotics, arsenic, arsenicals, bromine, iodine, chlorine, copper, copper salts, cresols, creosotes, fluorine, formaldehydes, mercury, mercuricals, phenols, phenol derivatives, silver, silver compounds, silvermides, toxic dyes (organic and mineral), or zinc; 
(2)  Any strong oxidizing agent such as chromates, dichromates, permanganates, or peroxides; 
(3)  Any chemical compound producing toxic flammable, or explosive gases either upon acidification, alkalization, oxidation or reduction; 
(4)  Any strong reducing agent such as nitrates, sulphides, sulfites and thiosulphates; 
(5)  Any waste from industrial processes, hospital procedures or commercial processes containing viable pathogenic organisms. 
(1)  Specific limitations on certain materials and substances in discharges; compatibility with regulatory agency requirement. Table A lists the maximum allowable values for certain materials in, or characteristics of, wastewater entering the sewerage systems. The utility reserves the right to establish standards for substances not contained in this list. In setting additional standards the utility will generally follow the standards of the Water Pollution Control Federation. In defining and interpreting the values in Table A, reference shall be made to "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater," American Water Works Association, latest edition. 
Table A Material or 
Characteristic Maximum 
Allowable 
value Boron 1.0 ppm Chromium, total 10.0 ppm Copper 10.0 ppm Cyanides 2.0 ppm Cadmium 2.0 ppm Lead 0.1 ppm Mercury 2.0 ppm Nickel 10.0 ppm Zinc 10.0 ppm Iron 25.0 ppm Phenols 0.5 ppm BOD 200 ppm Suspended solids 200 ppm PH 5.5-9.5 Temperature 105° F  
The above limitations are intended to apply generally to all industrial users in the sewerage system. If and when any regulatory agency regulations require a specific pretreatment concentration for a specific industry, whichever is the more stringent concentration level between these regulations and such regulations will apply. 
(m)  Discharges containing ground garbage: approval of certain size grinders required. Any discharge to the sewerage system containing garbage may be made acceptable by means of grinding and dilution, provided however that the installation of and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths horsepower (five hundred fifty-nine (559) watts) or greater shall be subject to review and approval by the city prior to such installation and operation and to periodic inspection by the city thereafter. 
(n)  Discharges containing acids and bases; neutralization required. Any water or waste which is unacceptable pursuant to these regulations shall be neutralized, diluted or subjected to some other acceptable method of pretreatment in order to render it acceptable to the applicable governmental agency in accordance with the provisions of this section prior to its discharge to the system. If necessary, the use of automatically operating diluting or neutralization and monitoring equipment shall be required. If, upon neutralization, the discharge is sufficiently high in ionic strength as to continue to be unacceptable, further pretreatment shall be required. 
(o)  Discharge of odors; control by owner required. It shall at all times be the responsibility of the owner to eliminate or control the emission of offensive odors from building sewers to the system or the development of offensive odors in the system as the result of a discharge. Whenever the public works director determines that offensive odors emanating from building sewers or resulting from a discharge are present in the system, he shall require the owner to take whatever steps are necessary to eliminate such odors from the system. The cost of any devices which may be necessary to eliminate or control such odors and all attendant expenses shall be borne by the owner. 
(p)  Prevention of accidental release of unacceptable substances. There shall be no connection to the system from any vessel, tank, container or receptacle of any kind used to receive, hold, store or in any other way handle any toxic or deleterious materials or substances, the discharge of which is prohibited by these regulations through which quantities of such materials or substances could accidentally or otherwise be discharged directly or indirectly into the system. Persons who in the course of their business or otherwise transport, store, receive, ship or in any other way handle or process any such materials or substances shall take precautions to prevent accidental spillage of such substances to any connection to the system by way of floor drains, basins, catch basins, downspouts, gutters, manholes, or any other such connection. Whenever the public works director determines that accidental spillage has occurred through any connection to the system as described above, he shall require the owner to eliminate the connection. 
(q)  Accidental release of unacceptable discharge; notification, charges. In the event of any accidental release to the system of any unacceptable discharge or of any substances or materials considered by the city to be toxic or deleterious as provided in this section, it shall be the responsibility of the user to notify the utility immediately, and in no case later than one (1) hour following such a discharge, at telephone number 893-6511, so that remedial action can be taken. Costs incurred to correct any damage resulting from such a discharge shall be charged to the user and failure to report such a discharge shall result in an additional charge of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) in addition to costs of correction. Each such discharge shall be considered separately and costs and charges levied accordingly. Each day on which there is such a discharge shall be and is hereby deemed to be a separate discharge and charges shall be levied accordingly. Such charges shall be collected by the city. 
(r)  Discharge of unpolluted water. No unpolluted water including all stormwater, surface water groundwater, roof runoff, uncontaminated cooling water, subsurface drainage, or unpolluted industrial process water shall be discharged to the sanitary sewer. Whenever in such areas any such unpolluted water is found to be discharged to sanitary sewer, the public works director shall require such discharge to be connected to a storm sewer or soakage facility at the expense of the user. 
(s)  Failure to comply with (discharge regulations; charges. Any failure to comply with any provision of this section in this Code shall result in an additional charge against the person or premises so failing to comply in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00); in addition, such person or premises shall be liable for any damages which occur to the system as a result of such failure to comply with any provision of these regulations, and each such failure to comply shall be and is hereby deemed to be a distinct and separate failure and charges shall be applied accordingly. Such charges shall be collected in the same manner as all other charges. 
(Code 1958, § 28-38) 
Secs. 19-133-19-145. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE REGULATIONS 

Sec. 19-146. - Construction and Maintenance of sewer systems. 
(a)  Unauthorized work on sewer system. No person shall tamper with, work on, uncover, make connection with, or in any way alter or damage any sewer or sewer appurtenance without written permission of the public works department. Further, unauthorized person shall cause stormwater, groundwater, or any other unauthorized water or material to enter the sanitary sewer system, including sanitary sewage from septic tank trucks. This shall include the tying of downspouts of air conditioning condensate lines into the sewer system, raising of manhole lids to allow for drainage, draining of motor oils, the dumping of garbage, refuse or other wastes in manholes, the draining of swimming pools into sewers or any other means of causing or allowing any substance not considered sanitary sewage or not legally paid for as sanitary sewage, to enter the sewer system. The offending person shall pay the total cost of all charges attributable to such tampering and be subject to all penalties as may be provided by law. 
(b)  Approval of authorized work. All authorized work shall be approved by the director of public works, and all other applicable governmental agencies having jurisdiction. 
(c)  Extent of city maintenance. The city shall be responsible only for the repair and maintenance of all public sewers, public stations, and force mains in the city system and shall make a diligent effort to inspect and keep these facilities in good repair. The city shall not be liable for damages to property resulting from failure of the sanitary sewer system from causes beyond the reasonable control of the city. 
(d)  Customer's maintenance. The customer shall be responsible for the maintenance of the plumbing from the connection at the service lateral into and including the house plumbing, if a common lateral is utilized for two (2) adjacent properties. If a single lateral is utilized exclusively for one (1) property, the customer shall be responsible for keeping the service lateral, in addition to the plumbing, free from obstructions. In either case, the public works department shall have the right to inspect the house connection and plumbing and to discontinue water service to any customer or property owner who fails to maintain the plumbing to the extent that it may or does cause harm to the sewer facilities. 
(e)  Common house connections. A single connection serving two (2) or more properties will not be permitted. In no case will common plumbing to two (2) or more lots or parcels be allowed. 
(f)  Maintenance of single sewer service laterals within city rights-of-way. Upon notification to the city that the customer's sewer service lateral is not functioning properly, the city will assist the customer in the maintenance of that portion of the lateral that is located under street or alley rights-of-way that have been dedicated to the city. After the city has determined that the nonfunctioning portion of the sewer lateral is within the city public rights-of-way, the city will clean and/or commence repairs to that portion of the lateral within forty-eight (48) hours after receipt of notice. In order to receive this service, the city may require the customer to allow the installation of a cleanout on his property near the right-of-way line. The fee for this assistance shall be determined by the city manager as may be set forth by administrative regulation. 
(g)  Maintenance of grease traps. All businesses having grease traps, as required by the South Florida Building Code, that are connected to the sanitary sewer system of the City of North Miami shall properly maintain such traps in the condition for which they were intended. To ensure compliance, each business occupant shall have the grease trap inspected semiannually by a licensed firm qualified to perform such service and if required, the grease trap shall be cleaned or repaired. A certificate of compliance by the licensed firm shall be submitted to the city. The city may require more frequent cleaning if it is proven that semiannual cleanings are not effective in preventing grease from entering the city sewer system. Failure to provide for the certification of compliance shall be sufficient reason for the city to take the necessary steps as prescribed by law to cause the system to be inspected. If such an inspection identifies a condition threatening to the public health, the city shall have the option to terminate water or sewer service to the business occupant. 
(Code 1958, § 28-39) 
Secs. 19-147-19-166. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - RATES AND CHARGES 

Sec. 19-167. - Rates for all consumers. 
(a)  The schedule of rates, fees and other charges to be imposed for the services and facilities furnished by the sewer system shall be as follows: 
(1)  Residences (single-family, townhouses, duplexes and triplexes), multiple-family dwellings (apartments, condominiums): percentage of total water bill as a sewer charge, thirty-one (31) percent. 
(2)  Commercial (stores, office buildings, financial institutions, restaurants, cafeterias, bars, lounges, public and private schools, all businesses engaged in manufacturing, processing or services, trailer parks, motels, hotels and tax exempt organizations) percentage of total water bill as a sewer charge, thirty-six (36) percent. 
(b)  The percentage of the total water bill used as a basis for determining the sewer charge shall be calculated upon the basis of rates provided by section 19-96, without regard to whether water service is actually provided by the city. 
(c)  In addition to rates indicated in subsection (a), a rate of three dollars and thirty-six cents ($3.36) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water used shall be charged sewer utility customers which rate shall cover the cost of sewage treatment and improvements to the sewer system. 
(Code 1958, § 28-37; Ord. No. 1025, § 1, 9-21-99; Ord. No. 1191, § 2, 9-21-05) 
Sec. 19-168. - Inspection of new facilities. 
(a)  Where sanitary sewage facilities are installed, including services, by other than city forces, the work shall be inspected and certified to ensure compliance to federal, state, county and city requirements. The city shall perform the following inspections at the listed fees: 
(1)  Connection to existing water main, each ..... $25.00 
Reinspection, each ..... 10.00 
(2)  Exfiltration test, per manhole section each ..... 50.00 
Reinspection, each ..... 50.00 
(b)  The contractor may elect to use a professional registered engineer or a city-approved technician to certify other mandatory inspections or may utilize the city forces at the following schedule: 
(1)  Television inspection of new sewer lines, per foot of pipe ..... $ 1.00 
Minimum per day ..... 400.00 
(2)  Grease trap certification, each ..... 25.00 
(3)  Field inspection to certify compliance with specifications, per hour for a period as determined by the city ..... 35.00 
(c)  All costs are based on normal working hours of city employees and other hours of service will result in increased fees. All fees must be paid prior to the work being performed unless otherwise approved by the director of public works. The contractor shall pay for all laboratory testing as may be required by regulatory agencies. 
(Code 1958, § 28-13; Ord. No. 1311, § 1, 11-14-10) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 1311, adopted Nov. 14, 2010, repealed the former § 19-168, which pertained to connection charges, and derived from the Code of 1958, § 28-40 and Ord. No. 881, § 8, adopted Sept. 24, 1992. Said ordinance renumbered former §§ 19-169 and 19-170 as §§ 19-168 and 19-169. 
Sec. 19-169. - Unpaid charges constitute lien against property. 
    When sewer service is furnished to the owner, occupant or occupants of premises, the charge for such sewer service shall be, and constitutes, a lien against the premises and shall become effective and binding as such lien from the date upon which the account becomes due, unpaid and in arrears. Liens accrued as set out in this paragraph shall be of the same dignity as liens acquired by virtue of state statutes. 
(Code 1958, § 28-41; Ord. No. 1311, § 1, 11-14-10) 
Editor's note- See editor's note to § 19-168. 
Secs. 19-170-19-185. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - SERVICE OUTSIDE OF THE CITY LIMITS OF THE CITY OF NORTH MIAMI 

Sec. 19-186. - Applications-Forms and plans. 
(a)  All applications for a sewerage system hookup shall be made at the office of the city manager of North Miami, in duplicate, on a blank prepared by the city for that purpose. 
(b)  The owner or owners of the premises proposed to be connected for sewers, or his or their agents thereunto duly authorized, in writing, must sign the application for such services. 
(c)  All applications for sewerage system hookups must be accompanied by a complete set of plans of the project or unit to be serviced, and of main sewer lines and appurtenances, including house connections. 
(Code 1958, § 28-55) 
Sec. 19-187. - Same-Deposit when application not accompanied by plans. 
    Upon receipt for a written application for sewer service, and in the absence of accompanying plans, the city may require a deposit, not to exceed ten (10) percent of the estimated cost of construction, to cover the cost of preparing plans, specifications, and a cost estimate, which deposit shall be credited against the total cost of the main extension. 
(Code 1958, § 28-56) 
Sec. 19-188. - Same-Processing by city officials. 
    All applications for sewerage system hookups, together with any and all plans and other data pertinent thereto, shall, upon receipt by the city manager's office, in the discretion of the city manger, be forwarded to the director of water and sewers, and the city's consulting engineer for review, recommendations, changes, alterations, or otherwise, as may be necessary or deemed advisable. Thereafter, the city manager shall advise the applicant of any recommendations, changes, alterations, or otherwise suggested for incorporation in the application. Upon receipt of the application, incorporating such recommendations, changes, alterations, or otherwise, and alter approval by the city manager, the city manager shall submit to the city council such application for its approval and for authorization to enter into a contract with the applicant for a sewerage system hookup and sewer service. 
(Code 1958, § 28-57) 
Sec. 19-189. - Connection charges. 
    Upon making application for service, the customer shall pay to the city a connection charge as provided in section 19-168. 
(Code 1958, § 28-58.1) 
Sec. 19-190. - State board of health requirements; city's duty. 
    The city shall conform to all requirements of the state board of health for design, construction and operation of its sewer facility and shall furnish all reports required by the state board of health and keep copies of same on file for inspection by the board or its authorized representatives. 
(Code 1958, § 28-59) 
Sec. 19-191. - Operation and maintenance of sewer facility by city; cost. 
    The city shall furnish adequate personnel to operate and maintain all sewerage facilities in accordance with design objectives, and shall flush, clean, and scour all sewer appurtenances located in the public right-of-way and owned by the city, and take any other precautions necessary to eliminate preventable odors, provided, however, that replacement or repair costs other than the normal maintenance of the sewerage facilities such as greasing equipment, cleaning equipment, etcetera, shall be at the customer's expense and delineated specifically in the contract between the city and the customer. 
(Code 1958, § 28-60) 
Sec. 19-192. - Adjustment of erroneous sewer service charges. 
    If the charge for sewer service is based upon a percentage of the water bill and such bill to the customer is found to be in error, regardless of the cause, the sewer charge portion of the bill is to be adjusted accordingly. 
(Code 1958, § 28-61) 
Sec. 19-193. - Right-of-way easement to be furnished by applicant. 
    The applicant shall provide without cost to the city any right-of-way easement required to furnish the service requested by the applicant. 
(Code 1958, § 28-63) 
Secs. 19-194-19-210. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1393, § 1, adopted Nov. 24, 2015, repealed § 19-194 which pertained to collection of pro rata cost of extension facility from subsequent applicants and refund to applicant, derived from the Code of 1958, § 28-64. 
ARTICLE V. - SEWAGE TREATMENT PLANTS AND SEPTIC TANKS 

Sec. 19-211. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Septic tank as used in this article means any watertight tank or receptacle used as a reservoir for receiving or disposing of sewage wastes and the soil absorption field which commonly receives the discharge from such tank or reservoir. 
    Sewage treatment plant means any plant, works or facilities owned or maintained by any person, firm, corporation, estate, trust, joint adventure, partnership or association, or other legal entity excluding partnership or association, or other legal entity excluding governments or governmental agencies, which subjects domestic wastes to any chemical, physical, mechanical or biological process in order to alter their characteristics so as to render them less offensive or dangerous to the health, comfort or property of any of the inhabitants of the City of North Miami, Florida, before the discharge of such wastes into any of the waters in Dade County, Florida, except septic tanks as hereinafter defined. 
(Code 1958, § 28-79) 
Sec. 19-212. - Legislative findings and intent. 
    The city council hereby finds and determines that the construction, installation, operation and removal of sewage treatment plants and septic tanks within the City of North Miami creates dangers to the health, safety and welfare of the residents and visitors of such city and that to protect the health, safety and welfare of such residents and visitors it is necessary to establish and enforce standards regulating the construction, installation, operation and removal of such sewage treatment plants and septic tanks to eliminate the dangers resulting therefrom. This article shall be liberally construed to accomplish this purpose. 
(Code 1958, § 28-78) 
Sec. 19-213. - Approval required. 
    No sewage treatment plant shall be constructed, installed, operated or removed within the City of North Miami, Florida, without the prior written approval of both the director of community planning and development and the director of the water and sewer department of the City of North Miami given in accordance with the standards and requirements of this article. 
(Code 1958, § 28-80) 
Sec. 19-214. - Standards and requirements for sewage treatment plants. 
    The director of community planning and development and the director of the water and sewer department shall not approve the construction, installation, operation or removal of any sewage treatment plant within the City of North Miami, Florida, unless the following standards and requirements are complied with: 
(1)  Setback. No sewage treatment plant or part thereof shall be installed or constructed within the limits of the City of North Miami within one hundred (100) feet from any structure, property line, right-of-way line or other legal boundary line, other than utility easement lines. 
(2)  Landscaping, screening. No sewage treatment plant may be constructed or installed within the limits of the City of North Miami unless it is surrounded by a masonry wall compatible with the subject property and surrounding neighborhood which shall be six (6) feet in height from the highest finished grade elevation within the subject property boundaries and which shall be landscaped with reasonably acceptable foliage which is at least four (4) feet in height at the time of planting and which shall be set no further than four (4) feet apart from stem to stem. 
(3)  Aboveground structure. No sewage treatment plant shall be constructed or installed within the City of North Miami which height is more than five (5) feet above the lowest finished grade elevation within the limits of the subject property. 
(4)  Auxiliary power. No sewage treatment plant shall be constructed or installed within the City of North Miami unless it is supplied with auxiliary standby electrical power sufficient to operate all sewage treatment plant equipment, monitoring equipment and lift stations during any and all primary power failures having a duration of five (5) minutes or more. 
(5)  Auxiliary disinfection equipment. Any sewage treatment plant installed within the limits of the City of North Miami shall be supplied with auxiliary gas chlorination devices which function continuously upon primary power failures and supplies two (2) times the chlorine dosage during such failures. 
(6)  Monitoring equipment. No sewage treatment plant shall be constructed or installed within the City of North Miami unless it is supplied with a continuous recording residual chlorine analyzer which reads out chlorine residual in increments of 0.25 parts per million and which is integrally connected with the gas chlorination equipment with limit switching and set in such a way that the residual chlorine in the final effluent from any sewage treatment plant does not depress below 1.5 parts per million residual chlorine. 
(7)  Geological-hydrological study required. Any application for approval of a sewage treatment plant to be installed within the City of North Miami shall be accompanied by a study of the geological and hydrological characteristics of the area which shall show that none of the final treated effluent disposed of in an approved drainage structure at any time or at any place affects the surface waters of Dade County in such a way as to create pollution or a nuisance as defined in chapter 24 of the Code of Metropolitan Dade County, Florida. 
(8)  Standards adopted. No sewage treatment plant shall be approved unless it complies in all respects with the standards, rules and regulations adopted by Dade County, Florida, and promulgated as Chapter 24 of the Code of Metropolitan Dade County, which standards are adopted herein by reference, as well as all standards and requirements adopted and promulgated by the State of Florida and the City of North Miami. In the event of any conflict between any such standards and regulations, the stricter standards shall apply. 
(9)  Operation, maintenance and costs. Any sewage treatment plant installed within the City of North Miami shall be operated by properly trained, qualified, and certified personnel in accordance with demonstrated education, experimental and technological abilities which meet the promulgated standards for same issued by the water and sewer department. Satisfactory evidence of continuing operation by qualified personnel must be provided to the water and sewer department as a condition precedent to the issuance of any approval for same. All reasonable costs incurred by the city in connection with its review of the qualifications of such personnel, or with its examination an inspection of the proposed plant prior to approval, or with its ongoing periodic inspection, maintenance and testing of installed sewage treatment plants shall be paid by the property owner to the city within thirty (30) days after submission to the property owner or its approved operational personnel of the city's itemized bill for services. When such services are furnished by the city, the charge for same shall be, and constitutes, a lien against the premises and shall become effective and binding as such lien from the date upon which the account becomes due, unpaid and in arrears. Liens so accrued shall be of the same dignity as liens acquired by virtue of state statutes. 
(10)  Operation and maintenance bond required. To secure payment of the costs of operation and maintenance of the sewage treatment plant and to secure payment of all costs in connection therewith which may be incurred by the city pursuant to the provisions of subsection (9) herein, the property owner shall deposit within the city a cash bond equal to twelve (12) times the normal monthly costs of operation and maintenance as determined by the water and sewer department. Any such bond may be required to include such additional sums as are reasonably calculated by the department to cover the costs of any extraordinary maintenance, repairs, testing, inspection and motoring necessary to the proper operation and maintenance of such sewage treatment plant. The director of the water and sewer department shall periodically review the sufficiency of all such bonds and, in the event an increase in the amount of same is necessitated, such bonds must be increased to the required amount within thirty (30) days from notification of same in the same manner as provided for the payment of costs pursuant to subsection (9) herein. 
(11)  Connection to public sanitary sewage system and removal of sewage treatment plant. When a public sanitary sewage system becomes available to service any property using a sewage treatment plant, the property owner shall have ninety (90) days from receipt of written notice by the city of such availability which to connect to the public sanitary sewage system and an additional thirty (30) days in which to remove the sewage treatment plant from his property and to restore the site in a reasonable manner to be established by the director of community planning and development in advance of the installation of the sewage treatment plant. If the property owner fails to comply with the foregoing, the city may take all actions necessary to satisfy these requirements at the expense of the property owner. 
(12)  Odor-free operation. The plant shall be capable of operating in an odor-free manner. 
(13)  Bond required. To guarantee the connection to the public sanitary sewage system, the property owner shall deposit with the city a cash bond of no less than twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) or no less than one hundred fifty (150) percent of the estimated cost of such connection, whichever is greater. Such bond shall be posted upon approval of the sewage treatment plant. In addition to the cash bond specified herein an additional cash bond of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) shall be deposited with the city to ensure the removal of the sewage treatment plant and the restoration of the land on which it sits. All cash bonds deposited with the city pursuant to the provisions of this article may be deposited by the city in nonsegregated accounts and commingled with the general funds of the city. All interest drawn on such funds shall solely inure to the city to offset the city's administrative expenses with respect to this article and no right or entitlement to such interest shall inure to the parties making any such deposits. 
(Code 1958, § 28-81) 
Sec. 19-215. - Septic tanks. 
(a)  Approval required. No septic tank shall be constructed or installed within the City of North Miami without the prior written approval of the director of community planning and development given in accordance with the requirements of this article. 
(b)  Standards. In addition to all other requirements of the State of Florida and County of Dade, no septic tank shall be constructed or installed within this City of North Miami unless the base of the septic tank is at least six (6) inches above the water table. 
(c)  Geological-hydrological study required. No septic tank shall be approved unless the application for approval shall be accompanied by a study of the geological and hydrological characteristics of the area which shall show that none of the final treated effluent disposed of in an approved drainage structure at any time or at any place affects the surface waters of Dade County in such a way as to create pollution or a nuisance as defined in chapter 24 of the Code of Metropolitan Dade County, Florida, which is adopted and incorporated herein by reference. 
(d)  Connection to public sanitary sewage system and deactivation of septic tank. When a public sanitary sewage system becomes available to service any property using a septic tank as provided herein, the property owner shall have ninety (90) days from receipt of written notice of such availability in which to connect to the public sewage system and in which to deactivate such septic tank in accordance with the requirements of the South Florida Building Code. 
(e)  Bond required. To guarantee connection to the public sanitary sewage system and deactivation of such septic tank, a cash bond of five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be posted with the city at the time of approval of the application for a septic tank. 
(Code 1958, § 28-82) 
Sec. 19-216. - Discontinuance of water service for noncompliance with article. 
    In the event of any mechanical, operational or technical failure of the sewage treatment plant, or, in the event of the failure of such plant to meet any required state, county or local standard of operation, or in the event of the failure of the owner to provide qualified operational personnel, or, in the event of the failure of the owner to pay any required increase in bond amount, or in the event of any violation of the provisions of this article, the city shall be entitled to discontinue water service to the premises utilizing such sewage treatment plant in accordance with the provisions of sections 19-56 and 19-107 of this Code. 
(Code 1958, § 28-83) 
Secs. 19-217-19-229. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - UTILITY DEPOSITS AND COMBINED BILLINGS 

Sec. 19-230. - Declaration of exemption from county regulation; equality of water and sewer charges. 
(a)  Exemptions. To the fullest extent allowed by F.S. § 180.191 it is hereby declared that the water and sewer utility system service of the city is exempt from regulation of water and sewer rates, fees and charges by the Metro Dade Water and Sewer Board or other county agency. 
(b)  Equality of charges. Effective upon the adoption of this section, consumers outside of the boundaries of the city shall be charged the same rates, fees and charges as consumers inside the municipal boundaries, as required by F.S. § 180.191(5)(a). The rates, fees and charges provided by this chapter shall be applicable to water and sewer utility service furnished by the city whether within the city limits or outside of the city limits. Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to impose any rate, fee or charge for water and sewer service upon consumers outside of the city limits unless the same rate, fee or charge is imposed upon consumers inside the city limits for such service. 
(c)  Charges subject to lien. Each of the rates, fees and charges provided by this chapter shall be subject to municipal lien to the fullest extent authorized by F.S. § 159.17, and any fees and charges previously incurred shall continue to be subject to such lien until paid. 
(d)  Billing of certain charges. The city water and sewer utility service shall provide for the billing of consumers for any applicable surcharge, pass-through charge or other charge resulting from water and sewer costs otherwise imposed, which are not fully reflected in the charges provided in this chapter, in accordance with the requirements of law. 
(Code 1958, § 28-3; Ord. No. 1025, § 1, 9-21-99) 
Sec. 19-231. - Deposits. 
(a)  Required. The following deposits are hereby required for the city's utility services (water, sewer, garbage and trash collections):

For a residential account established by a tenant rather than the owner, the required deposit shall be four (4) times the amount indicated.
